PREFACE
This code of the city of Bettendorf, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to
and including ordinance 06-25, passed April 1, 2025. Ordinances of the city
adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the city
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
ORDINANCE NO.    07 - 25
 
ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 11, CHAPTER 14 – SIGN ORDINANCE
SECTION 11-4-3(F) GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS AND
SECTION 11-4-8(B) BILLBOARD SIGNS (OFF-PREMISES ADVERTISING)
OF THE BETTENDORF CITY CODE
 
Section 1. BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BETTENDORF, IOWA,
that Title 11, Chapter 14 of the Bettendorf City Code – Sign Ordinance, Section
11-14-3(F) General Requirements and Restrictions – Public Service and Safety
Signs is hereby deleted and the following substituted therefor:
 
F. Signs on Public Property and Rights-of-Way: No signs other than official
signs shall be permitted on public property or rights-of-way. Only signs that
have been placed by or authorized by a federal, state, or local agency may be
installed on public property or rights-of-way. Any sign installed on public
property without prior authorization, including rights-of-way, will be removed
by the City without notice and disposed of.
 
1.   Official Sign Categories:
a.   Public Safety Signs: Traffic signs, directional signage, and construction
signage.
b.      Legal/Public Notice Signs: Any public notice or warning required by
applicable Federal, State or local law, regulation, or ordinance.
c.   Public Utilities: Warning signs, informational signs, notices, or markers
which are customarily erected and maintained by publicly owned or privately-
owned public utilities.
d.   Bettendorf Light Pole Banner Program Signs: A banner affixed to a city-
owned light pole. All banners shall meet the Bettendorf Light Pole Banner
Program policy and guidelines.
 
Section 2. BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BETTENDORF, IOWA,
that Title 11, Chapter 14 of the Bettendorf City Code – Sign Ordinance, Section
11-14-8(B) Billboard Signs (Off-Premises Advertising) - Location is hereby
amended by adding the following thereto:
3. I-80 Urban Renewal Plan Area Exclusion: Regardless of the underlying zoning
district, no billboard signs (static) and no billboard signs (digital display)
shall be permitted in the I-80 Urban Renewal Plan Area. Said area is described
in Resolution 85-17.
 
Section 3. Severability of Provisions. If any subsection, sentence, clause,
phrase, or portion of this ordinance be held invalid or unconstitutional by any
court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate,
distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portion hereof.
 
Section 4. Full Force and Effect. This ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from the date of passage and publications as required by law.
 
Section 5. Repealer. This ordinance shall be construed to repeal any prior
ordinance inconsistent herewith.
 
PASSED, APPROVED, AND ADOPTED this 20th day of May, 2025.
 
Robert S. Gallagher, Mayor
 
ATTEST: Decker P. Ploehn, City Clerk
 
 
ORDINANCE NO. 08-25
 
ORDINANCE AMENDING THE BETTENDORF CITY CODE
SECTION 7-4-2 “LOCATION OF POLES; COUNCIL AUTHORITY”
 
 
Section One. Be It Enacted by the City Council of the city of Bettendorf, Iowa,
that Bettendorf City Code Section 7-4-2 entitled, “Location of Poles; Council
Authority” is hereby amended by adding thereto the following:
 
D. Underground: All cables, wires and conduits in connection with any
communications systems shall be placed underground, except as provided in
subsection E of this section.
 
E. Overhead Permitted: Cables, wires and conduits in connection with a
communications system may be placed overhead in the following circumstances:
1. Areas of the city with an industrial zoning classification and where
existing poles of a franchised utility are to be used.
2. Where aboveground connection to buildings or other locations above ground is
reasonably necessary. Such aboveground connection shall be by means of poles
located, as far as reasonably practicable, outside of street right of way.
 
Section Two. Full Force and Effect. This ordinance shall be in full force and
effect the date of passage and publication as required by law.
 
Section Three. Severability of Provisions. If any section, subsection,
sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this ordinance be held invalid or
unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be
deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall
not affect the validity of the remaining portion thereof.
 
Section Four. Repealer. This ordinance shall be construed to repeal any prior
ordinance inconsistent herewith.
 
Passed, Approved and Adopted this 3rd day of June, 2025.
 
Robert S. Gallagher, Mayor
 
Attest: Decker P. Ploehn, City Clerk
 
 
 
 
ORDINANCE NO. 09 - 25
ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 5 - POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY,
CHAPTER 7 - FIREWORKS, SECTION 5-7-2(A) OF THE BETTENDORF CITY CODE
RELATING TO THE USE OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS
 
Section 1. BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BETTENDORF, IOWA,
that Title 5 – Police and Public Safety, Chapter 7 – Fireworks, Section 5-7-2
(A) - Fireworks Allowed as Specified of the Bettendorf City Code is hereby
amended by deleting the strike through text and adding the underline text:
 
5-7-2: FIREWORKS ALLOWED AS SPECIFIED:
 
A.   Use Of Consumer Fireworks: Consumer fireworks may be used on July 3 and
July 4 from two o'clock (2:00) P.M. nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. until eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. and on the night of December 31 from ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. until twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) A.M. on the
immediately following day. A person shall not use, explode or discharge
consumer fireworks on real property other than that person's real property or
on the real property of a person who has consented to the use of
consumer fireworks on that property. A person that uses, explodes or discharges
consumer fireworks shall have responsibility to clean up all debris created by
the fireworks. A person shall not release or cause to be released an untethered
sky lantern.
 
Section 2. Severability of Provisions. If any subsection, sentence, clause,
phrase, or portion of this ordinance be held invalid or unconstitutional by any
court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate,
distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portion hereof.
 
Section 3. Full Force and Effect. This ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from the date of passage and publications as required by law.
 
Section 4. Repealer. This ordinance shall be construed to repeal any prior
ordinance inconsistent herewith.
 
PASSED, APPROVED, AND ADOPTED this 17th day of June, 2025.
 
Robert S. Gallagher, Mayor
 
ATTEST: Decker P. Ploehn, City Clerk

ORDINANCE NO. 13 - 25
ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 4 - HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT,
CHAPTER 3 - OPEN BURNING
OF THE BETTENDORF CITY CODE
 
Section 1. BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BETTENDORF, IOWA,
that Title 4 – Health, Sanitation and Environment, Chapter 3 – Open Burning of
the Bettendorf City Code is hereby deleted and the following substituted
therefor:
 
4-3-1: OPEN BURNING PROHIBITED: No person shall allow, cause, or permit open
burning of combustible materials, except as provided in City Code section 4-3-
2. The term “open burning” shall mean any burning of combustible materials
where the products of combustion are emitted into the open air without passing
through a chimney or stack.
 
4-3-2: EXCEPTIONS:
 
A. Open burning of the following types is permitted, in compliance with Fire
Department guidelines and subject to regulations in the Iowa Administrative
Code:
 
1.   Fireplaces, wood burning stoves, barbecue grills, and propane or natural
gas fueled devices may be used for the purposes intended by such items.
 
2.   Open fires for cooking, heating, recreation and ceremonies shall be
allowed when such fire is composed of dry wood or commercial fireplace logs and
the location of such fire, and the items necessary for its containment comply
with the provisions of the fire code. However, all such fires are only
permitted between 9:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and must be completely extinguished
by 11:00 p.m. or at the discretion of the Fire or Police Department.
 
3.   Upon permit of the fire chief or assistant fire chief, and payment of a
ten-dollar ($10.00) permit fee, the following additional items may be burned
between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. and must be completely
extinguished by 5:00 p.m. or at the discretion of the Fire or Police
Department:
 
          a.   Disaster rubbish resulting from cleanup of an area within
specifically designated disaster zones.
 
          b.   Trees and tree trimmings by a local governmental entity.
 
          c.   Waste gases via a flare stack.
 
          d.   Landscape waste such as vegetable matter waste produced in
clearing, grubbing, and construction and development operations is limited to
areas located at least one-quarter mile from any building inhabited by anyone
other than the landowner or tenant conducting the open burning.
 
          e.   Training fires as set for bona fide training of public or
industrial employees in firefighting methods.
 
          f.   Paper pesticide containers and seed corn bags resulting from
farming activities occurring on the premises.
 
B. Conditions Of Permit: All such permits shall be subject to compliance by the
applicant with the fire code and guidelines implemented by the Fire Department,
and any regulation in the Iowa Administrative Code regarding such activity.
(2008 Code § 11-2)
 
Section 2. Severability of Provisions. If any subsection, sentence, clause,
phrase, or portion of this ordinance be held invalid or unconstitutional by any
court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate,
distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portion hereof.
 
Section 3. Full Force and Effect. This ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from the date of passage and publications as required by law.
 
Section 4. Repealer. This ordinance shall be construed to repeal any prior
ordinance inconsistent herewith.
 
Section 5. Municipal Infraction. Any person, persons, firm, partnerships, or
corporations, whether acting alone or in concert with any other, who violates
this ordinance shall be guilty of a municipal infraction and shall be penalized
as set forth in Section 1-9 of the City Code of the City of Bettendorf, Iowa.
 
PASSED, APPROVED, AND ADOPTED this 1st day of July, 2025.
 
Robert S. Gallagher, Mayor
 
ATTEST: Decker P. Ploehn, City Clerk
 
 
 
 
ORDINANCE NO. 14 – 25

RESTRICTIONS” BY ADDING A SCHOOL ZONE ON HOPEWELL AVENUE

that Bettendorf City Code Section 6-1-285 (B-9) entitled, “Speed Restrictions”
is hereby amended by adding thereto the following:

Hopewell Avenue from 900 feet east of Triangle Court to 500 feet west of
Criswell Street, 25 miles per hour. At all other times, the speed limit shall
be as established in subsection B8 of this section.
 
Section Two. Full Force and Effect. This ordinance shall be in full force and
effect the date of passage and publication as required by law.

sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this ordinance be held invalid or
unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be
deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall
not affect the validity of the remaining portion thereof.

∙   Forest Grove Drive, from the west city limits to 1,000 feet east of Eagle
Ridge Road, 35 miles per hour
∙   Forest Grove Drive, from Devils Glen Road to the east city limits, 40 miles
per hour

∙   Middle Road from Hopewell Ave to 550 feet south of Forest Grove Drive, 35
miles per hour

miles per hour

Drive, 40 miles per hour
∙   Forest Grove Drive from 500 west of Championship Drive to 425 feet east of
Competition Drive, 15 miles per hour
∙   Forest Grove Drive from 425 feet east of Competition Drive to the east city
limits, 40 miles per hour

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE 03-15
   AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE REVISED BETTENDORF CITY CODE
WHEREAS, the Bettendorf city code was originally published by Municipal Code
Corporation in 1969, and it has been maintained and supplemented by Sterling
Codifiers since 1996; and
WHEREAS, in August, 2013, the city council approved entering into a contract
with Sterling Codifiers to re-organize the Bettendorf city code (res. 173-13);
that process has been completed and the new code is ready for formal adoption;
and
WHEREAS, pursuant Iowa Code section 380.8(2)(b), a public hearing has been held
and a copy of the revised code has been made available for viewing in the
office of the city clerk.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BETTENDORF,
IOWA:
SECTION ONE.
The entirety of the Bettendorf city code (1996 edition) is hereby repealed and
amended by adopting the Bettendorf city code (2015 edition) in its entirety.
SECTION TWO.    Full Force And Effect
This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from the date of passage and
publication as required by law.
SECTION THREE.    Repealer
This ordinance shall be construed to repeal any prior ordinance inconsistent
herewith.
SECTION FOUR.    Severability Of Provisions
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this
ordinance be held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portion hereof.
PASSED, APPROVED, and ADOPTED this 17th day of March, 2015.
      Robert Gallagher, Mayor
ATTEST:
Decker P. Ploehn, City Clerk
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
BETTENDORF CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments To Code
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the city council, this code is hereby declared to be and
shall hereafter constitute the official city code of Bettendorf. This code of
ordinances shall be known and cited as the BETTENDORF CITY CODE and is hereby
published by authority of the city council and shall be supplemented to
incorporate the most recent legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents 1 . (2015 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. IC § 380.8.
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2015 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS TO CODE 1 :
   A.   Effect Of New Ordinances: All ordinances passed subsequent to this code
which amend, repeal or in any way affect this code may be numbered in
accordance with the numbering system of this code and printed for inclusion
herein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or
any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from this code by
omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and
printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of
such subsequent ordinances until such time as this code and subsequent
ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new municipal code.
   B.   Amendatory Language:
      1.   Amendments to any of the provisions of this code may be made by
amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this
code in substantially the following language: "That section             of the
municipal code, city of Bettendorf, Iowa, is hereby amended to read as follows:
. . .". The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired.
      2.   In the event a new section not heretofore existing in this code is
to be added, the following language may be used: "That the municipal code, city
of Bettendorf, Iowa, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered
        , which said section reads as follows: . . .". The new section shall
then be set out in full as desired. (2008 Code § 1-7)
 
Notes
1 2. IC § 380.2.
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions, any
part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions
thereof, or to alter or tamper with this code in any manner whatsoever which
will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. (2008 Code § 1-6)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances; Exclusions
1-2-2: Court Proceedings
1-2-3: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES; EXCLUSIONS:
   A.   Repeal; Exclusions: All general ordinances of the city passed prior to
the adoption of this code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in
this code or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject
to the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed:
      1.   Ordinances promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the
city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of
the city's indebtedness.
      2.   Appropriation ordinances providing for the levy of taxes or
prescribing salaries for city officers.
      3.   Ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations.
      4.   Contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants, or accepting the beneficial interest in
any trust.
      5.   Ordinances establishing street grades, or naming or vacating
streets, alleys or other public places.
      6.   Improvement ordinances.
      7.   Zoning map ordinances.
      8.   Legal descriptions of urban revitalization areas and urban renewal
areas.
      9.   Franchise ordinances.
      10.   Ordinances relating to elections.
      11.   Ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by
or from the city.
      12.   All special ordinances.
   B.   Continuing Effect: All such ordinances, as listed in subsection A of
this section, shall continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if
fully set out herein. (2015 Code)
1-2-2: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not,
as to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act
done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued
or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect
any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Provisions Concerning Repeals:
      1.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals,
either by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance
making any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
(2015 Code)
      2.   Previously Repealed Ordinances Not Revived: The repeal of an
ordinance does not revive an ordinance previously repealed, nor affect any
rights which have accrued, any duty imposed, or any proceedings commenced under
or by virtue of the ordinance repealed. (2008 Code § 1-5)
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the city herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this code. (2015 Code)
1-2-3: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code
or any part thereof or any portion adopted by reference therein is for any
reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this code, or any part thereof or
any portion adopted by reference therein. The city council hereby declares that
it would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or
phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared
unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (2015 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Rules Of Construction
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
In the construction of this code, the following rules shall be observed, unless
such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city
council or repugnant to the context of the provisions: (2008 Code § 1-2)
   A.   Verb Tense And Plurals: Words used in the present or past tense include
the future as well as the present and past, the singular number includes the
plural and the plural number includes the singular.
   B.   Gender: The use of any gender based pronoun should not be construed to
be gender biased, but is only used for grammatical simplicity.
   C.   Interpretation: All general provisions, terms, phrases, and expressions
contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that the true
intent and meaning of the council may be fully carried out.
   D.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring an
officer of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be
construed to authorize the officer to designate, delegate and authorize
subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless
the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise.
   E.   Or, And: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or" if the
sense requires it.
   F.   Nontechnical And Technical Terms: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the context and the approved usage of the language; technical
words and phrases, and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and
appropriate meaning in law, shall be construed according to such meaning.
   G.   Computing Time; Holidays: In computing time, the first day shall be
excluded and the last included, unless the last day falls on Sunday, in which
case the time prescribed shall be extended so as to include the whole of the
following Monday. However, when by the provisions of a statute or rule
prescribed under authority of a statute, the last day for the commencement of
any action or proceedings, the filing of any pleading or motion in a pending
action or proceedings, or the perfecting or filing of an appeal from the
decision or award of a court, board, commission or official falls on a
Saturday, a Sunday, a day on which the office of the clerk of the district
court is closed in whole or in part pursuant to the authority of the supreme
court, January 1, the third Monday in January, February 12, the third Monday in
February, the last Monday in May, July 4, the first Monday in September,
November 11, the fourth Thursday in November, December 25 and the following
Monday when any of the foregoing named legal holidays fall on a Sunday, and any
day appointed or recommended by the governor of Iowa or the president of the
United States as a day of fasting or thanksgiving, the time shall be extended
to include the next day which the office of the clerk of the court or the
office of the board, commission, or official is open to receive the filing of a
commencement of an action, pleading or a motion in a pending action of
proceeding, or the perfecting or filing of an appeal.
   H.   Officials, Boards, Commissions: Whenever reference is made to
officials, boards and commissions by title only, i.e., "council", "clerk", "the
mayor", etc., they shall be deemed to refer to the officials, boards and
commissions of the city of Bettendorf.
   I.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the city
has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter", "section"
and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to the city's ordinances is not meant
to amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2008 Code §
1-2; amd. 2015 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this code, unless specifically defined otherwise in another
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
CITY OR THIS CITY: The city of Bettendorf, Iowa, and extending to its several
officers, agents and employees.
CODE: The city code of Bettendorf, Iowa.
COUNCIL: The city council of Bettendorf, Iowa.
COUNTY: Scott County, Iowa.
IC: Iowa Code, as amended.
PERSON: Shall include and be applied to corporations, associations, clubs,
societies, firms, partnerships, municipalities and bodies politic and corporate
as well as to individuals.
STATE OR THE STATE: The state of Iowa. (2008 Code § 1-2; amd. 2015 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections and subsections of this code are
intended as mere catchwords to indicate the content of the section or
subsection and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections or
subsections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the
scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any section or subsection hereof,
nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such
sections or subsections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted.
(2015 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Municipal Infractions; Civil Penalty
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY 1 :
   A.   Penalty Imposed: The doing of any act prohibited or declared to be
unlawful or a misdemeanor by this Code, or the omission or failure to perform
any act or duty required by this Code, unless another penalty is specified,
shall be punishable in accordance with the fine set forth in Iowa Code sections
903.1(1)(a) and 903.1(3). (Ord. 01-18, 1-2-2018)
   B.   Construction Zone; Traffic Restrictions; Penalty: When appropriate
signs delineate the beginning and ending of a construction zone, the Chief of
Police may establish speed restrictions or other traffic control measures
within that zone for the length of time of the construction project which are
more restrictive than those established in this Code. Upon removal of the
signs, the temporary restrictions shall end. Penalties for the violations of
these temporary restrictions shall be as established for the violations under
State law, including, but not limited to, any enhanced penalty for violation
occurring in construction zones. (2008 Code § 1-8)
 
Notes
1 1. IC § 364.3(2).
1-4-2: MUNICIPAL INFRACTIONS; CIVIL PENALTY:
   A.   Violations Subject To Civil Penalty: Except as otherwise provided in
this Code, all violations of this Code may be charged as Municipal infractions.
(2008 Code § 1-9; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Repeat Offense: A repeat offense is a recurring violation of the same
section or provision of this Code by the same individual.
   C.   Violation, Penalties And Alternative Relief:
      1.   Every violation of the provisions listed in subsection A of this
section is a Municipal infraction.
      2.   Each day a violation occurs constitutes a separate offense.
      3.   Unless specified elsewhere, a Municipal infraction is a civil
offense punishable as follows:
         a.   First offense: Seventy five dollars ($75.00).
         b.   Second offense by the same defendant of the same provision of
subsection A of this section: Two hundred dollars ($200.00).
         c.   Third or further offense by the same defendant of the same
provision of subsection A of this section: Seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00).
         d.   Any violation arising from noncompliance with a pretreatment
standard or requirement referred to in 40 CFR 403.8 by an industrial user: One
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per occurrence per day.
      4.   Any civil penalty provided herein shall be nonexclusive. The City
shall remain free to issue a Municipal infraction as well as take any other
action to end the violation.
      5.   Nothing in this section shall be a limitation on the ability of a
peace officer from issuing a citation for a violation of this Code as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this chapter.
   D.   Civil Citations: Any employee, agent, contracted service provider, or
officer of the City employed to enforce subsection A of this section may issue
a civil citation to the person who is alleged to have committed a Municipal
infraction.
      1.   The citation shall serve as notification of the violation of
subsection A of this section, shall be served by personal service or by
certified mail, return receipt requested. One copy of the citation shall be
filed with the Clerk of the District Court, and one shall be retained by the
City, the defendant shall receive one copy, and one copy shall be provided to
the City Attorney.
      2.   The citation shall contain the following information:
         a.   The name, address, date of birth, and social security number of
the alleged violator.
         b.   The name or description of the alleged infraction, attested to by
the officer issuing the citation.
         c.   The location and time of the alleged infraction.
         d.   The amount of civil penalty for the violation charged and the
court costs or the alternative relief sought, or both.
         e.   The manner, location and time in which the penalty may be paid.
         f.   The time and place of court appearance.
         g.   A statement of the penalty for failure to appear in court. (2008
Code § 1-9)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for failure to perform such duty unless the intention of
the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (2015
Code)
CHAPTER 5
ELECTIONS 1
SECTION:
1-5-1: Holding Elections
1-5-2: Election Of Officers; Terms
1-5-3: Method Of Nomination
1-5-4: Notice Of Election
1-5-5: Filing Of Nominating Petitions
1-5-6: Voter Registration; Maintenance Of List
 
Notes
1 1. IC § 376.1 et seq.
1-5-1: HOLDING ELECTIONS:
A regular city election shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first
Monday in November of each odd numbered year. Other elections shall be held in
the manner provided by state law. (2008 Code § 9-1)
1-5-2: ELECTION OF OFFICERS; TERMS:
   A.   Election: There shall be a mayor and two (2) council members elected at
large and five (5) council members each of whom is elected from a ward as
defined in article A of this chapter.
   B.   Terms:
      1.   The term of office for the mayor and council shall be four (4)
years, beginning and ending at twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on January 1 which
is not a Sunday or legal holiday, following the regular city election.
      2.   The terms of the council members shall be staggered with one at
large and the first, third and fifth ward council members elected in one
election cycle, and balance of the council elected in the next cycle. (2008
Code § 9-2)
1-5-3: METHOD OF NOMINATION:
Nominations for office shall be as provided in Iowa Code chapters 44 and 45 as
such chapters exist now or may be amended in the future. (2008 Code § 9-3)
1-5-4: NOTICE OF ELECTION:
The council shall call for a special election by passing a resolution calling
therefor. The city clerk shall provide a copy of the resolution to the county
commissioner of elections. The county commissioner of elections shall publish
notice pursuant to state code. (2008 Code § 9-35)
1-5-5: FILING OF NOMINATING PETITIONS:
Nominating petitions shall be filed with the office of the county auditor.
(2008 Code § 9-36; amd. 2015 Code)
1-5-6: VOTER REGISTRATION; MAINTENANCE OF LIST:
Registration of voters shall be conducted by the county commissioner of
elections (county auditor) pursuant to Iowa Code chapter 48A, as amended.
Maintenance of the voter registration list shall be performed by the county
commissioner of elections. (2008 Code § 9-37; amd. 2015 Code)

CHAPTER 6
CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-6-1: Powers And Authority
1-6-2: Meetings
1-6-3: Compensation
1-6-4: Filling Vacancies In Elected Offices
1-6-1: POWERS AND AUTHORITY:
   A.   Powers: The Council shall have those powers and responsibilities
provided by State law and those powers and responsibilities as set by this
Code. (2008 Code § 2-1)
   B.   Authority: The Council shall have the management and control of the
finances and of the property of the City. No elected or appointed official,
agent or employee may enter into any contract or agreement for labor,
materials, equipment or supplies or for disbursing Municipal funds unless such
power is delegated or granted by express action of the Council. (2008 Code § 2-
3)
1-6-2: MEETINGS:
   A.   Time And Place: The meetings of the Council shall be on the first and
third Tuesdays of each month in the Council Chambers of City Hall.
   B.   Open Meetings; Moving; Scheduling: The meetings shall be open to the
public and may be moved or rescheduled or additional meetings called as are
necessary. (2008 Code § 2-2)
1-6-3: COMPENSATION:
A member of the Council shall receive compensation as follows:
   A.   Compensation; Payment:
      1.   Amount: For participation in the management and control of the
finances and of the property of the City, each member of Council shall receive
six hundred forty nine dollars seventy five cents ($649.75) per calendar month.
Payment shall be withheld from any member of the Council who misses all
meetings of the Council and Committee of the Whole scheduled during the
calendar month. (Ord. 12-19, 7-2-2019, eff. 1-2-2020)
      2.   Increase: On January 1, 2001, the monthly compensation for the
Council shall be increased by the average increase in prices for the Midwest
region as established by the Federal government via the consumer's price index
for the prior twelve (12) months. Each January 1 thereafter a similar
adjustment in compensation, either up or down, shall be made based upon that
index.
   B.   Reimbursement For Expenses: There shall be reimbursement for actual
expenses incurred while in the performance of the member's duties. (2008 Code §
2-4)
1-6-4: FILLING VACANCIES IN ELECTED OFFICES:
Unless otherwise mandated by State Code, the Council, when it desires to fill a
vacancy in elected office by appointment, shall use the following procedure:
   A.   A notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in
the City indicating the vacancy and requesting resumes of interested persons.
   B.   All resumes thus obtained shall be provided to the Council.
   C.   The Council may hold a special session to review and evaluate the
resumes or conduct any interviews desired.
   D.   The Council shall thereafter appoint a person to fill the unexpired
term by resolution. (2008 Code § 2-5)
CHAPTER 7
MAYOR
SECTION:
1-7-1: Powers And Authority
1-7-2: Compensation
1-7-3: Emergency Power Of Mayor
1-7-4: Emergency Parking Restrictions
1-7-1: POWERS AND AUTHORITY:
   A.   Powers: The Mayor shall have the powers and responsibilities prescribed
by State Code and those powers and responsibilities as set by this Code. (2008
Code § 2-10)
   B.   Authority:
      1.   The Mayor shall sign on behalf of the City all contracts when
authorized by the Council. The Mayor shall appoint persons to positions on the
various boards and commissions subject to Council approval and shall supervise
the City Administrator and assist the Administrator in carrying out Council
approved policies and directives. (Ord. 02-18, 1-16-2018)
      2.   The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the Council and the
Committee of the Whole.
      3.   The Mayor shall make announcements to the Council on the state of
the City at the first meeting of the Council in January and at such other times
and on such other topics as the Mayor deems necessary for the adequate
administration of the City. (2008 Code § 2-11)
1-7-2: COMPENSATION:
The Mayor shall be paid twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per year of
service payable in biweekly increments, plus reimbursement for actual expenses
incurred while in the performance of the Mayor's duties. On January 1, 2021,
the annual compensation for the Mayor shall be increased by the average
increase in prices for the Midwest region as established by the Federal
government via the consumer price index for the prior twelve (12) months. Each
January 1 thereafter a similar adjustment in compensation, either up or down,
shall be made based upon that index. (Ord. 12-19, 7-2-2019, eff. 1-2-2020)
1-7-3: EMERGENCY POWER OF MAYOR:
   A.   Declaration Of Emergency; Issuance Of Directions: Pursuant to Iowa Code
section 372.14 and this section, upon making a determination that a time of
emergency or public danger exists, the Mayor shall make a declaration of
emergency and shall govern the City by proclamation. Upon issuing the
declaration, the Mayor shall direct the Police, Fire and other departments to:
      1.   Take such action as will preserve and protect life.
      2.   Take such action as will preserve and minimize damage to property.
      3.   Take such action as to allow the continuation of City services to
the residents of the City.
   B.   Powers Of Mayor: Under a declaration of emergency, the Mayor shall be
empowered to:
      1.   Close public ways and places, or restrict their use.
      2.   Establish hours of curfew.
      3.   Procure by purchase or lease goods and services necessary to the
City's emergency response effort.
      4.   Contract for the repair of City buildings or facilities.
      5.   Lease such additional property or space deemed necessary for the
continued operation of City government and the providing of City services.
   C.   Violations Deemed Misdemeanor: Violation of any proclamation issued by
the Mayor or Mayor Pro Tem under a declaration of emergency shall be deemed a
violation of this section and punishable as a misdemeanor as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this title.
   D.   Mayor Pro Tem Powers: In the absence of the Mayor, or the Mayor's
inability to act, the Mayor Pro Tem shall have the powers of the Mayor under
this section.
   E.   Directions To City Employees And Volunteers: The Mayor may direct City
employees and volunteers in performance of emergency response; may establish a
hierarchy of command in such response; and may, by proclamation, delegate
purchasing authority to a specific person or persons.
   F.   Time Limitation: Any declaration of emergency declared by the Mayor
shall be directly related to the emergency itself, and shall exist only for so
long as is reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency confronting the
City and its residents; it being the goal of all parties to resume normal
governance as quickly as possible. (2008 Code § 2-14)
1-7-4: EMERGENCY PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Designation Of No Parking Or Restricted Parking Zones:
      1.   Whenever construction, accident or other emergency situation
requires the designation of certain streets as no parking or parking restricted
zones, the Mayor is hereby authorized to issue an order restricting parking
valid until the next regularly scheduled meeting of the Council.
      2.   The violation of any order under this section shall subject the
owner of the vehicle involved to the fine listed in section
6-1-140 of this Code.
   B.   Signs Posted: Whenever the Mayor acts pursuant to this section, the
zone shall be marked by signs at the start and end of the zone and along so
much of it as will provide notice of the parking restriction. (2008 Code § 2-
13)
CHAPTER 8
CITY ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-8-1: Office Created; Term; Qualifications
1-8-2: Appointment Procedure
1-8-3: Powers And Duties
1-8-4: Responsibility To City Council
1-8-5: Compensation
1-8-6: Nonsupervisory Relationship To City Attorney
1-8-7: Participation In Partisan Politics Restricted
1-8-8: Initiation Of Removal
1-8-9: Duties As Clerk And Treasurer
1-8-1: OFFICE CREATED; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Office Created: The office of the administrator is hereby created,
which office shall be filled by the favorable vote of at least two-thirds (2/3)
of all the members of the council confirming the appointment to the office by
the mayor.
   B.   Term; Removal: The city administrator shall hold office at the pleasure
of the council and shall be subject to removal only by the favorable vote of at
least two-thirds (2/3) of all the members of the council.
   C.   Qualifications: The administrator shall be qualified by experience and
training to perform the duties set forth in this chapter. (2008 Code § 2-30)
1-8-2: APPOINTMENT PROCEDURE:
In the event of a vacancy in the office of city administrator, the following
procedure shall be used:
   A.   The human resources director shall prepare a job description, position
requirements and pay range for the position, and provide them to the mayor and
council for comment.
   B.   After comments are received, considered, and incorporated, the human
resources director shall publicize the vacancy in a manner calculated to
generate interest in the position.
   C.   The mayor shall appoint three (3) council members who shall oversee the
process of candidate recruitment. Any council member requesting, however, shall
have access to the resumes received and may attend and participate in candidate
interviews. The members appointed shall advise the mayor of the names of the
persons they would consider finalists for the position.
   D.   When the candidate field is narrowed, the mayor and council shall
conduct finalist interviews. The mayor shall select one of the finalists and
recommend that selection to the council for approval. If approved, that person
shall serve as city administrator. If the council fails to approve the choice,
the mayor may select from the other finalists, or the process shall begin anew.
(2008 Code § 2-33; amd. 2015 Code)
1-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The powers and duties of the city administrator shall,
subject to the powers and duties of the mayor as provided by law, include the
following:
      1.   Implementing all policy directives promulgated by the mayor in the
mayor's executive capacity, and by the council in its legislative capacity.
      2.   Administration of all ordinances, resolutions, council policies and
directives.
      3.   Responsibility for all accounting and accounting procedures for the
municipality.
      4.   Preparation and administration of the city's annual operating
budget.
      5.   Supervision of the city's administrative policies and procedures,
including personnel and purchasing.
      6.   Keeping the council informed on the progress of its programs and the
status of its policies.
      7.   Coordination and direction of all city services provided through the
various departments.
      8.   Employment and removal of city employees in accordance with council
approved policies on hiring and discipline.
      9.   Studying possible joint arrangements with municipal boards and
commissions; making recommendations for such arrangements as are mutually
acceptable and coordinating these activities as agreed upon.
      10.   Assisting the mayor in any mayoral duties as requested by the
mayor.
      11.   Assisting the council and the planning and zoning commission in the
carrying out of the comprehensive plan and assisting in all other forms of
planning within the city government.
   B.   Contractual Duties: Where the city has contracted jointly with other
governmental subdivisions, the state of Iowa or the United States Of America,
the administrator shall act for the city in the execution of said contract.
   C.   Operational Control; Performance Evaluation:
      1.   The city administrator shall have daily operational control of all
city departments, with the exception of the library.
      2.   Department heads shall report to the city administrator. The city
administrator will have the responsibility for the performance evaluation and
salary adjustments of all department heads except the library director in
consultation with the council or other appropriate boards or commissions.
   D.   Work With Park Board: Recognizing that the park board is an elected
body, the administrator shall work with the board to accomplish its goals and
objectives consistent with council approved policies and funding. (2008 Code §
2-31)
   E.   Performance Of Additional Duties: The city administrator shall perform
such other duties as may hereafter be directed by the council, which duties are
not in conflict with the provisions of this chapter. (2008 Code § 2-36)
1-8-4: RESPONSIBILITY TO CITY COUNCIL:
The city administrator shall be directly responsible to the city council for
the administration of municipal affairs as directed by that body. All
departmental activity requiring the attention of the council shall be brought
before the body by the administrator, and all council involvement in
administration initiated by the council must be coordinated through the
administrator. (2008 Code § 2-32)
1-8-5: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the city administrator shall be in such amount as may from
time to time be fixed by the council. (2008 Code § 2-34)
1-8-6: NONSUPERVISORY RELATIONSHIP TO CITY ATTORNEY:
The city attorney shall not be considered to be a department head for purposes
of this chapter and shall continue to be appointed by and be directly
responsible to the city council. (2008 Code § 2-35)
1-8-7: PARTICIPATION IN PARTISAN POLITICS RESTRICTED:
The city administrator shall not, during the term of office, engage in partisan
politics in connection with city municipal elections. (2008 Code § 2-37)
1-8-8: INITIATION OF REMOVAL:
Either the mayor or any member of the city council may initiate the removal of
the city administrator. (2008 Code § 2-38)
1-8-9: DUTIES AS CLERK AND TREASURER:
   A.   Clerk: The city administrator shall serve as city clerk and perform all
duties of the clerk required by the state code or this code. (2008 Code § 2-39)
   B.   Treasurer: The city administrator shall perform such duties as are
required of the city treasurer under city or state code. No additional
compensation shall be afforded the city administrator for such service. (2008
Code § 2-20)
CHAPTER 9
CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-9-1: Appointment And Removal Procedure; Compensation
1-9-2: Duties Enumerated
1-9-3: Attendance At Meetings
1-9-1: APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL PROCEDURE; COMPENSATION:
   A.   Appointment; Term; Legal Opinions:
      1.   A city attorney shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the
council (as described in subsection B of this section) to hold office until
such time as the council shall initiate removal.
      2.   It shall be expected that the city attorney provide independent
legal opinions without regard to politics or impact of the opinion.
      3.   The council may appoint additional attorneys when and upon such
conditions as the council deems appropriate.
   B.   Procedure For Filling Vacancy: In the event of a vacancy in the office
of city attorney, the following procedure shall be used:
      1.   The human resources director shall prepare a job description,
position requirements (license to practice law, etc.) and pay range for the
position, and provide them to the mayor, administrator, and council for
comment.
      2.   After comments are received, considered, and incorporated, the human
resources director shall publicize the vacancy in a manner calculated to
generate interest in the position.
      3.   The mayor shall appoint three (3) council members who shall oversee
the process of candidate recruitment. Any council member requesting, however,
shall have access to the resumes received and may attend and participate in
candidate interviews. The members appointed shall advise the mayor of the names
of the persons it would consider finalists for the position.
      4.   When the candidate field is narrowed, the mayor and council shall
conduct finalist interviews. The mayor shall select one of the finalists and
recommend that selection to the council for approval. If approved, that person
shall serve as city attorney. If the council fails to approve the choice, the
mayor may select from the other finalists, or the process shall begin anew.
   C.   Term; Removal: The city attorney shall hold office at the pleasure of
the council and may be removed upon the favorable vote of two-thirds (2/3) of
all members of the council.
   D.   Compensation: Compensation for the city attorney and any assistants
shall be set by the council. (2008 Code § 2-40)
1-9-2: DUTIES ENUMERATED:
   A.   Preparation Of Ordinances And Resolutions:
      1.   The city attorney shall draft ordinances or resolutions upon request
of any member of the council, the mayor or the city administrator.
      2.   The city attorney shall review this code and update ordinances as
necessary but no less than once every five (5) years.
      3.   The city attorney shall review all proposed ordinances and
resolutions prior to council approval. (2008 Code § 2-41)
   B.   Litigation: The city attorney shall appear in all cases in which the
city is a party or has an interest unless otherwise directed by the council and
shall monitor cases handled on behalf of the city when not directly involved.
(2008 Code § 2-42)
   C.   Opinions: Consistent with the mandates of the open records law, the
city attorney shall exercise and maintain the attorney-client privilege. At the
direction of the mayor, council or city administrator, the city attorney may
release documents which otherwise would be covered by the attorney- client
privilege or which would be considered the work product of the attorney. (2008
Code § 2-43)
   D.   Advisory Duties: The city attorney shall act as legal advisor to the
mayor and council and the departments when requested by the council or the city
administrator. Such duties shall include responding to requests but shall be
limited to questions of compatibility of the action with city, state or federal
law and not be a review or critique of policy decisions set by others. Advisory
actions of the city attorney need not be in writing. (2008 Code § 2-44)
   E.   Drafting Documents: Upon request, the city attorney shall draft or
review contracts, leases or other documents for use by the mayor, council or
city departments. When authorized by resolution, the attorney may sign
documents on behalf of the city. (2008 Code § 2-45)
   F.   Code Enforcement: The city attorney or the assistant city attorney
shall prosecute all violations of this code. (2008 Code § 2-46)
   G.   Other Duties: The city attorney shall perform such other duties as the
council shall direct. (2008 Code § 2-47)
1-9-3: ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS:
The city attorney shall attend all regular and special meetings of the council,
the council's committee of the whole and such committees of the council or the
city's boards as the council shall direct unless excused by vacation or
illness. (2008 Code § 2-48)
CHAPTER 10
CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-10-1: Oath Of Office
1-10-2: Terms Of Office
1-10-3: Removal Of Appointees; Hearing
1-10-4: Department Heads
1-10-1: OATH OF OFFICE:
All officials of the City shall qualify for office by taking the following
oath:
I,                    do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of
the United States and of the State of Iowa, and that I will faithfully and
impartially to the best of my ability discharge all the duties of the office of
                       in the City of Bettendorf as now or hereafter required
by law.
(2008 Code § 2-101)
1-10-2: TERMS OF OFFICE:
Terms of elected officials shall begin and end at twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
on January 1 which is not a Sunday or legal holiday following a regular City
election for the position. (2008 Code § 2-102)
1-10-3: REMOVAL OF APPOINTEES; HEARING:
All persons appointed to City office may be removed by the officer or body
making the appointment, but every such removal shall be by written order. The
order shall give the reasons, be filed in the Office of the City Clerk, and a
copy shall be sent by certified mail to the person removed who, upon request
filed with the Clerk within thirty (30) days of the date of mailing the copy,
shall be granted a public hearing before the Council on all issues connected
with the removal. The hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days of the date
the request is filed unless the person requests a later date. (2008 Code § 2-
103)
1-10-4: DEPARTMENT HEADS:
   A.   Appointment; Approval; Salary: The City Administrator shall appoint all
department heads. All department heads shall be subject to Council approval,
and the salary for the department head shall be as the Council sets. (Ord. 02-
18, 1-16-2018)
   B.   Duties Generally: The department heads shall have those duties as are
in their job descriptions, prescribed by State Code or as contained in this
Code. (2008 Code § 2-51)
   C.   Specific Officials, Duties:
      1.   Finance Director: The Finance Director shall consult with the City
Treasurer and Mayor in addition to the City Administrator regarding
investments. The Finance Director shall provide periodic reports to the Council
on the state of City finances.
      2.   Director Of Public Works:
         a.   The Director of Public Works is hereby granted authority to
approve the change orders on contracts for the construction or repair of public
improvements; provided, that any change order shall not exceed five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) or change the size or scope of the public improvement. All
other change orders shall be subject to approval by the Council. (2008 Code §
2-52)
         b.   The Director of Public Works or his or her designee is also
authorized to review and accept on behalf of the City construction plans for
subdivision improvements that are to be accepted by the City upon completion.
In the event the Director refuses to accept or approve such plans, the property
owner may appeal to the Council for review and decision. (2008 Code § 2-52;
amd. 2015 Code)
ARTICLE A. CITY PERSONNEL
SECTION:
1-10A-1: Civil Service And Retirement Systems
1-10A-2: Personnel Policies
1-10A-3: Positions And Pay Grade
1-10A-4: Appeals
1-10A-1: CIVIL SERVICE AND RETIREMENT SYSTEMS:
The city shall follow the state code as it relates to civil service, public
employer retirement and public safety employee retirement systems. (2008 Code §
2-90)
1-10A-2: PERSONNEL POLICIES:
Personnel policies, including sick leave and vacation, shall be established
from time to time by the council by resolution. The policies shall be codified
in an employee's handbook and distributed to the employees. (2008 Code § 2-91)
1-10A-3: POSITIONS AND PAY GRADE:
   A.   Classifications, Job Descriptions And Pay Grades: The council has
adopted by resolution a classification, job description and pay grade for each
position in the city. Some pay grades may be established through collective
bargaining. (2008 Code § 2-92)
   B.   Changes In Position: Upon a vacancy in a position, the city
administrator shall determine whether the position's duties and pay grade
should be changed. In the event the position's duties and pay grade are not to
be changed and the position is budgeted, the administrator may fill the
position. If the administrator recommends a change in either duties or pay
grade, the administrator shall report the recommendation to the council, and
the vacancy shall not be filled until the council acts thereon. (2008 Code § 2-
93)
   C.   New Positions: No position shall be created unless a job description
and pay grade is established therefor. (2008 Code § 2-94)
1-10A-4: APPEALS:
   A.   Request For Review: An employee may at any time submit a written
request to his department head for a review of the classification and/or
compensation of his position setting forth the employee's reasons justifying
the review.
   B.   Investigation: The department head will make an investigation of the
position with the purpose of determining if the employee's request is justified
and will report the findings in writing to the city administrator and to the
employee.
   C.   Department Head Decision Appealed To Administrator: The decision of the
department head may be appealed to the city administrator who may review the
decision, take any additional evidence deemed necessary and affirm or modify
the decision of the department head. The administrator's decision shall be
final unless a collective bargaining agreement provides for further review.
(2008 Code § 2-95)
CHAPTER 11
MISCELLANEOUS ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-11-1: Leasing Of Space
1-11-1: LEASING OF SPACE:
City departments, upon the approval of the administrator, may lease space in
city facilities to a private vendor, upon such terms and conditions as are
deemed appropriate, provided no such lease may extend beyond three (3) years
without public hearing and council approval as provided by law; and provided
further, that any such lease must provide materials and/or services
complementary to the functioning of the city facility. (2008 Code § 2-115)
TITLE 2
BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES
CHAPTER 1
BOARDS GENERALLY
SECTION:
2-1-1: Compensation; Vacancies; Appointments; Procedure
2-1-1: COMPENSATION; VACANCIES; APPOINTMENTS; PROCEDURE:
   A.   Serving Without Compensation: Persons appointed to any board shall
serve without compensation therefor.
   B.   Appointments To Vacancies:
      1.   Appointments to vacancies on a board shall be deemed to fill the
unexpired term for which the appointment is made.
      2.   The mayor shall appoint to fill any vacancy subject to approval by
the council.
   C.   Expiration Of Term: In the event a member's term expires, the member
shall hold over until a successor is appointed.
   D.   Authority To Establish Rules And Regulations: All boards shall have
authority to establish rules and regulations governing the procedures used by
the board. (2008 Code § 2-60)
CHAPTER 2
BETTENDORF FUND BOARD
SECTION:
2-2-1: Bettendorf Fund
2-2-2: Bettendorf Fund Board
2-2-1: BETTENDORF FUND:
   A.   Fund Established: There is hereby established a "Bettendorf fund",
which shall be a separate fund from the general revenues of the city, to be
used as an incentive to enable development and redevelopment to occur in the
city. Persons or businesses donating to the fund may do so with the
understanding and expectation that such donations will be used exclusively for
that purpose. In addition, the city's finance director and community
development director shall serve as ex officio members.
   B.   Trust Account; Disbursement Of Funds: The funds shall be held in a
trust account at a bank or savings and loan having a branch in Bettendorf. The
trustee shall be authorized to invest any funds held in the same manner and
with the same restrictions as the investment of other public funds. The trustee
shall disburse funds upon a resolution by the Bettendorf fund board and by the
city council so authorizing. Interest and principal may be used for any
development or redevelopment project. (2008 Code § 2-82)
2-2-2: BETTENDORF FUND BOARD:
   A.   Board Established; Compensation: There is hereby established a
Bettendorf fund board composed of seven (7) members who shall serve without
compensation.
   B.   Terms: The members of the board shall serve for a three (3) year term.
For purposes of staggering terms under this section, upon initial appointment,
three (3) members shall serve for one year, three (3) members shall serve for
two (2) years, and one member shall serve for three (3) years.
   C.   Appointment; Qualifications: Members shall be appointed by the mayor
and approved by the council. Members should have background or experience in
economic development projects, although at least one member shall represent the
public generally. Nominations for the board may be received from the council,
Bettendorf chamber of commerce, Bettendorf Development Corporation, and
interested citizens.
   D.   Duties: Members shall:
      1.   Assist in fundraising efforts.
      2.   Evaluate proposals for expenditures from the fund.
      3.   Authorize expenditures from the fund (no money will be spent,
however, without council concurrence).
      4.   Perform such other duties as the mayor and council shall direct.
(2008 Code § 2-83)
CHAPTER 3
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION; PLANNING DEPARTMENT 1
SECTION:
2-3-1: Commission Created; Appointment
2-3-2: Qualifications
2-3-3: Terms
2-3-4: Vacancies
2-3-5: Compensation; Conflict Of Interest
2-3-6: Powers And Duties
2-3-7: Commission Meetings
2-3-8: Annual Report
2-3-9: Director Of Community Development, Staff Advisor
2-3-10: Council Members Attend Meetings; Assistance By City Officials
2-3-11: Report To Council
2-3-12: Community Development Department
 
Notes
1 1. IC § 392.1 et seq.
2-3-1: COMMISSION CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created and established in the city a city planning and zoning
commission consisting of seven (7) members who shall be appointed by the mayor,
subject to the approval of the council. (2008 Code § 22-1)
2-3-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
All members of the planning and zoning commission shall be citizens and
residents of the city and qualified by knowledge or experience to act in
matters pertaining to the development and execution of a city plan. No person
holding an elective office in the city shall be eligible to appointment upon
the commission. (2008 Code § 22-2)
2-3-3: TERMS:
The term of office of members of the planning and zoning commission shall be
five (5) years from the date of the appointment of each respective member. The
expiration date for all terms of office shall be the first Monday in November;
however, all members shall hold over until their successors are appointed and
approved. (2008 Code § 22-3)
2-3-4: VACANCIES:
Any vacancy in the membership of the commission shall be filled by the mayor,
subject to the approval of the council, for the remainder of the vacant term.
(2008 Code § 22-4)
2-3-5: COMPENSATION; CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
No member of the planning and zoning commission shall receive any compensation
for his services nor shall any member of the commission act or join in any
action hereunder in which said member has a direct financial interest. (2008
Code § 22-5)
2-3-6: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Such commission shall have and possess the following powers, and such other
powers as may be incidental to the successful carrying out of the powers vested
in it herein or such as may be expressly conferred upon it by law:
   A.   To make such surveys, studies, maps, plans or plats of the whole or any
portion of the city and of any land outside thereof, which in the opinion of
such commission bears relation to a comprehensive plan, and shall submit such
plan to the council with its studies and recommendations and it may publish
same.
   B.   To prepare a comprehensive plan regarding the height, number of stories
and size of buildings and other structures; the percentage of ground that may
be occupied; the size of yards, courts and other open spaces; the density of
population; the location and use of buildings, structures and land for trade,
industry, residence or other purposes and to this end shall prepare a
preliminary report and hold public meetings thereon and after such meetings
have been held to submit its final report and recommendations to the city
council.
   C.   To recommend to the city council, from time to time as conditions
require, amendments, supplements, changes or modifications in the comprehensive
plan prepared by it.
   D.   To review and give its recommendation on (before approval by the city
council) all plans, plats or replats of subdivisions or resubdivisions of land
embraced in the city or adjacent thereto, laid out in lots or plats with the
streets, alleys, or other portions of the same intended to be dedicated to the
public, and all proposals for the vacation or partial vacation of a street,
alley or public ground. (2008 Code § 22-6)
2-3-7: COMMISSION MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The planning and zoning commission shall hold regular
meetings at least once each month at such time and place as it may by
resolution determine.
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held upon the call of the
chairman of the commission or upon written request signed by at least three (3)
members of the commission. At least twenty four (24) hours' notice shall be
given of any special meeting. (2008 Code § 22-7)
2-3-8: ANNUAL REPORT:
In January of each year, the planning and zoning commission shall make a report
to the mayor and council of the matters received, handled and pending and the
progress of its work for the preceding twelve (12) months. (2008 Code § 22-9)
2-3-9: DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT, STAFF ADVISOR:
   A.   The director of community development or the director's designee shall
serve as a staff advisor to the planning and zoning commission, shall assist
the commission in the performance of its duties, and advise the commission on
proposed changes in this code, and compliance by applicants with such code at
the time of commission review.
   B.   The director shall make such city facilities, records, or supplies
available as will enable the commission to perform its function. (2008 Code §
22-10)
2-3-10: COUNCIL MEMBERS ATTEND MEETINGS; ASSISTANCE BY CITY OFFICIALS:
   A.   Council Attending Meetings: The members of the council may attend the
meetings of the planning and zoning commission for the purpose of study,
consultation or discussion of any of the problems coming before the commission.
   B.   Assistance By City Officials: It shall be the duty of all officers and
employees of the city to give such aid and assistance to the commission and its
members as will enable the commission most effectively to perform its duties,
and the clerk and the heads of the departments of the city are hereby
authorized and directed to furnish to the commission, upon its request, any
records, documents, ordinances, plats, maps, charts or other information which
may be in the possession of the clerk or a department and which the commission
may need for its consideration in connection with its duties. (2008 Code § 22-
11)
2-3-11: REPORT TO COUNCIL:
The planning and zoning commission shall promptly handle any matter brought
before it, and shall report the decision rendered in any matter to the council
for such further action as the council deems appropriate. (2008 Code § 22-12)
2-3-12: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Department Created: There is hereby created a community development
department for the city. (2008 Code § 22-25; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Duties And Functions: It shall be the duty and function of the
community development department to advise, assist and consult with the city
planning and zoning commission in the exercise of its duties and powers and to
advise, assist and consult with the council in the formulation and execution of
such plans as the council or this chapter shall direct. (2008 Code § 22-26;
amd. 2015 Code)
CHAPTER 4
BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION
ARTICLE A. BOARD OF APPEALS
SECTION:
2-4A-1: Composition; Functions; Qualifications
2-4A-2: Appointment And Powers
2-4A-1: COMPOSITION; FUNCTIONS; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Board Created; Composition: In order to determine the suitability of
alternate materials and types of construction in the construction of buildings
and to provide for reasonable interpretations of the provisions of the
construction and technical codes adopted by the city, there shall be and is
hereby created a board of appeals constituted as follows:
      1.   Two (2) members shall be in the construction field or a related
field, one of which may be a bonded contractor in the city;
      2.   One member shall be associated with a fire department, or have
experience in the firefighting profession;
      3.   One member shall be associated with an architectural firm or have
experience in the architectural profession;
      4.   One member shall be a representative of the general citizenry of the
city. (2008 Code § 2-61)
   B.   Qualifications; Experienced With Adopted Codes: All members shall be
qualified and experienced and trained to pass on matters pertaining to building
construction, occupancy, abatement and fire hazards as set forth in the adopted
building code, property maintenance code, residential code and the fire code.
(2008 Code § 2-61; amd. 2015 Code)
   C.   Building Inspector: The building inspector shall act as the secretary
of the board, and he/she will also be an ex officio member except on items
related to the fire code.
   D.   Fire Code: The fire chief or chief's designee shall be an ex officio
member of the board on items relating to the fire code. (2008 Code § 2-61)
2-4A-2: APPOINTMENT AND POWERS:
   A.   Appointment; Terms: The members of the board of appeals shall be
appointed by the mayor subject to council approval and shall serve a two (2)
year term.
   B.   Powers And Authority:
      1.   The board shall have the power to decide questions of interpretation
of the various building, fire and residential codes, and the various city
departments shall be bound thereby. (2008 Code § 2-62; amd. 2015 Code)
      2.   The board may make recommendations to the council on changes to any
code within its purview. (2008 Code § 2-62)
ARTICLE B. ELECTRICAL COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-4B-1: Board Created; Function
2-4B-2: Appointment And Qualifications
2-4B-3: Term; Compensation
2-4B-4: Meetings; Quorum
2-4B-1: BOARD CREATED; FUNCTION:
There is hereby created a board known as the Electrical Commission, which shall
consist of five (5) members which shall exist for the purpose of determining
the proper installation of electrical facilities, suitability of alternate
materials, and the reasonable interpretation of the "National Electrical Code".
(Ord. 27-17, 8-1-2017)
2-4B-2: APPOINTMENT AND QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Composition And Qualifications: The commission shall be constituted as
follows:
      1.   Two (2) members shall be licensed electrical contractors, residents
of the City and shall have been engaged in the business of electrical
contracting in the City prior to their appointment on the commission.
      2.   One member shall be a journeyman electrician who has worked as a
journeyman electrician in the City for at least two (2) years prior to his
appointment to the commission.
      3.   One member shall be an electrical engineer in the employment of the
electric utility company serving the City.
      4.   One member shall be a layman.
   B.   Appointment: The members of the commission shall be appointed by the
Mayor, subject to the majority consent of the Council. (Ord. 27-17, 8-1-2017)
2-4B-3: TERM; COMPENSATION:
   A.   Term: The members of the commission shall be appointed and shall hold
office for a term of two (2) years, or until their successors are appointed and
qualified.
   B.   Compensation: The members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 27-
17, 8-1-2017)
2-4B-4: MEETINGS; QUORUM:
   A.   A majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum to transmit
business.
   B.   The commission may establish procedures, including manner of electing a
Chairperson, as are necessary to allow for orderly conduct of its meeting.
   C.   Meetings shall be called by the Chair or by any two (2) members of the
commission, in compliance with the Open Meetings Law, chapter 21 of the State
Code. (Ord. 27-17, 8-1-2017)
ARTICLE C. MECHANICAL BOARD OF APPEALS
SECTION:
2-4C-1: Board Created; Appointment; Function
2-4C-2: Composition; Qualifications
2-4C-3: Term; Compensation
2-4C-4: Removal Of Members; Grounds
2-4C-5: Quorum; Duties And Authority
2-4C-1: BOARD CREATED; APPOINTMENT; FUNCTION:
   A.   Creation; Appointment: There is hereby created a board known as the
mechanical board of appeals, which shall consist of five (5) members appointed
by the mayor, subject to the majority consent of the council. (2008 Code §§
16.5-9, 16.5-10)
   B.   Function: The board shall determine the suitability of alternate
materials and methods of construction and shall provide reasonable
interpretations of the mechanical code.
   C.   Mechanical Inspector: The mechanical inspector shall be an ex officio
member of the board and shall act as secretary to said board. (2008 Code §
16.5-9)
2-4C-2: COMPOSITION; QUALIFICATIONS:
The board shall be constituted as follows:
   A.   Two (2) members shall be heating, ventilating and air conditioning
contractors, who shall have been engaged in the contracting business within the
city prior to their appointment on the board. Preference in appointment shall
be given when possible to Bettendorf residents.
   B.   One member shall be a heating engineer in the employment of MidAmerican
Energy Company.
   C.   Two (2) members shall be either in the heating trade or a closely
allied field. (2008 Code § 16.5-11)
2-4C-3: TERM; COMPENSATION:
   A.   Term: The members of the board shall be appointed and shall hold office
for a term of two (2) years, or until their successors are appointed and
qualified. (2008 Code § 16.5-12; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Compensation: Members shall serve without compensation. (2008 Code §
16.5-12)
2-4C-4: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS; GROUNDS:
The mayor may, subject to the majority consent of the council, remove any
member of the board for incompetency or improper conduct. (2008 Code § 16.5-13)
2-4C-5: QUORUM; DUTIES AND AUTHORITY:
   A.   Quorum: A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum to transact
business.
   B.   Duties And Authority: The board shall:
      1.   Adopt written rules for the conduct of business;
      2.   Have the power to change and amend the rules; and
      3.   Recommend to the city council reasonable fees to be paid for the
inspection of mechanical equipment installed or altered in the city. (2008 Code
§ 16.5-14)
ARTICLE D. PLUMBING BOARD
SECTION:
2-4D-1: Appointment; Qualifications
2-4D-2: Term
2-4D-3: Quorum
2-4D-4: Powers And Duties
2-4D-1: APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Board Established; Appointment: There is hereby established a plumbing
board, which shall consist of five (5) members, appointed by the mayor with
approval by the council.
   B.   Qualifications:
      1.   Two (2) of the members shall be licensed as plumbing contractors by
the city;
      2.   One member shall be either an architect or engineer; and
      3.   The balance of the members shall not be required to hold any special
license or have experience unique to the plumbing trade. (2008 Code § 23-8)
2-4D-2: TERM:
The term of office shall be a two (2) year term commencing April 1 of each
year. Once appointed, a member may hold over until a successor is appointed and
qualified. (2008 Code § 23-9)
2-4D-3: QUORUM:
A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of the
business of the board. A majority of those present shall be necessary for
approval of any matter under consideration by the board. (2008 Code § 23-10)
2-4D-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Function And Duties:
      1.   The board shall determine the suitability of alternate materials and
methods of construction and shall provide reasonable interpretations of the
plumbing code.
      2.   The board shall, upon application of any party, resolve questions of
interpretation of either title 10, chapter 6 of this code, or any uniform
plumbing code adopted by the city.
      3.   The board may adopt such rules as will implement any of these powers
or duties.
   B.   Plumbing Inspector: The plumbing inspector shall be an ex officio
member of the board and shall act as secretary to said board. (2008 Code § 23-
11)
CHAPTER 5
HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-5-1: Appointment; Composition; Terms
2-5-2: Compensation; Expenditures; Limitations
2-5-3: Election Of Officers; Terms
2-5-4: Powers And Duties Generally
2-5-5: Meetings; Rules; Quorum
2-5-6: Open Meetings And Records; Exceptions
2-5-7: Appoint And Prescribe Duties Of Staff
2-5-8: Cooperation With Other Agencies
2-5-1: APPOINTMENT; COMPOSITION; TERMS:
   A.   Appointment; Composition:
      1.   There is hereby created a human rights commission, which shall
consist of seven (7) members, appointed by the mayor, with the advice and
consent of the council.
      2.   Appointments shall take into consideration the various racial,
religious, cultural and social groups in the city.
   B.   Terms: Two (2) of the initial appointees shall serve until January 1,
2005, three (3) shall serve until January 1, 2006, and two (2) shall serve
until January 1, 2007. Subsequent appointees shall serve for a term of three
(3) years and thereafter or until a successor has been appointed.
   C.   Vacancies: Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired
term. (2008 Code § 8-12)
2-5-2: COMPENSATION; EXPENDITURES; LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Compensation; Expenses: The members of the commission shall serve
without compensation; provided, that they may receive actual and necessary
expenses incurred, within the limits established in the city budget.
   B.   Expenditures; Limitations: The council shall provide the commission
with funds to enforce this chapter and title 5, chapter 3 of this code. The
commission is not authorized to spend any funds in excess of the funds provided
by the council. (2008 Code § 8-13)
2-5-3: ELECTION OF OFFICERS; TERMS:
   A.   Officers:
      1.   The commission shall elect from its membership at its regular
January meeting, its chair and vice chair, each to serve for a term of one
year. It may elect such other officers as it deems necessary or appropriate.
      2.   Immediately upon its creation, the commission shall meet and elect
