its officers to serve until the following January meeting.
   B.   Vacancies: The commission shall fill vacancies among its officers for
the remainder of the unexpired term. (2008 Code § 8-14)
2-5-4: POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY:
The commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To receive, investigate, mediate and determine the merits of charges or
complaints alleging unfair or discriminatory practices, as provided in this
chapter and title 5, chapter 3 of this code.
   B.   To investigate and study the existence, character, causes and extent of
discrimination in public accommodations, employment, apprenticeship programs,
on the job training programs, vocational schools, credit practices, and housing
in the city and to attempt the elimination of such discrimination by education
and conciliation. (2008 Code § 8-15)
   C.   To issue such publications and reports of investigations and research
as, in the judgment of the commission, shall tend to promote goodwill among the
various racial, religious, and ethnic groups of the city and which shall tend
to minimize or eliminate discrimination in public accommodations, employment,
apprenticeship and on the job training programs, vocational schools, or housing
because of race, creed, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity,
national origin, religion, ancestry, or disability. (2008 Code § 8-15; amd.
2015 Code)
   D.   To prepare and transmit to the mayor and the council from time to time,
but not less often than once each year, reports describing its proceedings,
investigations, hearings conducted and the outcome thereof, decisions rendered,
and the other work performed by the commission.
   E.   To make recommendations to the mayor and the council for such further
legislation concerning discrimination as it may deem necessary and desirable.
   F.   To cooperate, within the limits of any appropriations made for its
operation, with other agencies or organizations, both public and private, whose
purposes are consistent with those of this chapter and title 5, chapter 3 of
this code, and in the planning and conducting of programs designed to eliminate
racial, religious, cultural and intergroup tensions.
   G.   To adopt, publish, amend, and rescind regulations consistent with and
necessary for the enforcement of this chapter and title 5, chapter 3 of this
code.
   H.   To receive, administer, dispense and account for any funds that may be
voluntarily contributed to the commission and any grants that may be awarded
the commission for furthering the purposes of this chapter and title 5, chapter
3 of this code.
   I.   To defer a complaint to any other civil rights commission asserting
jurisdiction or already processing the complaint, to refer to the state any
complaint in which the city, its employees or agents are a respondent, or any
other referral as may be agreed upon by the complainant and respondent.
   J.   To issue subpoenas and order discovery as provided by this section in
aid of investigations and hearings of alleged discrimination. The subpoenas and
discovery may be ordered to the same extent and are subject to the same
limitations as subpoenas and discovery in a civil action in district court.
   K.   To defer proceedings and refer a complaint to a local commission that
has been recognized by the United States department of housing and urban
development as having adopted ordinances providing fair housing rights and
remedies that are substantially equivalent to those granted under federal law.
   L.   To utilize volunteers to aid in the conduct of the commission's
business including case processing functions such as intake, screening,
investigation, and mediation. (2008 Code § 8-15)
2-5-5: MEETINGS; RULES; QUORUM:
   A.   Regular Meetings, Time And Place: The commission shall meet at six
o'clock (6:00) P.M. on the first Wednesday of each month, or as needed, in the
council chambers at city hall.
   B.   Special Meetings: The chair, the vice chair, or any three (3) members
of the commission may call a special meeting by giving at least one full day's
notice to every member of the commission. The call for a special meeting shall
include an agenda, and only matters included in that agenda may be discussed at
the meeting.
   C.   Quorum: A quorum of the commission shall be four (4) members. A
majority of the members present and voting shall be necessary for the passage
of any motion; the chair shall vote as a member of the commission.
   D.   Rules: The commission may adopt, amend, or rescind such rules as may be
necessary for the conduct of its business. (2008 Code § 8-16)
2-5-6: OPEN MEETINGS AND RECORDS; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Public Meetings; Exceptions: All meetings of the commission shall be
public meetings, except:
      1.   The commission may, when necessary to prevent irreparable and
needless injury to the reputation of an individual whose employment or
discharge is under consideration, hold a closed session by affirmative vote of
two-thirds (2/3) of its members; the votes on such a motion are to be recorded
in the minutes by yeas and nays. No action may be taken in executive session;
however, upon the conclusion of an executive session, the commission may
reenter open session and decide any matter by motion recorded in the minutes of
the open session.
      2.   The commission shall hold a closed session for consideration of any
charge or complaint, as provided in this chapter and title 5, chapter 3 of this
code and for deliberations in connection with a public hearing held pursuant to
a complaint filed with the commission.
   B.   Public Records; Exceptions: All records of the commission shall be
public, except:
      1.   Charges, complaints, reports of investigations, statements and other
documents or records obtained in an investigation of any charges shall be
closed records unless they are used in public session or district court action
as provided in this chapter and title 5, chapter 3 of this code.
      2.   The minutes of any session which is closed under the provisions of
subsection A2 of this section shall be closed records.
   C.   Confidential Information: No member of the commission or of its staff
shall disclose the filing of a charge, the information gathered during the
investigation, or the endeavors to eliminate a discriminatory or unfair
practice by conference, conciliation, or persuasion, unless the disclosure is
made in connection with the conduct of the investigation or after the
commission has held a public hearing upon a complaint filed in connection with
the charge. This section does not prevent any complainant, witness or other
person from publicizing the filing of a charge or complaint or of the matter
therein complained, or the release of information to state or federal agencies
investigating the same or similar complaints. (2008 Code § 8-17)
2-5-7: APPOINT AND PRESCRIBE DUTIES OF STAFF:
Consistent with budgeting authority granted by the city council, the commission
may appoint and prescribe the duties of its director and other members of its
staff. (2008 Code § 8-18)
2-5-8: COOPERATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES:
The commission shall cooperate with the state civil rights commission, the
United States civil rights commission, the federal equal employment opportunity
commission and other agencies with similar purposes. (2008 Code § 8-19)
CHAPTER 6
FAMILY MUSEUM OF ARTS AND SCIENCES BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2-6-1: Museum Established; Purpose
2-6-2: Director Of Museum
2-6-3: Board Of Trustees; Appointment; Qualifications
2-6-4: Terms
2-6-5: Compensation
2-6-6: Duties And Responsibilities
2-6-7: Expenditure Of Funds
2-6-1: MUSEUM ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE:
There is hereby established the "Family Museum Of Arts And Sciences At The
Learning Campus" composed of the former Children's Museum And Center For The
Cultural Arts, whose purpose shall be to provide for the cultural enrichment of
the city and quad city community through the establishment of a children's
museum and teaching the performing arts, visual arts and sciences. (2008 Code §
15-1)
2-6-2: DIRECTOR OF MUSEUM:
The director of the Family Museum of Arts and Sciences at the Learning Campus
shall be appointed by the city administrator. The director shall seek guidance
from the board on those matters entrusted to it under section
2-6-6 of this chapter, but shall report to and be subject to the city
administrator in all other matters. The role of the director of the Family
Museum of Arts and Sciences at the Learning Campus may be assumed by the
director of Culture and Recreation, a position combining the director of the
Family Museum of Arts and Sciences at the Learning Campus and the director of
parks and recreation, as the city administrator may decide, in consultation
with the city council. References in the City Code to the director of the
Family Museum of Arts and Sciences at the Learning Campus shall operate to
pertain to the director of Culture and Recreation in those circumstances that a
director of Culture and Recreation is in place. (2008 Code § 15-7; amd. Ord.
17-21, 10-19-2021)
2-6-3: BOARD OF TRUSTEES; APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Composition; Qualifications: The board of trustees for the museum shall
consist of no more than eleven (11) members, six (6) of whom shall be residents
of the city. All members of the board shall be at least eighteen (18) years of
age.
   B.   Appointment: The board shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of
the council. One council member appointed by the mayor may serve as ex officio
member of the board. (2008 Code § 15-2)
2-6-4: TERMS:
   A.   Appointment; Vacancy: Appointments shall be for a three (3) year period
commencing July 1. Appointments shall be made, as near as possible, to stagger
the terms. Appointments made to fill a vacancy shall be for the balance of the
term.
   B.   Resignation: A board member shall be deemed to resign the appointment
upon any of the following:
      1.   Moving personal residence outside of Bettendorf when appointed to a
Bettendorf resident position.
      2.   Four (4) consecutive absences from regular board meetings, unless
excused by illness or temporary absence from the city. A board member who has
missed four (4) regular meetings may make a request to the board to remain a
member. Upon approval by two-thirds (2/3) majority of the full board, the
absences will be excused and the member allowed to continue. (2008 Code § 15-3)
2-6-5: COMPENSATION:
No member of the board shall receive any compensation for service thereon.
(2008 Code § 15-4)
2-6-6: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The board shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
   A.   To meet and organize the selection of one of their members to serve as
president and such other officers as the board shall deem appropriate.
   B.   To establish its rules of procedure, time and place of meeting, and
votes required, so long as such rules do not violate the municipal or state
code requirements.
   C.   To establish policies concerning hours of operation, classes provided,
and exhibits presented consistent with budgeted amounts.
   D.   To work with and support the department and other city officials in the
promotion of the museum and learning campus.
   E.   To accept on behalf of the city gifts or items deemed appropriate for
use by the museum, funds given to the department, establish long range
strategic directives for the facility and work toward their achievement.
   F.   To recommend to the mayor the appointment of persons to serve on the
board.
   G.   To establish such committees or task forces as will assist the board in
implementing the above duties. (2008 Code § 15-5)
2-6-7: EXPENDITURE OF FUNDS:
No funds shall be expended by the department except in conformance with council
policies and as are allocated in the department budget. (2008 Code § 15-6)
CHAPTER 7
LIBRARY BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2-7-1: Library Established
2-7-2: Board Established; Qualifications
2-7-3: Terms Of Office; Resignation
2-7-4: Powers And Duties
2-7-5: Contracts
2-7-6: Authorizing Nonresident Use Of Library
2-7-7: Library Account
2-7-8: Annual Report
2-7-9: Unauthorized Retention Of Library Materials; Enforcement
2-7-1: LIBRARY ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the Bettendorf Public Library for the use of the
residents of the city and existing under the rules and regulations promulgated
by the library board of trustees. (2008 Code § 2-64)
2-7-2: BOARD ESTABLISHED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby established a library board of trustees consisting of seven (7)
persons who must be and remain residents of the city and who have attained the
age of eighteen (18) years. (2008 Code § 2-65)
2-7-3: TERMS OF OFFICE; RESIGNATION:
   A.   Terms: All appointments to the board shall be for a term of six (6)
years commencing July 1. (2008 Code § 2-66; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Resignation: A board member shall be deemed to have resigned if the
member moves from the city or is absent from four (4) regularly scheduled
meetings of the board during a fiscal year. The library board may grant one
exception by two- thirds (2/3) vote of the entire board. (2008 Code § 2-66)
2-7-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board shall have and exercise the following powers and duties:
   A.   To meet and elect from its members a president, a secretary and such
other officers as it deems necessary. The city treasurer shall serve as board
treasurer but shall not be a member of the board.
   B.   To have charge, control and supervision of the public library, its
appurtenances, fixtures and rooms containing the same.
   C.   To direct and control all the affairs of the library.
   D.   To employ a library director and authorize the library director to
employ employees as may be necessary for the proper management of the library
and fix their compensation; provided, however, that prior to such employment,
the compensation of the library director and employees shall have been fixed
and approved by a majority of the members of the board voting in favor thereof.
(2008 Code § 2-67)
   E.   To remove by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the board the library director
and provide procedures for the removal of employees for misdemeanor,
incompetency or inattention to duty subject, however, to the provisions of Iowa
Code chapter 66. (2008 Code § 2-67; amd. 2015 Code)
   F.   To select or authorize the library director to select and make
purchases of books, pamphlets, magazines, periodicals, papers, maps, journals,
other library materials, furniture, fixtures, stationery and supplies for the
library within budgetary limits set by the board.
   G.   To authorize the use of the library by nonresidents of the city and to
fix charges therefor.
   H.   To make and adopt, amend, modify or repeal rules and regulations not
inconsistent with ordinances and the law for the care, use, government and
management of the library and the business of the board, fixing and enforcing
penalties for violations.
   I.   To have exclusive control of the expenditure of all funds allocated for
library purposes by the council and of all monies available by gift or
otherwise for the erection of library buildings and of all other monies
belonging to the library including fines and rentals collected under the rules
of the board.
   J.   To accept gifts of real property, personal property or mixed property
and devises and bequests, including trust funds; to take the title to said
property in the name of the library; to execute deeds and bills of sale for the
conveyance of said property and to expend the funds received by them from such
gifts for the improvement of the library.
   K.   To keep a record of its proceedings.
   L.   To enforce the performance of conditions on gifts, donations, devises
and bequests accepted by the city by action against the city council.
   M.   To have authority to make agreements with local county historical
associations where such exists and to set apart the necessary room and to care
for such articles as may come into the possession of the association. The
trustees are further authorized to purchase necessary receptacles and materials
for the preservation and protection of such articles as are in their judgment
of a historical and educational nature and pay for the same out of funds
allocated for library purposes.
   N.   To lease a portion of the library for the operation of a coffee shop
upon such terms and conditions as the board shall deem appropriate, provided no
such lease may extend beyond three (3) years without public hearing and council
approval as provided by law. (2008 Code § 2-67)
2-7-5: CONTRACTS:
   A.   Generally: The board may contract with any other boards of trustees of
free public libraries and other city, school, corporation, private or
semiprivate organization, institution of higher learning, township or county or
with the trustees of any county library district for the use of the library by
their respective residents.
   B.   Termination: Such a contract may be terminated at any time by mutual
consent of the contracting parties. It also may be terminated by a majority
vote of the electors represented by either of the contracting parties. Such a
termination proposition shall be submitted to the electors by the governing
body of a contracting party on a written petition of not less than five percent
(5%) in number of the electors who voted for governor in the territory of the
party at the last general election. The petition must be presented to the
governing body not less than forty (40) days before the election. The
proposition may be submitted at any election provided by law that is held in
the territory of the party who is seeking to terminate the contract. (2008 Code
§ 2-68)
2-7-6: AUTHORIZING NONRESIDENT USE OF LIBRARY:
The board may authorize the use of the library by nonresidents in any one or
more of the following ways by:
   A.   Lending the books or other materials of the library to nonresidents on
the same terms and conditions as to residents of the city or upon payment of a
special nonresident library fee.
   B.   Establishing depositories of library books or other materials to be
loaned to nonresidents.
   C.   Establishing bookmobiles or a traveling library so that other library
materials may be loaned to nonresidents.
   D.   Establishing branch libraries for lending books or other library
materials to nonresidents. (2008 Code § 2-69)
2-7-7: LIBRARY ACCOUNT:
All monies appropriated by the council from the general fund for the operation
and maintenance of the library shall be set aside in an account for the
library. Expenditures shall be paid for only on orders of the board signed by
its president and secretary. The authorized official to sign purchase orders is
the library director. (2008 Code § 2-70)
2-7-8: ANNUAL REPORT:
The board shall make a report to the city council immediately after the close
of the municipal fiscal year. This report shall contain statements of the
condition of the library, the number of books added thereto, the number
circulated, the amount of fines collected and the amount of money expended in
the maintenance of the library during the year together with such further
information required by the council. (2008 Code § 2-71)
2-7-9: UNAUTHORIZED RETENTION OF LIBRARY MATERIALS; ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Library Materials Defined: "Library materials" shall be defined as any
material offered by the library for the use of the public off the premises of
the library.
   B.   Prohibited Act: Any person who removes or retains library materials
beyond the date of required return shall be guilty of unauthorized retention of
library materials and may be prosecuted by municipal infraction.
   C.   Enforcement: The library director or the director's designee shall be
charged with the enforcement of this section. (2008 Code § 2-72)
CHAPTER 8
PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
SECTION:
2-8-1: Advisory Board Created; Function
2-8-2: Appointments; Qualifications
2-8-3: Duties And Responsibilities
2-8-4: Compensation
2-8-5: Director Of Parks And Recreation
2-8-6: Supervision Of City Employees
2-8-1: ADVISORY BOARD CREATED; FUNCTION:
A parks and recreation board is hereby created to advise the council and
director of parks and recreation on the needed facilities to provide open space
such as parks, playgrounds, and community facilities, or other forms of
recreation. It shall also advise the council and director of parks and
recreation of city programs and encourage other programs, for the leisure time
of the city's residents of all ages. The parks and recreation board shall meet
on no less than a quarterly basis. (Ord. 04-21, 3-16-2021)
2-8-2: APPOINTMENTS; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Terms: The board shall consist of no more than ten (10) board members,
all at least eighteen (18) years old and citizens of the city, whose terms of
office shall be three (3) years in duration commencing July 1. Appointments
shall be made, as near as possible, to stagger the terms. Appointments made to
fill a vacancy shall be for the balance of the term. Appointments made upon the
commencement of board may be made for shorter terms and on such commencement
date as the mayor determines.
   B.   Appointment: The board shall be appointed by the mayor, with
ratification by council. (Ord. 04-21, 3-16-2021)
2-8-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
In furtherance of the purpose set forth in City Code §
2-8-1, the board shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
   A.   To meet and organize the selection of one of their members to serve as
president and such other officers as the board shall deem appropriate.
   B.   To establish its rules of procedure, time and place of meeting, and
votes required, so long as such rules do not violate municipal or state code
requirements.
   C.   To establish policies concerning hours of operation and classes
provided, presented consistent with budgeted amounts, and to establish such
other policies and make such recommendations to the council and the director of
parks and recreation as appropriate to fulfill the purpose of City Code §
2-8-1.
   D.   To work with and support the department and other city officials in the
promotion of parks and recreation.
   E.   To accept on behalf of the city gifts or items deemed appropriate for
use by parks and recreation, funds given to the department, establish long
range strategic directives for the department and work toward their
achievement.
   F.   To recommend to the mayor the appointment of persons to serve on the
board.
   G.   To establish such committees or task forces as will assist the board in
implementing the above duties. (Ord. 04-21, 3-16-2021)
2-8-4: COMPENSATION:
Members of the board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 04-21, 3-16-2021)
2-8-5: DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION:
The director of parks and recreation shall serve as the department head for the
parks and recreation department. (Ord. 04-21, 3-16-2021)
2-8-6: SUPERVISION OF CITY EMPLOYEES:
The director of parks and recreation shall serve as the department head for the
parks and recreation department. Day to day supervision of parks and recreation
employees shall be by the director of parks and recreation, who shall report to
and be subject to the city administrator. All matters regarding hiring,
discipline, and discharge of parks and recreation employees shall be handled by
the city administrator in concert with the director of parks and recreation
and, as appropriate, the city attorney. The role of the director of parks and
recreation may be assumed by the director of Culture and Recreation, a position
combining the director of the Family Museum of Arts and Sciences at the
Learning Campus and the director of parks and recreation, as the city
administrator may decide, in consultation with the city council. References in
the City Code to the director of parks and recreation shall operate to pertain
to the director of Culture and Recreation in those circumstances that a
director of Culture and Recreation is in place. (Ord. 17-21, 10-19-2021)
CHAPTER 9
TREE COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-9-1: Committee Created; Term
2-9-2: Duties
2-9-3: Finances; Compensation
2-9-1: COMMITTEE CREATED; TERM:
There is hereby created a tree committee, consisting of five (5) members
appointed by the mayor, who shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. (2008
Code § 2-81; amd. 2015 Code; Ord. 05-21, 3-16-2021)
2-9-2: DUTIES:
   A.   The committee shall:
      1.   Study, investigate and develop a plan for the care, preservation,
trimming, planting, removal or disposition of trees in public areas.
      2.   Strive to promote and educate the residents of the city on the value
and care of public trees.
      3.   Respond to any questions posed of it by the city council within the
scope of its work.
   B.   The committee may:
      1.   Recommend to the city council the implementation of the plan
described herein.
      2.   Pursue grants or other sources of funding to enhance tree planting
and maintenance within the public way. (2008 Code § 2-81; amd. 2015 Code; Ord.
05-21, 3-16-2021)
2-9-3: FINANCES; COMPENSATION:
No budget allocation shall be made for the committee; no compensation shall be
paid any committee member for service thereon. No grants received by the
committee may be expended except upon approval of the city council. (2008 Code
§ 2-81; amd. 2015 Code; Ord. 05-21, 3-16-2021)
CHAPTER 10
URBAN DEER HUNTING ADVISORY COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-10-1: Membership; Terms; Qualifications
2-10-2: Duties
2-10-1: MEMBERSHIP; TERMS; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Committee Created; Compensation: There is hereby established a
Bettendorf urban deer hunting advisory committee composed of eleven (11)
members who shall serve without compensation.
   B.   Terms: The members of the committee shall serve for a three (3) year
term. For purposes of staggering terms under this chapter, upon initial
appointment, three (3) members shall serve for one year, four (4) members shall
serve for two (2) years, and four (4) members shall serve for three (3) years.
   C.   Appointment; Qualifications: Members shall be appointed by the mayor
and approved by the council. Members should have background or experience in
urban deer hunting and/or have an interest in working with the mayor and city
council and police department in reviewing the city urban deer hunting policies
to make them as safe and efficient as possible. (2008 Code § 2-84)
2-10-2: DUTIES:
Members shall:
   A.   Assist in gathering urban deer hunting policies from other municipal
jurisdictions.
   B.   Evaluate current ordinances and make recommendations to the mayor and
city council concerning urban deer hunting in the city.
   C.   Perform such other duties as the mayor and city council shall direct as
it relates to urban deer hunting within the city. (2008 Code § 2-84)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUSINESS LICENSES GENERALLY
SECTION:
3-1-1: Licensing Requirements; Fees
3-1-2: Application For License; Payment Of Fee
3-1-3: Required Signatures
3-1-4: Display Of License
3-1-5: Bonds Or Insurance In Conjunction With License
3-1-6: Inspection
3-1-7: Denial, Suspension Or Revocation Of License
3-1-1: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
   A.   Generally: Businesses regulated by this title shall be required to be
licensed prior to operation. All licensed businesses shall be required to
follow the mandates of this code. (2008 Code § 16-1)
   B.   License Required For Sales Of Goods, Wares Or Merchandise; Fees:
      1.   Unless otherwise regulated by the state or municipal code, all
retail and wholesale businesses within the city which sell goods, wares, or
merchandise shall obtain a license therefor. No business shall be required to
obtain both a retail business and transient merchant license.
      2.   The fee for such license shall be:
         a.   Seventy five dollars ($75.00) for businesses occupying up to four
thousand (4,000) square feet of space.
         b.   One hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) for businesses
occupying four thousand one (4,001) to nine thousand (9,000) square feet of
space.
         c.   One hundred seventy five dollars ($175.00) for businesses
occupying nine thousand one (9,001) to fourteen thousand (14,000) square feet
of space. (2008 Code § 16-3)
         d.   Two hundred twenty five dollars ($225.00) for businesses
occupying fourteen thousand one (14,001) square feet or more of space. (2008
Code § 16-3; amd. 2015 Code)
   C.   Term Of License:
      1.   Unless otherwise stated on the license, a license shall be issued
effective on the date of issuance through June 30. License renewals shall be
effective from July 1 through June 30. (2008 Code § 16-2)
      2.   New licenses issued on dates other than July 1 shall be prorated.
(2008 Code § 16-2; amd. 2015 Code)
   D.   License Nontransferable: No license shall be transferred to any other
business or individual. (2008 Code § 16-13)
   E.   Additional License For Entertainment Machines: Any business operating
or allowing to be operated within its premises any of the following: electronic
video games, electronic pinball machines, pinball machines, pool tables,
jukeboxes, or other similar devices, shall obtain an additional license for
each such machine, and the cost of such license shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00) for each machine. The license shall run concurrent with the business
license. (2008 Code § 16-4; amd. 2015 Code)
3-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; PAYMENT OF FEE:
   A.   Application: All requests for licenses shall be on the form as
established by the city clerk. Copies of the application form shall be
available at the office of the city clerk and the office of the code
enforcement officer at the city hall annex. Applications shall be received at
the office of the code enforcement officer only. (2008 Code § 16-9)
   B.   Payment Of Fee: The required license fee shall be paid at the time of
application. (2008 Code § 16-10)
3-1-3: REQUIRED SIGNATURES:
Whenever approval of a specific city employee or state official is required
prior to issuance of a license, the applicant shall secure such approval prior
to filing the application. (2008 Code § 16-11)
3-1-4: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
   A.   Displayed Or Carried: Upon issuance, the city license shall be
displayed at a conspicuous location within the business licensed. If the
license is to an individual for regulated conduct, such license shall be
carried with the person at all times when the regulated conduct is being
performed.
   B.   Display To Police Or City Official Upon Request: The license shall be
displayed to any police officer or code enforcement officer upon request. (2008
Code § 16-12)
3-1-5: BONDS OR INSURANCE IN CONJUNCTION WITH LICENSE:
Whenever a bond or insurance is required in conjunction with a license, such
bond or insurance shall be issued by an entity licensed to do business within
the state of Iowa, and shall be on a form as provided with the application, and
attached to the application at the time of filing. (2008 Code § 16-14)
3-1-6: INSPECTION:
The code enforcement officer shall be granted entry to any premises licensed or
regulated under this title to inspect to verify compliance with this code.
(2008 Code § 16-16)
3-1-7: DENIAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Reasons For Denial, Suspension Or Revocation: A license may be denied,
suspended, or revoked by the issuing authority for any of the following
reasons:
      1.   Failure to qualify for the license.
      2.   Failure to continuously comply with all the conditions required as a
precedent for approval of the license.
      3.   Fraud, misrepresentation or incorrect statement contained in the
application.
      4.   Expiration or cancellation of any bond or insurance required.
      5.   Refusal to comply with requests by the code enforcement officer to
inspect the licensed premises.
      6.   Conducting actions beyond that authorized by the granting of the
license.
      7.   Violation of any regulation or provision of this code applicable to
the activity for which the license has been granted.
      8.   Conducting the licensed activity in a manner which constitutes a
danger or harm to the health, safety or welfare of the public, or constitutes a
breach of the peace.
   B.   Right Of Appeal: Any person aggrieved by the action of the issuing
authority in denying, suspending, or revoking a license shall have the
following rights of appeal:
      1.   Within five (5) days, the person aggrieved may file a written appeal
to the city administrator. The city administrator shall, within five (5) days,
schedule a hearing, take whatever evidence or information is presented, and
shall, within two (2) days thereafter, decide to affirm or reverse the decision
of the issuing authority. If the decision is to reverse, the administrator
shall have full power to increase, modify, or revoke the sanction.
      2.   If the person is still aggrieved, further appeal shall be requested
in writing within five (5) days. Such appeal shall be heard by the city council
at its next regularly scheduled meeting. Upon hearing such evidence or
information as shall be produced, the council shall decide whether to affirm,
modify, or reverse the decision of the administrator. No further appeal shall
be granted. (2008 Code § 16-15)
CHAPTER 2
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
3-2-1: Amusement Parks
3-2-2: Carnivals And Circuses
3-2-3: Inspection
3-2-4: Revocation Of License
3-2-1: AMUSEMENT PARKS:
No person shall operate an amusement park within the city without first
obtaining a license therefor. The fee for such park shall be two hundred
dollars ($200.00) per year, valid from July 1 to June 30. (2008 Code § 3-1)
3-2-2: CARNIVALS AND CIRCUSES:
   A.   Carnivals: No person shall operate a carnival within the city without
first obtaining a license therefor. The fee for such carnival shall be two
hundred dollars ($200.00) per year, valid from July 1 to June 30, or fifty
dollars ($50.00) per calendar week, whichever the applicant chooses. (2008 Code
§ 3-2)
   B.   Circuses: No person shall operate a circus within the city without
first obtaining a license therefor. The fee for such circus shall be two
hundred dollars ($200.00) per year, valid from July 1 to June 30, or fifty
dollars ($50.00) per calendar week, whichever the applicant chooses. (2008 Code
§ 3-3)
3-2-3: INSPECTION:
By applying for and receiving a license under this chapter, the operator of an
amusement park, carnival or circus agrees to follow all fire, building, zoning,
sanitation and health codes applicable within the city and to permit inspection
of the amusement by the police or building inspectors to verify compliance.
(2008 Code § 3-4)
3-2-4: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
When, in the opinion of the appropriate code enforcement official, the
operation of the amusement constitutes an immediate threat to any individual's
health or safety, the license of the amusement shall be revoked, and the
amusement shall cease to operate. The decision of the official may be appealed
to the city council, which may affirm, rescind, or modify that decision. (2008
Code § 3-5)
CHAPTER 3
HOTELS, MOTELS AND BED AND BREAKFASTS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Definitions
3-3-2: License Required; Fee
3-3-3: Hotel/Motel Tax
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Hotels, motels, boarding houses, and bed and breakfast inns shall be as defined
in section
11-1-6 of this code. (2008 Code § 16-41)
3-3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
The fee for a license required by this chapter shall be as follows:
   A.   Rental of one to ten (10) rooms per facility: Fifty dollars ($50.00)
per year.
   B.   Rental of eleven (11) to fifty (50) rooms per facility: One hundred
dollars ($100.00) per year.
   C.   Rental of fifty one (51) to one hundred (100) rooms per facility: One
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year.
   D.   Rental of more than one hundred (100) rooms per facility: Two hundred
dollars ($200.00) per year. (2008 Code § 16-42)
3-3-3: HOTEL/MOTEL TAX:
   A.   The hotel/motel tax, authorized by Iowa Code chapter 423A, and as
approved by the voters on November, 1991, is established at seven percent (7%)
of the gross receipts from the rental of sleeping quarters in a hotel, motel,
inn, public lodging houses, rooming house, mobile home, tourist court, or in
any place where sleeping accommodations are furnished to transient guests for
rent. (2008 Code § 16-43; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Such tax shall become effective January 1, 1992, and shall not be
changed without an election and majority vote in favor thereof.
   C.   The tax shall not be collected on rentals of rooms when such rental is
to the same person for a period of thirty (30) or more consecutive days.
   D.   The tax shall be collected in the manner required by law. (2008 Code §
16-43)
CHAPTER 4
SOLICITORS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Definitions
3-4-2: License Required
3-4-3: Display Of License
3-4-4: Sales Regulations
3-4-5: Fixed Location Transient Merchants
3-4-6: Application For License
3-4-7: Issuance Of License
3-4-8: Fees
3-4-9: Bond Required
3-4-10: Duplicate Licenses
3-4-11: Charitable And Nonprofit Organizations
3-4-12: Blanket Licenses
3-4-13: Activities Not Subject To Transient Merchant Licensing
3-4-14: Door To Door Solicitors
3-4-15: Denial Or Revocation Of License; Procedure
3-4-16: Penalty
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation of this chapter:
CITY: The city of Bettendorf, Iowa.
PERSON: An individual person, firm, corporation, partnership or association.
RESIDENCE: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one
or more persons contained within any type of building or structure.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT:
   A.   Any person intending to remain in business in the city for less than
one year who:
      1.   Offers for sale tangible personal property or personal services; or
      2.   Takes or attempts to take orders for the sale of tangible personal
property and services, including advertising or subscriptions, to be furnished
or performed in the future.
   B.   A transient merchant may operate from a fixed location, or may simply
go door to door. (2008 Code § 21-2)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a transient
merchant in the city without first obtaining a license as herein provided. Each
employee, agent or subcontractor of a transient merchant shall be licensed.
(2008 Code § 21-3)
3-4-3: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Each transient merchant shall at all times while doing business in the city
keep in the possession of such person the license required by this chapter and
shall, upon request, display the license as evidence of compliance with the
requirements of this chapter. (2008 Code § 21-4)
3-4-4: SALES REGULATIONS:
   A.   Use Of Public Property; Special Authorization: No person shall engage
in activities regulated under this chapter on public property without first
procuring special authorization from the city council.
   B.   Sound Devices: No person shall shout or use any sound device upon any
of the public places of the city or upon any private premises in said city
where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom violates any
noise ordinance of the city.
   C.   Defiance Of Notice Indicating Peddlers Or Solicitors Not Welcome: No
person shall engage in business as a transient merchant in defiance of any
notice exhibited at a residence or business indicating that peddlers or
solicitors are not welcome or not invited.
   D.   Hours Restricted: No person shall engage in the activities regulated
under this chapter from door to door prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after
nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. Monday through Saturday, at any time on a Sunday, or
on a state or national holiday.
   E.   Intimidation Or Coercion: No person shall continue to remain on
another's private property in an attempt to intimidate or coerce a sale after
being told that the seller's merchandise was not wanted or after being told to
leave. (2008 Code § 21-5)
3-4-5: FIXED LOCATION TRANSIENT MERCHANTS:
   A.   Written Permission Required: No transient merchant shall engage in
business at a fixed location without the written permission, by lease or
otherwise, of the owner or person in control of the property. This written
agreement shall be signed by the parties and shall include the dates the
transient shall be conducting business. This agreement shall be displayed by
the transient merchant at such fixed location when he is doing business there.
   B.   Off Street Parking: A transient merchant doing business at a fixed
location shall provide sufficient off street parking spaces for all employees
and customers.
   C.   Display Of Personal Property; Signs: Any display of tangible personal
property, or signs or advertisements therefor, shall comply with the
appropriate sections of this code.
   D.   Bathroom Facilities: The owner or person in control of the property
shall furnish bathroom facilities for the use of the transient merchant. (2008
Code § 21-6)
3-4-6: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a transient merchant license shall give the following
information:
   A.   The name of the person having the management or supervision of
applicant's business during the time that it is proposed it will be carried on
in the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business.
   B.   The permanent address of each person working for the merchant; whether
such person will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee, the name and
address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will
be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the
same is incorporated.
   C.   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
said business shall be conducted.
   D.   The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant, where applicant within three (3) years next preceding the date of
said application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and
giving the post office box number and street address of any building or office
in which said business was conducted.
   E.   A statement of the nature and character of the tangible personal
property or service to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the
city; whether the goods are new, damaged or rejects; whether the same are
proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample, or at auction or by
direct sale or by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or
property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods
or products are located at the time said application is filed.
   F.   Whether or not any person having management or supervision of the
applicant's business has been convicted of a felony within the five (5) years
immediately preceding the date of said application or of the violation of any
law or ordinance relating to the same or similar business to be conducted by
the applicant, the nature of such offense and the punishment therefor.
   G.   Whether the applicant has ever applied for a license under this
chapter, which has been denied.
   H.   Whether the applicant has ever held a license under this chapter, which
has been revoked.
   I.   A copy of the acknowledgment from the Iowa secretary of state regarding
the bond required in section
3-4-9 of this chapter. (2008 Code § 21-7)
3-4-7: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
   A.   The police department or the city clerk's office shall accept the
application. The police department shall investigate whether the information is
complete and accurate.
   B.   Licenses or the denials thereof shall be issued within ten (10) days
from the completion of the investigation, and payment of the licensing fee.
   C.   Licenses shall not be transferable.
   D.   There shall be no refund of the license fee. (2008 Code § 21-8)
3-4-8: FEES:
Before a license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay a license fee
according to the following schedule:
   A.   Blanket license for a fixed location:
      1.   Single event blanket license (such as a "starving artists" event):
Seventy five dollars ($75.00).
      2.   Blanket annual license: Five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   B.   Transient merchant's license (door to door):
      1.   For one day: Fifteen dollars ($15.00); for each additional day: Five
dollars ($5.00).
      2.   For one month: Seventy five dollars ($75.00).
      3.   For six (6) months: One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
      4.   For one year: Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
   C.   Duplicate license: Five dollars ($5.00). (2008 Code § 21-9)
3-4-9: BOND REQUIRED 1 :
Except as provided in this chapter, before any license under this chapter shall
be issued, each applicant for a transient merchant license or a blanket license
shall file with the city clerk an acknowledgment from the Iowa secretary of
state that the bond required of all transient merchants operating anywhere
within the state has been filed and will remain valid through the time the
merchant is operating within the city. (2008 Code § 21-10)
 
Notes
1 1. IC § 9C.4.
3-4-10: DUPLICATE LICENSES:
When a transient merchant or any other person required to be licensed by this
chapter loses the license, no further activity may occur until a duplicate
license has been secured. The fee for the duplicate license shall be as
established in subsection
3-4-8C of this chapter. (2008 Code § 21-11)
3-4-11: CHARITABLE AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS:
   A.   License; No Fee:
      1.   A religious, charitable, patriotic, social service, civic, or
political nonprofit organization shall receive a license for activities
regulated under this chapter where its authorized representatives undertake
such activities without remuneration and where the entire proceeds of the
activities will go to the organization and not for private profit. The
organization shall file the information required for a transient merchant
license.
      2.   The clerk shall issue, free of charge, a license for the requested
activity. The license shall be valid for a period of one year, and may be
renewed on or before the expiration date.
   B.   Waiver Of Fee; Proof Of Federal Recognition: If the merchant pays any
of its personnel for conducting the merchant activity, then the fee shall be
waived only upon a showing that the federal internal revenue service has
recognized the merchant as a 501(c)(3) (or similar section of the internal
revenue code) corporation. (2008 Code § 21-12)
3-4-12: BLANKET LICENSES:
   A.   Conditions For Obtaining Blanket Annual License: The owner or person in
control of any real property located in the city, upon which a permanent
business and building is located, who conducts events regulated and required to
be licensed under this chapter, or who leases the premises to transient
merchants for such regulated events, may procure a blanket annual license, and
the individuals conducting the various concessions there will not be required
to obtain individual licenses, under the following conditions:
      1.   The owner or person in control of such real property shall be
required to submit in writing to the city clerk, on forms provided by the
clerk, the locations of the premises upon which such activities are to be
conducted, the names and addresses of the officers and directors or other
governing body of the owner of the premises, and the name, permanent address
and business address of the person in charge of managing such property. Said
person shall also sign a statement that, in the event the license is granted,
he will comply with all the provisions of this chapter and that he guarantees
that the transient merchant leasing property from him shall also comply with
all the provisions of this chapter.
      2.   The licensee shall make the provisions of this chapter a part of any
agreement for the use of the premises for any purpose to which the provisions
of this chapter are applicable.
      3.   It shall be the responsibility of the licensee not to permit any
person to operate or conduct a business on the premises as a transient merchant
who is not entitled to conduct such business under the blanket license.
   B.   Single Event Blanket License:
      1.   Any person conducting or sponsoring an activity in subsection A of
this section may secure a single event blanket license for the same uses and
purposes and on the same terms and conditions as the annual blanket license.
      2.   No event authorized under a single event blanket license shall
continue for more than fourteen (14) consecutive days. (2008 Code § 21-13)
3-4-13: ACTIVITIES NOT SUBJECT TO TRANSIENT MERCHANT LICENSING:
Persons engaged in the following described activities are exempt from the duty
of applying for a transient merchant license:
   A.   Persons selling at wholesale to merchants for the purpose of resale.
   B.   Persons selling or distributing newspapers.
   C.   Persons selling tangible personal property or services to business
enterprises.
   D.   Persons who sell, at their permanent residence in the city, works of
art or craft made or created by such person or a member of such person's
immediate family.
   E.   Persons licensed by the state to sell real estate or insurance or
licensed as transient vendors of drugs.
   F.   Persons selling or distributing livestock feeds as defined by the laws
of the state.
   G.   Persons selling or delivering tangible personal property or services
through a permanent business licensed through the city.
   H.   Persons selling at events for which a blanket license has been
obtained.
   I.   Persons selling or distributing fresh fruit or vegetables cultivated by
such person.
   J.   Persons selling tangible personal property at a garage, basement or
yard sale held at one of the person's premises; however, such activities may be
regulated and shall comply with any zoning restrictions.
   K.   Persons conducting and selling admissions to or for theatricals, shows,
rides, sports and games, concerts, circuses, carnivals or any other public
amusement where no sales of other products are involved and such sales are made
on the premises where the event is to be conducted.
   L.   Persons selling food and beverages at a food service establishment
regulated pursuant to the Iowa Code. (2008 Code § 21-14)
3-4-14: DOOR TO DOOR SOLICITORS:
   A.   License Not Required: Any person who goes door to door soliciting funds
for a nonprofit corporation or religious, charitable, patriotic, social
service, civil or political party shall not be licensed.
   B.   Registration Upon Request: Such person may request registration with
the city to enable response to citizen inquiry, but this is not required. (2008
Code § 16-96)
3-4-15: DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; PROCEDURE:
   A.   Denial Of License: The city administrator may deny, within ten (10)
days, a license to any applicant who has:
      1.   Held a license under this chapter that has been revoked within two
(2) years of the date of the present application.
      2.   Failed to make a complete application.
      3.   During the past two (2) years, a history of:
         a.   Fraudulent applications for similar licenses;
         b.   Misrepresentation of the quality of merchandise or services
offered for sale;
         c.   Crimes involving personal injury.
   B.   Revocation Of License: The city administrator or designee may revoke
any license issued under the provisions of this chapter by sending a notice of
revocation by certified mail to the license holder at the last known address or
by personal service on the license holder, or any licensed person acting on
behalf of the license holder for any of the following causes:
      1.   Information showing that the license was erroneously issued.
      2.   For any violation of the provisions of this chapter.
      3.   For any violation of any city or state law regulating the sales
activities of the license holder.
   C.   Request For Hearing:
      1.   The license shall stand denied or revoked unless, within five (5)
days after denial or receipt of the notice of revocation from the city
administrator, the license applicant or holder files a written request for a
public hearing on the city administrator's action.
      2.   Public hearing shall be conducted before the city council which
shall decide whether a license should be denied, reinstated or revoked, as the
case may be.
      3.   The city council may order the license issued or reinstated either
conditionally or unconditionally or revoke the license.
      4.   Ten (10) days' notice of the time and place of the public hearing
shall be given to the license holder who shall have an opportunity to appear
before the council and present any evidence or arguments he may have as to why
the action taken by the city administrator should not be approved by the city
council. (2008 Code § 21-15)
3-4-16: PENALTY:
Anyone violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each sale or solicitation of a sale made without a license
of bond in violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. (2008
Code § 21-16; amd. 2015 Code)
CHAPTER 5
AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
SECTION:
3-5-1: Auctioneer's License; Fee And Bond
3-5-2: Auction Permit; Fee
3-5-3: Restrictions On Sale
3-5-1: AUCTIONEER'S LICENSE; FEE AND BOND:
   A.   License Required: Any person desiring to perform auctioneering within
the city shall first receive a license therefor.
   B.   Fee: The fee for such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per year.
   C.   Bond: A bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall
be provided with the application to guarantee compliance with this chapter.
Such bond shall be for the benefit of the city and any party damaged by virtue
of an auctioneer's noncompliance with this code. (2008 Code § 16-21)
3-5-2: AUCTION PERMIT; FEE:
   A.   Permit Required: No auctioneer shall sell any property, real, personal,
or mixed, by auction in the city until a permit is received therefor.
   B.   Fee: Fee for such permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per day of
auction.
   C.   Application For Permit: The application for permit shall include a
general description of property to be sold, and the time, date, and place of
the auction. (2008 Code § 16-22)
3-5-3: RESTRICTIONS ON SALE:
   A.   No auction shall be conducted in a manner which will cause streets or
sidewalks to be blocked.
   B.   No person shall, in the conduct of an auction, violate the noise
restriction ordinance.
   C.   No person shall act as a "capper", "booster" or "shill", bidding only
to increase the prices obtained without intending to purchase the merchandise
offered.
   D.   No advertisement for an auction shall be made which makes untrue or
deceptive statements.
   E.   No auction shall be conducted from nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. to eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M.
   F.   No person shall exhibit and sell an item at auction, only to attempt to
convince the purchaser to take a substitute item. (2008 Code § 16-23)
CHAPTER 6
CLOSING OUT OR GOING OUT OF BUSINESS SALES
SECTION:
3-6-1: Sale Defined
3-6-2: License Required; Fee
3-6-3: Application For License
3-6-4: Restrictions On Sale
3-6-5: Revocation Of License
3-6-1: SALE DEFINED:
   A.   "Closing out or going out of business sales" shall be defined as
including any sale in which the public is led to believe that the sale will
include goods damaged by fire, smoke, water, or other means regardless of
whether the business intends to cease operation; that goods offered are offered
to dispose of such inventory prior to the close or cessation of business; or
any of the following types of sales: adjuster, adjustment, assignee, bankrupt,
benefit of creditors, benefit of trustee, loss of lease, forced out of
business, quitting business, or liquidation. It shall also include sales by a
person or business which is closing one of multiple sales locations within the
city.
   B.   Such sales as described in subsection A of this section shall not be
deemed to include sales by the sheriff, by an executor or guardian, or by any
party pursuant to a court order. (2008 Code § 16-36)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
No person shall hold a closing out or going out of business sale without first
obtaining a license therefor. The fee for such license shall be twenty five
dollars ($25.00) per day. (2008 Code § 16-37)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The application for the license required by this chapter shall contain the
following information:
   A.   The name of the owner of the goods.
   B.   A description of the place where the goods are to be sold.
   C.   The dates on which the sale is to be held.
   D.   A statement of the reason for the sale.
   E.   A complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be sold. (2008 Code §
16-38)
3-6-4: RESTRICTIONS ON SALE:
   A.   No sale as licensed herein shall be for more than sixty (60)
consecutive days. A license having been given once to any business shall not be
renewed.
   B.   No merchandise may be sold at such sale except as is listed on the
inventory.
   C.   No sale or offer of sale shall include the use of deceit, fraud, or
misrepresentation in either such sale or advertising for such sale.
   D.   No business shall qualify for a going out of business license until
such business has existed for at least one hundred twenty (120) consecutive
calendar days. (2008 Code § 16-39)
3-6-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Upon discovery of a violation of this chapter, the code enforcement official
shall revoke the license issued. Appeal shall be as described in section
3-1-7 of this title. (2008 Code § 16-40)
CHAPTER 7
PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND GOODS DEALERS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: License Required; Fee
3-7-3: Exclusions
3-7-4: Record Of Transactions
3-7-5: Purchases From Minors
3-7-6: Time Merchandise Held Prior To Sale
3-7-7: Altered Serial Numbers
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ESTABLISHED DEALER: Any person who has engaged in any occupation regulated
under this chapter for more than thirty (30) consecutive days at a fixed
location in Bettendorf, Iowa.
ITINERANT DEALER: Any person who engages in any occupation regulated under this
chapter who is not an established dealer.
PAWNBROKER: Any person engaged in the business of buying tangible personal
property for which a record of transaction is required to be filed, whether
said purchase is subject to the seller's right of repurchase or redemption or
not; or a person engaged in the business of receiving actual possession of
tangible personal property for which a record of transaction is required to be
filed as security for loans with or without a mortgage, lien, or bill of sale.
SECONDHAND DEALER: Any person engaged in the business of buying or selling
secondhand goods.
SECONDHAND GOODS: Tangible personal property previously owned by another
person, whether used or not, which property, in its present state, possesses
utility for the purpose for which it was originally intended. This definition
shall include gold, silver, copper, or platinum articles to include any coins,
jewelry, or gems bought for resale, meltdown or scrap.
TANGIBLE PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall be deemed to include, but not limited to:
   A.   Items made in whole or in part of gold, silver, platinum, copper or
other precious metal;
   B.   A collection of one or more coins or bills of currency;
   C.   Items containing or consisting of precious or semiprecious gemstones or
other polished stones used for decoration or jewelry;
   D.   Articles with serial numbers, model numbers or identifying marks,
including, but not limited to, appliances, tools, radios, stereo equipment,
radar detectors, televisions, cellular phones, video recorders, camcorders,
video equipment, computers, computer equipment and accessories, digital music
recorders and players, video game equipment and accessories, cameras, but not
including washers, dryers, refrigerators and auto parts;
   E.   Musical instruments;
   F.   Rifles, shotguns, firearms, and handguns;
   G.   Movie cassette tapes and disks, digital video disks (DVDs), music
cassette tapes, compact discs, record albums, computer software and diskettes,
and video game cartridges.
The pawnbroker or secondhand goods dealer must specify the identity of all
items pawned or sold under this chapter. (2008 Code § 16-76)
3-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
No person shall operate as a pawnbroker or secondhand goods dealer without
first obtaining a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00). (2008 Code § 16-77)
3-7-3: EXCLUSIONS:
The following activities shall not apply to the provisions of this chapter:
   A.   Collecting/selling by nonprofit corporations, including, but not
limited to, Salvation Army and Goodwill Industries.
   B.   Auctions by licensed auctioneers.
   C.   Single day or limited events such as flea markets or garage sales.
   D.   Fairs, conventions, and hobby shows.
   E.   Wholesaling or dealer to dealer sales of merchandise. (2008 Code § 16-
78)
3-7-4: RECORD OF TRANSACTIONS:
   A.   Report Required: Every pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, established
dealer or itinerant dealer shall report each transaction to the designated
internet based property tracking service at the end of each business day to
include an accurate and detailed account of the sale, purchase, pawn, trade in,
or exchange of tangible personal property.
   B.   Description Of Transactions:
      1.   The record of each transaction shall be entered and maintained using
the designated internet based property tracking service required by the police
department and shall include a complete, detailed, and accurate description of
each article pawned, purchased, traded in, or exchanged including serial
numbers and model numbers; a transcription of any engraving or other
identifying labels, markings, or writings located on the item; brand name and
model number of each item if applicable; the titles of all movie cassette tapes
or DVD disks; the title and artist name of all musical cassette tapes, albums,
or compact discs; the number and description of any decorative precious or
semiprecious gems, stones, or jewelry; the brand name and title of any and all
video game cartridge; the brand name and title of any and all computer
software; and the price paid to the customer for each item.
      2.   The record of each transaction shall be uploaded into the designated
internet based property tracking service by the end of each business day.
   C.   Digital Photograph Of Property And Customer:
      1.   Digital photographs shall be taken of each transaction to include:
an overall photograph of the item, a photograph depicting the serial and model
number of each item if applicable, a photograph depicting any identifiable
marks or engravings on the item if applicable. U.S./foreign coin and/or
currency would be excluded from the digital photograph transaction requirement.
      2.   A current state issued photographic identification card or driver's
license shall be scanned or photographed and uploaded to the designated
internet based property tracking service for each transaction thereafter.
      3.   All digital photographs must be clear and recognizable of the
property and customer.
      4.   All digital photographs shall be uploaded to the internet based
property tracking service designated by the police department by the end of
each business day.
   D.   Customer And Dealer Information Required:
      1.   The record of each transaction shall include the date and time of
the transaction, a description of the customer selling, pawning, trading in, or
exchanging tangible personal property, which description shall include the
person's first and last name, address, date of birth (month/day/year), sex,
driver's license or state issued identification number to include the state,
approximate height and weight, and other distinguishing characteristics (scars,
tattoos, birthmarks, known physical limitations).
      2.   The dealer or employee involved in the transaction shall be
identified for each item listed on the record of transaction. No such entry
shall be erased, obliterated, or deleted in any manner. A separate record of
transaction shall be completed for each transaction between the licensed
establishment and a particular customer for that specific date and time.
Transactions with a particular customer on the same date as a previous
transaction, but at a later time, shall be completed on a separate record of
transaction as if the earlier transaction had not occurred. Transactions
between licensed establishments located at different addresses shall be
recorded on the record of transaction in the same manner as any other required
recorded transaction.
   E.   Records Open To Inspection:
      1.   The record of transaction as well as each item of tangible personal
property pawned, pledged, or purchased shall, at all reasonable times, be open
to inspection upon demand by any sworn officer of any federal, state, county,
or city law enforcement agency in regard to a criminal investigation.
      2.   Each licensee shall keep, file and maintain copies of the record of
transactions to include the resale of property and buyer identification for at
least one year from the date of the transaction.
   F.   Internet Based Property Tracking Service: The current internet based
property tracking service designated by the Bettendorf police department is
LeadsOnline (leadsonline.com). (2008 Code § 16-80)
3-7-5: PURCHASES FROM MINORS:
No dealer under this chapter shall acquire any tangible personal property
described in section
3-7-1 of this chapter from a person under eighteen (18) years of age. (2008
Code § 16-81)
3-7-6: TIME MERCHANDISE HELD PRIOR TO SALE:
   A.   Time Period: No pawnbroker, secondhand goods dealer, established dealer
or itinerant dealer shall sell, melt, scrap, change, dispose of, transfer, or
alter in any manner any tangible personal property received in exchange, trade
in or purchase for a minimum period of ten (10) business days after the record
of transaction has been uploaded to the designated internet based property
tracking service. U.S./foreign coin and/or currency would be excluded from the
time requirement. Items received in pawn must be held for a minimum of ten (10)
business days after the date for repayment of the amount loaned has expired,
unless the property pawned is redeemed by the person who originally pawned it
within the agreed time limit with the licensee.
   B.   Tagging Articles: During the ten (10) day waiting period, the dealer
shall separate each day's acquisitions by tagging each article or placing each
article in a container such that the date of the acquisition of the article is
clearly indicated.
   C.   Suspicion Of Stolen Articles; Extension Of Time: In the event that the
chief of police or his designee has reasonable suspicion that an article
pawned, purchased or exchanged is stolen or that information furnished by the
customer is false, the retention period may be extended for an additional seven
(7) days. (2008 Code § 16-82)
3-7-7: ALTERED SERIAL NUMBERS:
No pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, established dealer or itinerant dealer shall
acquire any tangible personal property bearing evidence of a serial number
which has been tampered with, scratched or obliterated in any manner unless the
dealer informs the Bettendorf police department of such fact at the time of the
acquisition. (2008 Code § 16-83)
CHAPTER 8
JUNK DEALERS
SECTION:
3-8-1: Definitions
3-8-2: License Required; Fee
3-8-3: Record Book
3-8-4: Resale Of Junk
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
JUNK: Any article or material which, because of age, deterioration or use, has
lost its original utility or desirability but which, through alteration,
restoration, or salvage, may become an item of value.
JUNK DEALER: A person or business engaged in the collecting, storing, buying or
selling of junk. (2008 Code § 16-46)
3-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
No person or business shall operate as a junk dealer without receiving a
license therefor. The fee for such license shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) per
year. (2008 Code § 16-47)
3-8-3: RECORD BOOK:
Each junk dealer shall maintain a record book of items received, showing from
whom received, a description of the item including quantity and weight, and
amount paid. Such book shall be made available to a police officer or code
enforcement officer, upon request. (2008 Code § 16-48)
3-8-4: RESALE OF JUNK:
No junk shall be resold for forty eight (48) hours after acquisition. (2008
Code § 16-49)
CHAPTER 9
BILLPOSTERS
SECTION:
3-9-1: Billposter Defined
3-9-2: License Required; Fee
3-9-3: Posting Of Advertising Material
3-9-1: BILLPOSTER DEFINED:
A "billposter" shall be a person who engages in the business of distributing
advertising by posting, painting or otherwise. (2008 Code § 16-25)
3-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
Any person acting as a billposter shall apply for and receive a license
therefor. The fee for such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each day
the person engages in billposting. (2008 Code § 16-26)
3-9-3: POSTING OF ADVERTISING MATERIAL:
   A.   Consent Required: No advertising material may be posted on private
property without the consent of the owner, or city property, including city
rights of way, without the consent of the council.
   B.   Placing On Vehicles: No advertising material may be placed on vehicles
standing in any street, alley, parking lot, or other public place. This
subsection shall not be deemed to prevent public officers from attaching
notices or other matters to vehicles pursuant to their duties.
   C.   Throwing On Streets, Other Public Grounds: No person shall simply throw
or deposit advertising materials on the streets or other public grounds of the
city. (2008 Code § 16-27)
CHAPTER 10
TREE SURGEONS
SECTION:
3-10-1: Definition
3-10-2: License Required; Fee
3-10-3: Insurance Required; Amounts
3-10-4: Bond Required; Conditions
3-10-1: DEFINITION:
The term "tree surgeon", as used in this chapter, shall mean any person who for
a valuable consideration cuts or trims any tree or limbs or branches of any
tree or who cuts and removes any tree or treats diseases of any tree. (2008
Code § 29-16)
3-10-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   License Required: No person shall act as a tree surgeon in the city
without first obtaining a license therefor. (2008 Code § 29-17)
   B.   Fee: The annual fee for a license required by this chapter shall be
twenty five dollars ($25.00). (2008 Code § 29-19)
3-10-3: INSURANCE REQUIRED; AMOUNTS:
   A.   Amounts Of Insurance: Before any license required by this chapter shall
be issued, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a certificate of
insurance with the city being shown as an insured which insures the city and
the applicant in the following minimum amounts: fifty thousand dollars'
($50,000.00) coverage for property damage, one hundred thousand dollars'
($100,000.00) coverage per person per occurrence for death or bodily injury
with a maximum of three hundred thousand dollars' ($300,000.00) coverage per
occurrence for death or bodily injury.
   B.   Notice Of Cancellation: Said certificate shall further provide for
fifteen (15) days' notice of cancellation. (2008 Code § 29-18)
3-10-4: BOND REQUIRED; CONDITIONS:
The applicant for license required by this chapter shall post with the clerk a
penal bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with good and
sufficient sureties approved by the city attorney. The bond shall guarantee the
applicant's payment for any damage done to the city or to public property in
the course of the performance of the applicant's business. (2008 Code § 29-20)
CHAPTER 11
CAR DEALERS
SECTION:
3-11-1: License Required; Application; Fee
3-11-2: Car Lots
3-11-3: Car Auctions
3-11-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE:
   A.   License Required: Any person who engages in the business of selling or
buying motor vehicles, such vehicles to be licensed and used on public right of
way, whether new or used, shall make application and receive a license
therefor.
   B.   Fee: The fee for such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   C.   Employees Or Agents Excepted: Businesses which receive licenses under
this section shall not be required to license individual employees or agents.
(2008 Code § 16-29)
3-11-2: CAR LOTS:
   A.   Minimum Area For Lot: The minimum area for a new or used car lot shall
be ten thousand (10,000) square feet.
   B.   Hard Surface; Cleanliness: All car lots shall be hard surfaced with
portland concrete, cement or asphalt, and free of dust, trash, and debris.
(2008 Code § 16-30)
3-11-3: CAR AUCTIONS:
No person shall sell motor vehicles at auctions without first providing to the
police department the vehicle identification number of the vehicle to be
auctioned, a description of the vehicle by make, year and model, and its value.
This information shall be provided at least one week before the auction is to
be held. (2008 Code § 16-31)
CHAPTER 12
VEHICLES FOR HIRE
SECTION:
3-12-1: Bus Stops And Taxicab Stands
3-12-2: Parking On Public Or Private Property
3-12-3: Payment For Transportation
3-12-4: Rates For Municipal Transit System
3-12-5: Appeal From Actions Of Clerk
3-12-6: Denial, Suspension Or Revocation Of License
3-12-1: BUS STOPS AND TAXICAB STANDS:
   A.   Designation By Signs: Every bus stop and taxicab stand shall be
designated by appropriate signs.
   B.   Use Of Stops And Stands:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle other than a
bus to stand or park in an officially designated bus stop, or of any vehicle
other than a taxicab to stand or park in an officially designated taxicab
stand, except that the operator of any passenger vehicle may temporarily stop
in any such stop or stand for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in,
the loading or unloading of passengers.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any bus or taxicab to stand
or park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a
bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively. This provision shall not prohibit the
operator of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other
parking regulations at any place for the purpose of, and while actually engaged
in, loading or unloading passengers. (2008 Code § 30-1)
   C.   Bus Stops Enumerated: The following locations shall be used as bus
stops in the city:
State Street, on the south side, from one hundred seventy three feet (173')
west of 17th Street to one hundred ten feet (110') west of 17th Street. (2008
Code § 30-6)
3-12-2: PARKING ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   Streets, Public Places: It shall be unlawful to leave any motor vehicle
kept for hire parked or standing on any street, alley or public place, except
for the purpose of loading and unloading, and then only so long as is necessary
for loading and unloading, not to exceed ten (10) minutes at any one time.
   B.   Private Property: All such vehicles kept for hire, when not actually in
use carrying or loading or unloading passengers or freight, shall stand on
private property. (2008 Code § 30-2)
3-12-3: PAYMENT FOR TRANSPORTATION:
No person shall, without having previously arranged for credit on account
thereof, procure carriage or transportation by any taxicab or rent any
automobile from any person conducting an auto livery, with or without a driver,
without paying for such transportation or the hiring of such vehicle. (2008
Code § 30-3)
3-12-4: RATES FOR MUNICIPAL TRANSIT SYSTEM:
Quad city monthly passport                                               $30.00
Fare information:                                                         
 Full                                                                   1.00
  Dial-a-bus                                                             4.00

  Route bus                                                              0.50

  Accompanying aide                                                      Free
College students (upon presentation of current school ID)                0.50
Monthly pass (Bettendorf transit only)                                   21.00
Monthly pass (Bettendorf transit only; seniors/patrons with disabilities 10.50
- medicare card qualifies)
 
(2008 Code § 30-7)
3-12-5: APPEAL FROM ACTIONS OF CLERK:
Any person deeming himself aggrieved by any ruling of the city clerk with
respect to the application of any administrative provisions of this chapter may
appeal therefrom to the city council. (2008 Code § 30-4)
3-12-6: DENIAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Suspension Or Revocation; Notice; Hearing: Licenses granted pursuant to
this chapter may be suspended or revoked at any time by the mayor or by the
council for violation of any provision of this chapter or for any cause deemed
sufficient by the council. The revocation of any license is sufficient cause
for the mayor to deny the issuance of another license under this chapter to the
same licensee. If the issuance of any license is denied or if a license is
revoked by the mayor, the mayor shall immediately give the applicant or
licensee written notice of such action and specify a time, not more than five
(5) days after the notice, for a hearing before the mayor and city council, at
which time the applicant or licensee may show cause and be heard in behalf of
the granting or restoring of such license.
   B.   Rendering Decision: If proper showing is made at the hearing, the mayor
and city council shall order the license issued or restored. (2008 Code § 30-5;
amd. 2015 Code)
ARTICLE A. TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-12A-1: Definition
3-12A-2: License Required; Fee
3-12A-3: Insurance Required
3-12A-4: Vehicle Inspection; Equipment
3-12A-5: Designation Of Taxicabs
3-12A-6: Taximeter
3-12A-7: Rates For Service; Receipts
3-12A-8: Driver Photo Identification
3-12A-9: Taxi Stands
3-12A-10: Unattended Taxicabs
3-12A-1: DEFINITION:
"Taxi service" shall be defined as the transport of passengers in a motor
vehicle from one point to another either within or without the city for pay.
(2008 Code § 16-102)
3-12A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   License Required: No person shall operate a motor vehicle to provide a
taxi service within the city without obtaining a license therefor.
   B.   Fee; Term Of License: The fee for this license shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) for each vehicle registered, and the license shall be valid from July
1 to June 30 of each year. (2008 Code § 16-102)
3-12A-3: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
All vehicles serving as taxicabs shall be covered by insurance in an amount not
less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for the injury or death
of any one person, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for the injury or death
of any number of persons, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for
property damage from any one accident. The city shall be listed as an
additional named insured. (2008 Code § 16-102)
3-12A-4: VEHICLE INSPECTION; EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Inspection: All vehicles used as taxicabs shall be inspected by the
chief of police or the chief's designee prior to a license being issued.
   B.   Equipment: All vehicles serving as taxicabs shall be equipped with all
safety equipment, including, but not limited to, seat belts, horns, lights,
windshield wipers, etc., required by this code or state law. (2008 Code § 16-
103)
3-12A-5: DESIGNATION OF TAXICABS:
Each vehicle used to provide taxi service within the city shall display on the
