      1.   Leaving a motor vehicle (whether licensed or not) on city streets on
a regular (daily) and continual (for periods of time of not less than 15 hours)
basis.
      2.   Leaving a motor vehicle (whether licensed or not) on city streets,
moving such vehicle only to comply with the criminal requirements of section
6-1-133 of this code.
   B.   Prohibition: In any zoning district where open storage of material is
not allowed, no person shall use the city street or right of way for storage of
vehicles. (2008 Code § 27-35)
7-1-5: ABUTTING PROPERTY OWNER MAINTENANCE DUTIES:
   A.   Maintenance Required: The owner of property abutting a public street or
streets shall maintain all property outside the lot and property lines and
inside the curb lines upon such public street or streets, except that the
property owner shall not be required to remove diseased or dead wood.
   B.   Serving Order For Maintenance: If the director of public works finds
that any such maintenance work is necessary, the director shall serve a written
order on the owner of the abutting property specifying therein the work
necessary to be done. The order may be served by either:
      1.   Making personal service of the order on the owner as permitted by
Iowa rules of civil procedure (IRCP) 56. The person making the service shall
make a return of personal service which shall state the time, manner and place
of service, and the name of the person to whom a copy of the order was
delivered; or
      2.   Mailing a copy of the order by certified mail to the property owner
as shown by the records of the Scott County auditor.
   C.   Time Limit: The order required by this section shall set forth a
reasonable time limit for compliance.
   D.   Right To Appeal: Any property owner to whom an order pursuant to this
section is directed shall have the right, within forty eight (48) hours from
service of the order, to appeal to the mayor who shall review the order within
five (5) days and file his decision thereon. Unless the order is revoked or
modified, it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by the property owner as
directed, with the time for compliance to commence at the time of the mayor's
decision. (2008 Code § 27-20)
7-1-6: CITY PERFORMANCE OF WORK; COSTS; ASSESSMENT:
   A.   Failure Of Owner To Comply; Abatement By City: When a property owner to
whom an order issued pursuant to section
7-1-5 of this chapter is directed, fails to comply within the time specified,
the director of public works shall remedy the condition, or contract with
others for such purpose, and charge the cost thereof to the person to whom the
order is directed.
   B.   Failure To Pay Costs; Assessment Against Property: If the cost of
remedying a condition is not paid within thirty (30) days after the mailing of
a statement therefor from the director of public works, the cost shall be
assessed against the abutting property for collection in the same manner as a
property tax. (2008 Code § 27-21)
7-1-7: REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS BY PROPERTY OWNER OR CITY:
The city may require the abutting property owner to repair, replace or
reconstruct sidewalks; but in the event that such work is not completed within
thirty (30) days of the date of deposit in the mail of notice to the property
owner as shown in the records of the county auditor, by certified mail, then
the council may cause such work to be done and assess the expense thereof on
the property in front of which such work is done, and the same shall be
certified and collected as other taxes. If the cost exceeds two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00), the same may be certified for payment in three (3) equal
annual installments with interest from the date of certification on each
installment until paid, at the maximum interest rate allowed by law, and shall
be collected as other taxes with the September semiannual payment thereof.
(2008 Code § 27-44)
7-1-8: MAILBOXES AND NEWSPAPER RECEPTACLES:
   A.   Installation Requirements: It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain a
mailbox or newspaper receptacle on public grounds between the curb line or
shoulder and the sidewalk or, where no sidewalk exists, property line, except
in conformance with the following requirements:
      1.   Mailbox And Newspaper Receptacles: The location and height of a
mailbox or newspaper receptacle shall be constructed in conformance with the
requirements of postal regulation, section 156.5, as adopted by the United
States postal service.
      2.   Supporting Structure: The mailbox or newspaper receptacle supporting
structure shall be adequate to properly mount the box and shall be constructed
of:
         a.   Wood no larger than four inches by four inches (4" x 4") square
or a four and one-half inch (41/2") round post.
         b.   Metal pipe or conduit having inside diameter of no more than one
and one-half inches (11/2") or a metal post weighing no more than two (2)
pounds per foot.
   B.   Effective Date: This section shall apply to all mailboxes or newspaper
receptacles constructed or reconstructed after the effective date hereof 1 .
(2008 Code § 27-22)
 
Notes
1 1. This section derived from ordinance 3-85, adopted February 5, 1985.
7-1-9: DUMPING OF MATERIAL AT RECYCLING CENTERS:
No person shall deposit or leave any material, whether recyclable or not,
within the confines or adjacent to any city sponsored recycling location when
such location is not open and accepting such material. (2008 Code § 27-34)
7-1-10: REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE FROM SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Removal Required: No owner, tenant, responsible party or person in
possession or control of property shall allow snow or ice accumulations to
remain upon abutting sidewalks for more than forty eight (48) hours from the
end of a winter weather event.
   B.   Removal By City: Snow or ice accumulations which have remained on any
sidewalk for more than forty eight (48) hours may be removed by the city. If
the property owner fails to pay the costs of such removal, including a seventy
five dollar ($75.00) administrative fee, the city may assess the costs against
the property in the same manner as a property tax, as provided by Iowa law.
   C.   Notice To Owners: Notice to the owner or person in control of lands
subject to this chapter shall be as follows: The director of community
development shall cause to be published on or about November 1 of each year in
a newspaper of general circulation within the city a notice stating that work
of snow and ice removal is required to be done during the months of November
through March, inclusive, and a statement that property owners have forty eight
(48) hours within which such owners may cause the work to be done. Further, the
notice shall state that failure to comply after publication of the notice will
result in the work being done by the city, and the costs incurred by the city,
including a seventy five dollar ($75.00) administrative fee, shall be assessed
against the property in the manner provided by law. No further notice shall be
required. (Ord. 22-16, 11-1-2016)
7-1-11: OBSTRUCTING STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Obstructions; Gates: Except as provided in section
6-1-128 of this code, it shall be unlawful to obstruct, or cause or allow to be
obstructed any street, alley, or sidewalk, or to erect or hang any gate so it
opens outward over any street, alley or sidewalk. (2008 Code § 27-1)
   B.   Depositing Substances Prohibited; Exception: It shall be unlawful to
place or deposit on any sidewalk, street or public ground, any substance, thing
or material. This subsection shall not apply to the receipt or delivery of any
merchandise on a sidewalk which does not occupy more than one-third (1/3) of
the width of a sidewalk and is not permitted to remain upon the sidewalk for
more than twenty four (24) consecutive hours. (2008 Code § 27-1; amd. 2015
Code)
7-1-12: SALES STANDS; MERCHANDISE:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to erect or keep any stand for
the sale of fruit, vegetables, or other substances or commodities on any
sidewalk, street or alley, or to use or occupy any vehicle for the sale
therefrom of any article on any street or alley without first obtaining a
written permit therefor from the mayor.
   B.   Interruption Of Pedestrians: It shall be unlawful to place upon or
above any sidewalk, any goods or merchandise for sale or for display in such a
manner as to interfere with the free and uninterrupted passage on the sidewalk
of pedestrians. In no case shall more than two feet (2') of the sidewalk next
to the building be occupied for such purposes. (2008 Code § 27-3)
7-1-13: AWNINGS; STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any awning over any street or
sidewalk unless all parts of the awning are elevated at least seven feet (7')
above the surface of the street or sidewalk and the roof or covering is made of
duck, canvas or other suitable material supported by iron frames or brackets
securely fastened to the building, without any posts or other device that will
obstruct the street or sidewalk or hinder or interfere with the free passage of
pedestrians or vehicles. (2008 Code § 27-4)
7-1-14: ENCROACHING STAIRS OR STEPS:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any stairs or steps to the first or
second floor of any building upon any part of any sidewalk, street or alley,
without permission by resolution of the city council. (2008 Code § 27-5)
7-1-15: OPENINGS AND ENCLOSURES:
   A.   Council Permission Required: It shall be unlawful to construct or build
a stairway or passageway to any cellar or basement by occupying any part of the
sidewalk, street or alley, or to enclose any portion of a street, sidewalk or
alley with a railing, without permission by resolution of the city council.
   B.   Openings Guarded:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to keep open any cellar door, grating, or cover
to any vault on any sidewalk, street, or alley, except while in actual use,
with adequate guards to protect the public.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to neglect to properly protect or guard all
openings on or within six feet (6') of any street, alley or sidewalk. (2008
Code § 27-6)
7-1-16: REMOVING OR AVOIDING BARRICADES:
It shall be unlawful to knock down, remove or destroy any barricade erected on
any street, alley or public place by the authority of the city, or to drive on
or over any curb or parking to pass around such a barricade. (2008 Code § 27-7)
7-1-17: REMOVAL OF MATERIALS FROM PUBLIC WAYS AND GROUNDS:
It shall be unlawful to remove or cause to be removed any dirt, sand, stone,
rock, tree, shrub, plank, sidewalk, or fence from any street, alley, lot, or
ground belonging to the city, without authority from the city council. (2008
Code § 27-8)
7-1-18: FIRES ON PAVEMENT PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to make a fire of any kind on any pavement or sidewalk.
(2008 Code § 27-9)
7-1-19: ERECTION OF POSTS:
It shall be unlawful to erect, maintain, or to cause or allow to be erected or
maintained, any signpost or other post or pole for any purpose on any sidewalk,
street or alley, except by permission by resolution of the city council. (2008
Code § 27-11)
7-1-20: RAINWATER DISPOSAL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any waterspout, trough,
gutter or balcony extending from any building owned or leased by him to
discharge or conduct water upon the surface of any sidewalk. All such water
shall be conducted under the sidewalk in accordance with plans and
specifications of the city engineer and under his direction. (2008 Code § 27-
12; amd. 2015 Code)
7-1-21: BARBED WIRE:
   A.   Areas Zoned Agricultural: It shall be unlawful to place or maintain any
barbed wire fronting on or adjacent to any street, alley or sidewalk except in
those areas zoned for agricultural purposes, or as permitted herein.
   B.   Commercial And Industrial Purposes: In areas zoned for commercial and
industrial purposes, barbed wire may be placed more than six feet (6') above
the ground when placed in conjunction with a woven wire security fence. (2008
Code § 27-13)
7-1-22: PLANTING SHRUBBERY ON PARKINGS:
It shall be unlawful to plant or maintain shrubbery on any parking or between
the sidewalk and the curb line of any street. (2008 Code § 27-14)
7-1-23: DEFACING PUBLIC WAYS AND PLACES:
It shall be unlawful to scatter or place any paste, paint or writing on any
sidewalk, street or public place. (2008 Code § 27-15)
7-1-24: DANGEROUS OBJECTS; REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful to throw, place or deposit any glass, nails or other sharp
substances, ashes, cinders, straw, paper, sweepings, brush, weeds, spoiled
fruit or vegetables, refuse, or rubbish of any kind, upon any sidewalk, street,
alley, gutter, drain, or public ground. (2008 Code § 27-16)
7-1-25: FUEL ON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful to place or allow any fuel to remain upon any street,
alley, or sidewalk. (2008 Code § 27-17)
7-1-26: CLEANING OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Transporting Dirt Or Fill: When construction activity requires
transport of earthmoving equipment or dirt or fill across city streets and
sidewalks, no dirt shall be allowed to remain on streets or sidewalks as a
result of such movement.
   B.   Removal Of Dirt; Responsibility: When dirt or other material is left on
sidewalks or streets as a result of activities as described in subsection A of
this section, the dirt or other material shall be immediately removed by the
person actually placing the dirt on city streets or sidewalks, by the employer
of such a person, by the general contractor at the site of the construction
activity, and/or by the owner of the property being developed. The
responsibility affixed by this section shall be joint and several to the
parties listed.
   C.   Violation; Penalty: Failure to clean up shall subject the parties to
the municipal infraction penalties of this code. (2008 Code § 27-23)
7-1-27: LITTERING OF STREETS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, directly or
indirectly, through employees, agents or subcontractors to store, cast,
deposit, strew, scatter or lay or cause or allow to be stored, cast, laid,
deposited, strewn or scattered, any shavings, ashes, mud, garbage, dung,
rubbish, dirt, earth, stone, crushed rock, gravel, cement, plaster, cement or
lime mixtures, coal, wood, glass, metal, snow, ice, leaves or other debris,
filth or refuse matter on any of the streets, lanes, alleys or other public
property in the city, without having obtained prior approval in writing for
such from the department of public works. Each day that any of the above
substances are allowed to remain on public property shall constitute a separate
offense. (2008 Code § 27-30)
7-1-28: SNOW AND WATER FROM ROOFS:
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any snow or water from any roof to be
thrown or placed upon any street. (2008 Code § 27-31)
7-1-29: BUILDING MATERIALS IN STREET; PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to place or deposit any building
material in any street without a written permit from the community development
director, subject to revocation by the council, to use part of the street in
front of or adjacent to the lot whereon a building is being erected, for
depositing thereon the material for the building.
   B.   Obstructing Gutters Prohibited: All material shall be placed in such a
manner as not to obstruct the gutters.
   C.   Guarding Obstruction: The person occupying a portion of a street
subject to this section shall at all times enclose or guard the same in such a
manner as to protect the public. Lighted barricades shall be placed thereon and
kept burning at night. (2008 Code § 27-32; amd. 2015 Code)
7-1-30: EQUIPMENT, FACILITIES ON STREETS:
It shall be unlawful to erect, maintain, or to cause or allow to be erected or
maintained on any street, any air line, air service pipe or hose, air pump,
water hydrant or water service of any kind except water hydrants belonging to
the city. (2008 Code § 27-33)
CHAPTER 2
SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-2-1: Permanent And Temporary Sidewalks; Procedure
7-2-2: Resolution; Construction By Owner Or City
7-2-3: Failure Of Property Owner To Construct
7-2-4: Approaches And Curb Cuts; Access Permit
7-2-5: Sidewalk Improvements
7-2-6: Construction Standards And Specifications
7-2-7: Contractors, Bond
7-2-8: Sidewalk Repairs
7-2-1: PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY SIDEWALKS; PROCEDURE:
   A.   Permanent Sidewalks:
      1.   The city council may by resolution order the construction or
reconstruction of permanent sidewalks upon any street, but the construction of
a permanent sidewalk shall not be made until the bed of the permanent sidewalk
has been graded so that, when completed, the sidewalk will be at the
established grade.
      2.   Unless the owners of a majority of the linear feet of property
fronting on the improvement petition the council therefor, the improvement
shall not be made unless three- fourths (3/4) of all members of the council by
vote order the improvement. (2008 Code § 27-52)
   B.   Temporary Sidewalks:
      1.   The city council may by resolution order the construction or
reconstruction of temporary sidewalks upon any street or court which has not
been brought to the established grade, and may assess the cost thereof against
the property in front of which the sidewalk is laid.
      2.   No temporary sidewalk shall be ordered except by a vote of three-
fourths (3/4) of the members of the council. (2008 Code § 27-53)
7-2-2: RESOLUTION; CONSTRUCTION BY OWNER OR CITY:
   A.   Notice To Property Owners: After the city council adopts a resolution
of necessity to construct sidewalks, notice shall be sent by certified mail to
property owners advising them that they have a minimum of thirty (30) days
after the adoption of said resolution of necessity to construct the walks.
   B.   Noncompliance By Owner; Construction By City; Assessment Of Costs:
Unless said sidewalks are constructed within the time specified, the council
shall cause such sidewalks to be constructed, and the cost and expense thereof
assessed against the adjoining or abutting lots or parcels of ground. (2008
Code § 27-54)
7-2-3: FAILURE OF PROPERTY OWNER TO CONSTRUCT:
If the owner of any lot or parcel of ground in front of which a sidewalk is
constructed or reconstructed fails to construct or reconstruct the sidewalk
within the time prescribed by the resolution ordering the improvement, the
council shall cause the improvement to be made, and the costs and expense
thereof shall be assessed against the lots or parcels of ground adjoining the
improvement. (2008 Code § 27-56)
7-2-4: APPROACHES AND CURB CUTS; ACCESS PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required; Specifications:
      1.   No person or owner of property shall construct any sidewalk or
driveway approach or make any curb cut on a public street without first
obtaining a permit.
      2.   A driveway approach to a single-family residential lot shall be the
same width of the applicant's driveway at the point of connection up to, but
not to exceed, twenty feet (20'), except where applicant has a three (3) car
garage, in which case a driveway approach shall be the same width of the
applicant's driveway at the point of connection or thirty three feet (33'),
whichever is less.
      3.   The driveway located in an A-1 agricultural district may be composed
of material comparable to an adjoining city or county street or road.
      4.   The driveway must meet Bettendorf fire department maneuverability
and weight bearing standards. (2008 Code § 27-57)
   B.   Application; Fee; Granting Of Permit:
      1.   Application for a permit along with payment of a permit fee pursuant
to the fee schedule adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council
shall be made to the building inspector on forms supplied by the building
department. The community development director shall, within ten (10) days
following the filing of the application, either grant or deny the permit. Said
permit must be granted if the proposed sidewalk, driveway approach or curb cut
will not: (2008 Code § 27-57; amd. 2015 Code)
         a.   Endanger the traveling public or pedestrians;
         b.   Cause damage or injury to any public improvements, public
facilities or public utilities;
         c.   Cause substantial injury to the rights of adjacent property
owners;
         d.   Unreasonably reduce the carrying capacity of the public street.
(2008 Code § 27-57)
      2.   The community development director may grant a permit subject to
conditions or limitations reasonably designed to ensure compliance with the
above.
   C.   Right Of Appeal: The applicant may appeal to the city council a
determination of the community development director granting or denying an
access permit by filing a written notice of appeal with the city clerk within
thirty (30) days following the date of the community development director's
determination. (2008 Code § 27-57; amd. 2015 Code)
7-2-5: SIDEWALK IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   City Contract: All sidewalk improvements made by the city shall be done
under written contract. (2008 Code § 27-58)
   B.   Costs Assessed By Resolution: Whenever any sidewalk improvement is
constructed or reconstructed by the council as provided in this chapter, the
cost and expense of the construction or reconstruction shall be assessed by
resolution against the lot or parcel of ground adjoining. (2008 Code § 27-59)
7-2-6: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Minimum Widths:
      1.   All sidewalks shall be constructed a minimum of five feet (5') in
width, except that sidewalks constructed or reconstructed in blocks with
existing sidewalks shall be of the same width and of the same distance from the
property line as the existing sidewalks.
      2.   The sidewalks constructed at the following locations shall be six
feet (6') in width:
Devils Glen Road, on the east side, from State Street to the north entrance to
Crow Creek Park.
Kimberly Road, on the east side, from East Locust Street to Duck Creek.
Middle Road, on the east side, from Crow Creek to Interstate Highway 80.
State Street, on the north side, from 26th Street to the west city limits of
Riverdale.
      3.   The sidewalks constructed at the following locations shall be eight
feet (8') in width:
Middle Road, on the east side, from Norwood Drive to Crow Creek.
   B.   Maintenance Responsibilities:
      1.   Where a sidewalk width is six feet (6') or less, the abutting
property owner shall be responsible for routine maintenance for the full width
of the sidewalk, including, but not limited to, snow removal.
      2.   When the sidewalk width is greater than six feet (6'), the city
shall be responsible for routine maintenance of the full width of the sidewalk,
including, but not limited to, snow removal.
      3.   When an overwidth sidewalk is ordered to be constructed by the city,
the adjacent property owner shall pay the cost of four feet (4') of the width,
with the city paying for the width above that amount, for the entire length
ordered.
   C.   Conformance With Plans And Specifications; Inspection By City: All
permanent sidewalks, driveway approaches and curb cuts shall be constructed in
accordance with the standard drawings and standard specifications of the city
in effect at the time of construction. Said standard drawings and standard
specifications shall be on file in the office of the city engineer. Portland
cement concrete or asphaltic concrete shall not be placed until the preparatory
work has been inspected and approved by an authorized representative of the
city as being in accordance with the standard drawings and standard
specifications.
   D.   Establishment Of Grade: Sidewalk grades shall be as established by city
ordinance and all grades not established by city ordinance will be set by the
city engineer or his representative.    
   E.   Slope; Authority; Appeal:
      1.   All permanent sidewalks shall be constructed at such height above
the top of the curb as may be determined by the city engineer.
      2.   The owner of any abutting property fronting on the proposed sidewalk
may, by serving a written notice to that effect upon the city engineer, appeal
from the decision of the city engineer fixing the height of the sidewalk to the
council. The city engineer shall report his acts and proceedings in the matter
and the fact of the appeal to the council, and the council shall then determine
the height above such curb at which the sidewalk shall be constructed. (2008
Code §§ 27-71 - 27-76; amd. Ord. 16-21, 9-7-2021)
7-2-7: CONTRACTORS, BOND:
Any person, firm or corporation desiring to construct sidewalks, driveway
approaches or make curb cuts on public rights of way in the city shall file
with the city clerk a surety bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) conditioned on the faithful performance of all the provisions of
this code, such surety to be a company authorized to transact business as a
surety in the state of Iowa. (2008 Code § 27-82)
7-2-8: SIDEWALK REPAIRS:
   A.   Permit Required; Filing Application; Waiver Of Bond:
      1.   A property owner shall secure a permit to make repairs to an
existing sidewalk abutting his property. Application for a permit to make
repairs to an existing sidewalk shall be made to the building inspector.
      2.   If such repairs total less than twelve (12) linear feet, the
requirement in section
7-2-7 of this chapter that a bond be secured may be waived by the building
inspector.
      3.   All repairs to sidewalks shall be protected by barricades and
warning signs. (2008 Code § 27-85)
   B.   Permit Fee: The fee for each permit for repair of sidewalk shall be per
fee schedule payable to the city of Bettendorf. (2008 Code § 27-86; amd. 2015
Code)
CHAPTER 3
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Permit Required For Certain Excavations
7-3-2: Contents Of Permit Application
7-3-3: Permit Fee; Exemptions
7-3-4: Bond Requirements
7-3-5: Safety Devices
7-3-6: Specifications Of Restoration
7-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN EXCAVATIONS:
No person, firm or corporation shall make any excavation within the right of
way of any street or alley for any purpose without first obtaining a permit
from the building inspector, except:
   A.   If an emergency exists, work may proceed immediately to protect public
safety and the person, firm or corporation responsible for such work shall
secure from the building inspector on the next working day a permit for such
work.
   B.   Employees of the city on official business shall be exempt from this
section. (2008 Code § 27-95)
7-3-2: CONTENTS OF PERMIT APPLICATION:
The application for a permit required by this chapter shall state the place and
purpose of the excavation for which the permit is sought. (2008 Code § 27-96)
7-3-3: PERMIT FEE; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Fee Amount; Franchise Holders Exempt:
      1.   The fee for each excavation permit, which permit shall be for a
single project involving continuous work requiring excavation in the right of
way of any street or alley, shall be pursuant to the fee schedule adopted from
time to time by resolution of the city council. (2008 Code § 27-99; amd. 2015
Code)
      2.   Holders of valid utility franchises which specifically exempt that
utility from a permit fee are exempt from this section. (2008 Code § 27-99)
   B.   Exception For Other Permit; Bond: No fee shall be charged for an
excavation permit if the applicant secures, at the same time and for the same
purpose of excavation another required permit; provided, however, the applicant
has on file with the clerk, a properly executed bond for the work to be
performed. (2008 Code § 27-100)
7-3-4: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Bond Required: The applicant for a permit required by this chapter
shall file with the city clerk a properly executed bond, with sureties to be
approved by the city clerk in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), conditioned for the faithful performance and observation of all
provisions of this code and other ordinances of the city relative to excavation
and further conditioned that the obligors on the bond will save harmless the
city from all damages sustained or caused by reason of the negligence of the
applicant or his agent or employee.
   B.   Business Of Making Excavations: Any person whose business requires the
making of excavations in the public streets for sewer, drain, water or other
connections may file a properly executed bond to the city clerk which shall be
sufficient to fulfill the requirements of this chapter. (2008 Code § 27-97)
7-3-5: SAFETY DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful to make any excavation in any street, alley, or other
public place or within six feet (6') of any sidewalk, street, alley or other
public place unless the excavation is secured by a substantially built
enclosure with warning lights placed and operational at night. (2008 Code § 27-
98)
7-3-6: SPECIFICATIONS OF RESTORATION:
   A.   Restoration: The excavation construction and restoration of any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public property shall be made so as to restore the
property to as good a condition as existed prior to the excavation, but shall
not be less than the standard specifications and requirements of the public
works department adopted pursuant to chapter 2 of this title.
   B.   Maintenance: All excavations shall be maintained in good and suitable
repair to the satisfaction of the public works department for three (3) years
after completion of the excavation work. (2008 Code § 27-101)
CHAPTER 4
UTILITIES FACILITIES
SECTION:
7-4-1: Technical Standards
7-4-2: Location Of Poles; Council Authority
7-4-3: Damage From Utility Poles; Liability
7-4-4: Supervisory Authority
7-4-5: Notice Of Intent To Erect Utility Poles
7-4-6: Removal Of Poles
7-4-7: Actions During Emergencies
7-4-8: Removal Of Underground Facilities
7-4-9: Costs Borne By Owner
7-4-1: TECHNICAL STANDARDS:
All electric wires and poles shall be constructed and maintained in accordance
with the provisions of the electrical code adopted in section
10-4A-1 of this code. (2008 Code § 27-109)
7-4-2: LOCATION OF POLES; COUNCIL AUTHORITY:
   A.   Utility poles shall be removed from the streets and be placed in the
alleys whenever the council shall so order by resolution.
   B.   The council shall have authority as to when and where to remove poles,
and the poles shall be so placed as not to interfere with ordinary private and
public use of any alley, street or private property.
   C.   All poles erected in any street shall be erected within the curb lines.
(2008 Code § 27-110)
7-4-3: DAMAGE FROM UTILITY POLES; LIABILITY:
Any damage to any pavement, sidewalk, water pipe, sewer or other public or
private property resulting from, or in the setting of, telephone, telegraph, or
electric poles in any of the streets, alleys or other public places shall be
paid by the company erecting them, and the city shall not be responsible for
any damages resulting therefrom. (2008 Code § 27-111)
7-4-4: SUPERVISORY AUTHORITY:
   A.   The city engineer shall have general supervision over the erection of
all telegraph, telephone, and other electric wires and the poles and supports
therefor placed in or over the streets and alleys, or along or over any public
or private grounds, and it shall be his duty to enforce the provisions of this
section. (2008 Code § 27-112)
   B.   The electrical inspector shall perform similar duties under direction
and supervision of the community development director. (2008 Code § 27-112;
amd. 2015 Code)
7-4-5: NOTICE OF INTENT TO ERECT UTILITY POLES:
Before any person, having authority to do so, shall erect any telephone,
telegraph or other utility poles in any street, alley or other public place, he
shall serve a three (3) days' notice in writing upon the city engineer, setting
forth the time, place and manner in which the poles are proposed to be erected,
and it shall be the duty of the city engineer to see that the poles are erected
in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (2008 Code § 27-113)
7-4-6: REMOVAL OF POLES:
   A.   Notice: Any utility poles opposite public or private property which
interfere with the use thereof, any poles erected in violation of the
provisions of this chapter, or any poles which need to be moved in the public
interest, shall be moved by the person owning the utility poles, upon written
notice from the city engineer, after adoption of a resolution therefor by the
council. If the notice is not complied with within twenty (20) days, the city
engineer may remove the utility poles, after giving the owner five (5) days'
written notice of his intention to do so.
   B.   Owner Responsible For Expenses: All expenses of the removal shall be
charged to the owner of the utility poles. (2008 Code § 27-114)
7-4-7: ACTIONS DURING EMERGENCIES:
   A.   In case of fire or other emergencies, utility poles, wires and street
fixtures may be cut and removed or the electrical current may be cut off by
order of the fire chief, without any liability or expense on the part of the
city or the fire chief.
   B.   If it is possible to do so, the owner or employees in charge of the
utility equipment shall be previously notified of the necessity to remove the
poles, wires and fixtures or to cut off the electrical current. (2008 Code §
27-115)
7-4-8: REMOVAL OF UNDERGROUND FACILITIES:
Any utility lines, wires, pipes, fixtures or appurtenances located in street
rights of way which interfere with construction, reconstruction or use thereof
shall be moved by the person, firm or corporation owning the lines, wires,
pipes, fixtures or appurtenances, upon written notice from the city engineer.
If the notice is not complied with within twenty (20) days, the city engineer
may remove the utility lines, wires, pipes, fixtures or appurtenances after
giving the owner five (5) days' written notice of his intention to do so. (2008
Code § 27-116)
7-4-9: COSTS BORNE BY OWNER:
The cost of the removal of any utility lines, wires, pipes, fixtures or
appurtenances which have been removed pursuant to any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be borne by the owner of such facilities. (2008 Code § 27-117)
ARTICLE A. UNDERGROUND UTILITIES
SECTION:
7-4A-1: Property Owners Responsible For Connections
7-4A-2: Location Of Connection; Number Required
7-4A-3: Notice To Property Owners; Hearing Of Objections
7-4A-4: Connections Made By City
7-4A-5: Additional Charges; Disposition Of Funds
7-4A-6: Underground Sprinklers In City Right Of Way; Easement Agreement
7-4A-1: PROPERTY OWNERS RESPONSIBLE FOR CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Responsibility For Connections: Whenever the city council orders any
street, alley, public ground or place permanently improved by paving,
graveling, macadamizing, parking, guttering or curbing, it shall be the duty of
the owners of the property abutting thereon and adjacent thereto to make the
connections from gas, water or steam heating pipes or sewer or underground
electric conduit to the curb line of the abutting or adjacent property before
the improvement is made. (2008 Code § 27-121)
   B.   Supervision: The excavations, connections, and backfilling shall be
made under the direction of the city engineer; the work shall be done according
to the specifications of the city engineer. (2008 Code § 27-121; amd. 2015
Code)
7-4A-2: LOCATION OF CONNECTION; NUMBER REQUIRED:
   A.   Connections required by this article shall be made for each sixty feet
(60') of frontage unless platting, zoning or land use plan requirements provide
for another minimum lot frontage.
   B.   A separate and independent connection to each underground utility shall
be made for each building on an interior lot; however, when no utility
(including, but not limited to, gas, water, steam heating pipes, sewer,
electricity, cable TV and telephone) can be constructed to the rear building
through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the connections to the
front building may be extended to the rear building. (2008 Code § 27-122)
7-4A-3: NOTICE TO PROPERTY OWNERS; HEARING OF OBJECTIONS:
   A.   Notice: The city council shall cause notice to be given to owners of
property abutting a proposed improvement subject to this article, by certified
mail and publication, at least thirty (30) days before connection, repair, or
relocation to underground utilities work is required to be done, notifying the
owners to make the connection, repair, or relocation or to show cause in
writing why such connections, repair, or relocation should not be made.
   B.   Objections: At the expiration of the time fixed, the council shall
consider all objections so filed and, if overruled, shall by resolution order
the making of such connections, repairs, or relocation as it deems necessary.
(2008 Code § 27-123)
7-4A-4: CONNECTIONS MADE BY CITY:
   A.   City Work; Assessment Of Costs: If the owners of the property on public
ways or grounds subject to this article fail to make the connections required
by this article in the manner and within the time fixed by the council, the
council may cause the connections to be made and assess the cost thereof
against the property for which they are made.
   B.   Nonpayment; Notify County Auditor: The clerk shall send a bill to the
owner of the property for the cost of the connections, and if the bill is not
paid within ten (10) days of the mailing of the bill, the clerk shall certify
the cost to the county auditor as a special tax against the property for which
the connections were made. (2008 Code § 27-125)
7-4A-5: ADDITIONAL CHARGES; DISPOSITION OF FUNDS:
In any case where connections required by this article are not made before
permanent public way or ground improvements are made, no permits shall be
issued for the making of the connection, except upon the payment in advance of
a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) in addition to all other fees and
charges, which fee shall be paid to the clerk and by the clerk paid to the
treasurer and credited to the fund used for keeping streets in repair. (2008
Code § 27-126)
7-4A-6: UNDERGROUND SPRINKLERS IN CITY RIGHT OF WAY; EASEMENT AGREEMENT:
In any case where a property owner wishes to install an underground lawn
watering system in the city right of way between the curb of the roadway and
the property edge, for the purpose of watering the sod located thereon, the
owner shall request an easement from the city. The easement agreement shall be
on a form approved by the city attorney. The director of public works shall be
authorized to sign the easement on behalf of the city. The fee for granting the
easement shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). The easement may be terminated on
thirty (30) days' written notice to the owner and the city shall bear no
responsibility for the installation, maintenance, and removal of the system.
(2008 Code § 27-127)
CHAPTER 5
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
7-5-1: Purpose
7-5-2: Definitions
7-5-3: Enforcement Powers
7-5-4: Permit Requirements
7-5-5: Bettendorf Landscape Handbook
7-5-6: Permitted Trees And Shrubs
7-5-7: Tree Maintenance Responsibility
7-5-8: Protection Of Trees On Public Property And Rights Of Way
7-5-9: Appeals
7-5-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the regulation of the planting,
maintenance, and removal of trees, shrubs, and other plants on public ground
and public rights of way, and thereby to promote the public health, safety and
general welfare. (2008 Code § 29-1)
7-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
BOULEVARD: That part of public right of way not covered by paving or hard
surface, lying between the property line and that portion of the street
normally used for vehicular traffic.
CROWN: The mass of vegetative growth from the tree trunk.
DRIP ZONE: The entire area on the ground within the outer perimeter of the
crown of the tree projected vertically to the ground.
PERMITTING AUTHORITY: Unless otherwise noted, the permitting authority shall be
the director of parks and recreation or the director's designee.
PLANTING MEDIANS: The area of right of way, not covered by paving or other hard
surface and lying between the paved lanes for vehicle traffic.
SHRUB: A woody plant not classified as a tree.
TREE: Plants which have the capacity to grow to a mature size of at least four
inches (4") diameter (measured 4.5 feet above ground level) and twenty feet
(20') in height. Trees shall also include those plants classified as trees in
the 1976 or later version of "Hortus Third: A Concise Dictionary Of Plants
Cultivated In The United States And Canada".
TREE TOPPING: A severe cutting back of limbs to stubs rather than to lateral
branches within the tree so as to remove the normal crown. (2008 Code § 29-3)
7-5-3: ENFORCEMENT POWERS:
The city code enforcement officer or his designee shall have the power to
enforce this chapter. Such powers shall include:
   A.   The power to require any person to prune, maintain or remove trees,
plants, or shrubs from any property when those plantings interfere with the
ability of the public, city departments, or franchised utility to use public
property or rights of way.
   B.   The power to require abutting property owners to maintain trees,
plants, or shrubs between the property line and the driving surface of rights
of way. (2008 Code § 29-2)
7-5-4: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Application:
      1.   No person shall plant any tree on public property, including
boulevards, without first procuring a permit.
      2.   The application for permit shall include a drawing showing the
location of all utilities and their proximity to the planting, as well as the
location of the proposed planting, and the species of tree to be planted.
   B.   Approval Required:
      1.   Permits shall be requested from the parks and recreation department,
and shall require approval of the parks and recreation director prior to
issuance.
      2.   Permits will be reviewed by any other appropriate departments prior
to approval.
      3.   Alternatively, a permit shall be deemed given for any development
which is constructed in conformance with a council approved site and
landscaping plan.
   C.   Reasons For Denial: No permit shall be granted if:
      1.   The location of the planting is inappropriate under this chapter.
      2.   The tree is not of a kind approved in the "Bettendorf Landscape
Handbook".
      3.   The planting may interfere with the operation of a city or a
franchised utility. (2008 Code § 29-4)
7-5-5: BETTENDORF LANDSCAPE HANDBOOK:
The city council shall approve, by resolution, a "Bettendorf Landscape
Handbook", which shall list trees which may hereafter be planted within the
city. The handbook shall be reviewed and amended from time to time. The latest
approved version shall be the appropriate reference volume for this chapter.
(2008 Code § 29-5)
7-5-6: PERMITTED TREES AND SHRUBS:
   A.   Planting Restrictions: Any tree or shrub which is otherwise permitted
may not be planted:
      1.   In a boulevard which is less than seven feet (7') wide.
      2.   Within four feet (4') of the curb line.
      3.   Within thirty five feet (35') from the curb of the intersection of
two (2) streets.
      4.   Within twenty feet (20') of a driveway or alley.
   B.   Spacing:
      1.   Tree spacing should be established in the "Bettendorf Landscape
Handbook".
      2.   The permitting authority may grant distance reductions upon a
showing that the public health and safety is enhanced.
   C.   Backfill Soil: During planting, backfill soil shall be substantially
free of rocks and other construction debris. (2008 Code § 29-6)
7-5-7: TREE MAINTENANCE RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Tree Topping: Tree topping shall not be allowed on any tree on public
property.
   B.   Pruning: The abutting property owner shall be responsible for
maintenance of trees and shrubbery between the back of the curb and the
property line. Such care shall include, but not be limited to, pruning to:
      1.   Allow free passage of pedestrian and vehicle traffic.
      2.   Attain a branch clearance of eight feet (8') over sidewalks.
      3.   Attain a ground clearance of fifteen feet (15') over streets and
alleys.
      4.   Eliminate interference with the light from a streetlight or traffic
light; or visibility of any traffic control device.
   C.   Failure Of Property Owner To Maintain: If the abutting owner fails to
perform the maintenance work as detailed in subsection B of this section, the
code enforcement officer or designee shall contract to have the work done and
shall assess the cost of the maintenance against the property in the manner
provided by law.
   D.   Order To Remove Dead, Decayed Or Broken Limbs: The code enforcement
officer or designee shall order the property owner to remove any dead, decayed,
or broken limb or branch from privately owned property when such tree or any
portion of it constitutes a hazard to the public's use of streets, parks, or
other right of way, or harbors insects or disease which constitutes a potential
threat to other trees within the city. (2008 Code § 29-7)
7-5-8: PROTECTION OF TREES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY AND RIGHTS OF WAY:
   A.   All construction will be done in such a way as to minimize damage to
any tree, including the root system.
   B.   No person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, attach any rope,
wire, electric wires, or cables, insulators, nails, advertising posters, or
other contrivance to any tree; allow any gaseous liquid, chemical, or solid
substance that is harmful to such trees to come in contact with them; or set
fire or permit fire to burn when such fire or heat will injure any portion of
any tree.
   C.   No person shall remove, injure, or misuse any guard or device placed to
protect any tree, plant, or shrub growing in any street or public right of way.
   D.   During construction activity, protective plastic barrier fencing or
snow fence shall be erected to protect trees and their drip zones in the
construction area. The fencing will be installed five feet (5') outside the
perimeter of the tree drip zone prior to construction and not removed until
after final cleanup of the construction site.
   E.   At no time shall any construction or personal vehicles park or operate
within five feet (5') of the drip zone of any tree without measures in place to
protect the tree. Protective measures may include fencing, mulching to a
minimum depth of one foot (1') of mulch, planking or cribbing.
   F.   The surface of any unpaved area within five feet (5') of the drip zone
of any tree shall not be used for the storage of any materials.
   G.   At no time shall chemicals, rinsates, or petroleum products be disposed
of on the construction site.
   H.   Ditches or trenches shall not be excavated or laid within five feet
(5') of any drip zone of any tree.
   I.   To preserve viable root systems and maintain structural stability of a
tree, all underground utility placement or replacement shall be done by boring
or tunneling beneath the root systems of the tree.
   J.   The boulevard will not, to the extent possible, be cut into or
disturbed in any way within five feet (5') of any tree's drip zone. This
includes creating setbacks for the new curb and gutter, accommodating slip form
pavers, reducing the height of the boulevard, or, when an alternative exists,
trenching or digging for utilities.
   K.   Curb and gutter replacement adjacent to street trees can be made with
slip form pavers only if the pavers can be accommodated without additional
alterations to the existing boulevard. Where sufficient room does not exist,
the area will be poured using hand set steel forms. Expansion joints or
masonite may be necessary for forming around trees where conventional forms
will not fit.
   L.   If a root must be cut or a damaged root pruned, a clean cut behind the
damaged portion should be used.
   M.   Where sidewalk replacement is necessary, care should be taken to avoid
any injury to the tree's root system. Surface roots may be cut making clean
pruning cuts to a minimum depth below the finished grade of the new walk. The
root system should be cut no further than five inches (5") away from the edge
of the proposed new walk to accommodate its forms.
   N.   At no time shall the boulevard grade be changed by removing soil or
through the addition of soil within five feet (5') of any tree's drip zone.
   O.   Exceptions to any of the aforementioned terms in this section may be
granted only upon sufficient justification and the approval of the permitting
authority. (2008 Code § 29-8)
7-5-9: APPEALS:
Any order issued pursuant to this chapter may be appealed to the city council
within ten (10) days of receipt by providing a written request to appeal to the
city clerk. At the next regularly scheduled council meeting, the council shall
consider the matter and vote to affirm, modify, or revise the order. The
council's decision shall be final. (2008 Code § 29-9)
CHAPTER 6
PARKS AND RECREATION
SECTION:
7-6-1: City Council Waivers
7-6-2: Certain Acts Prohibited Without Permission
7-6-3: Rules For Trail Use In Quad Cities
7-6-4: Leach Park And Eagle's Landing Park And Boat Launch
7-6-5: Park Rules Generally
7-6-6: Splash Landing Family Aquatic Center
7-6-7: Consumption Of Alcoholic Beverages
7-6-8: Crow Creek Park; Rules For Enclosed Dog Park
7-6-1: CITY COUNCIL WAIVERS:
The City Council may waive rules otherwise applicable to the parks or
recreation trails for special events, when such waiver is by resolution of the
City Council, and the program leader for the special event keeps a copy of the
resolution available for display to any police officer requesting same. (2008
Code § 20-9; amd. 2015 Code; Ord. 05-21, 3-16-2021)
7-6-2: CERTAIN ACTS PROHIBITED WITHOUT PERMISSION:
   A.   Approval Required: No person shall swim, wade, boat, or use any type of
flotation device in the quarry located in Crow Creek Park, the lake in
McLamarrah Park, the lagoon in Middle Park, or the creek in Palmer Hills Golf
Course, except when approved by the director of parks and recreation or the
director's designee. (2008 Code § 20-2)
   B.   Permission In Writing: Permission must be in writing and kept with the
permittee and shown to any park and recreation department employee or peace
officer upon request. (2008 Code § 20-2; amd. 2015 Code)
7-6-3: RULES FOR TRAIL USE IN QUAD CITIES:
   A.   Purpose And Intent:
      1.   The trail system is intended for the activities of individuals and
permitted groups for recreation, transportation, fitness and other similar
purposes using human powered propulsion. Activities using powered equipment are
to be permitted by the unit of government given authority to issue permits.
Individuals with disabilities are allowed to use ADA compliant power assisted
devices intended for personal transport on trails.
      2.   The intent of this section is to establish consistent rules and
regulations for trail use. The rules set forth herein are a supplement to any
existing state vehicle codes or other applicable federal, state, or local rules
and regulations pertaining to trail use.
      3.   The rules set out in this section will apply to all persons using
the recreation trails within the city limits.
   B.   Trail: "Trail", for the purposes of this section, is a multiuse trail,
side path or shared use path defined by the American Association Of State
Highway And Transportation Officials (AASHTO) as a bikeway physically separated
from motorized vehicular traffic by an open space or barrier and either within
the highway right of way or on other public property or within an easement
dedicated for public use. These facilities may also be used by pedestrians,
skaters, wheelchair users, joggers, and other nonmotorized users.
   C.   Compliant Vehicles: Compliant vehicles are human powered devices no
wider than four feet (4') with the exception of equipment approved by the
governing agency for use to maintain the trail, provide for public safety, or
specially permitted for use by the governing agency responsible for the trail.
   D.   General Guidelines: Trails may be established for the purposes of
recreation, transportation, fitness and other similar purposes. They are
intended for human powered activities including, but not limited to, walking
and running; the use of devices such as bicycles, skates, skateboards, skis and
other similar activities; and recognized disability equipment for persons with
disabilities.
   E.   Trail System: There is hereby established in the city a trail system in
the lands, public parks, and/or rights of way heretofore designated or set
apart by the city for use as trails.
   F.   Rules; Restrictions: Users of the trail shall not:
      1.   Travel at a rate of speed that is greater than reasonable and
prudent.
      2.   Use the trail in a negligent manner that is likely to endanger
persons or property. Trail users shall use common courtesy and respect the
rights and safety of others. The applicable state regulations regarding the
equipment required to allow the safe operation of bicycles and other wheeled
vehicles during the time of the day when natural light is diminished shall be
applied to the trails subject to this section.
      3.   Use the trail under the influence of alcohol or other controlled
substances.
      4.   Walk any animal unless on a leash no longer than six feet (6') and
with the owner in complete physical control at all times.
      5.   Litter, leave animal waste, or discard any other items along or near
the trail.
      6.   Operate any vehicle other than a compliant vehicle as defined in
subsection C of this section. (2008 Code § 20-3; amd. 2015 Code)
7-6-4: LEACH PARK AND EAGLE'S LANDING PARK AND BOAT LAUNCH:
The following rules will apply to all persons using Leach Park and Eagle's
Landing Park and boat launch:
   A.   No operator of any boat or other watercraft shall operate in the boat
launching basin or near the boat launching ramps unless docking, launching, or
loading the craft.
   B.   No person shall operate any vehicle in a careless manner, or indulge in
waterskiing in the proximity of docking or launching areas.
   C.   No person shall wash any vehicle in the parking lot or launching areas,
although wiping of boats in authorized parking spaces after they are removed
from the water is permissible.
   D.   No person shall swim or wade in the Mississippi River adjacent to Leach
Park or Eagle's Landing Park and boat launch unless in conjunction with the
launching or docking of a boat or personal watercraft.
   E.   No person shall leave a vehicle or boat on Leach Park grounds or
Eagle's Landing Park and boat launch grounds with the purpose of displaying
such vehicle or boat for sale. No person shall leave a boat moored to the Leach
Park property or Eagle's Landing Park and boat launch property overnight.
   F.   No person shall fish from the docks (except at the Crow Creek Park
quarry) or launch area of the parks, or clean fish in any area of the parks.
   G.   No person shall park a vehicle and boat trailer at any place signed "No
Parking", except to launch or land boats. Vehicles with boat trailers are only
allowed to park in areas designated for trailer parking.
   H.   After the boat is launched or loaded, the vehicle or trailer carrying
the boat shall be moved from the launch area so that others may use the
facility. No boat cleanup shall be allowed at the dock or ramp. Personal
watercraft (i.e., jet skis, etc.) shall be allowed to dock only at the dock
designated for those watercraft. (2008 Code § 20-4)
7-6-5: PARK RULES GENERALLY:
The following rules shall apply to all parks and public grounds within the
city:
   A.   Motor vehicles (including, but not limited to, snowmobiles, minibikes,
motorized skateboards, motorbikes, motorcycles, all-terrain vehicles (ATVs),
cars, or trucks) shall not be operated on separated trails, bicycle paths,
fitness trails, jogging paths, or park grounds, except park roads and parking
lots. The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to park and recreation
department or public safety vehicles, or any other vehicles authorized by the
parks and recreation director, chief of police or his or her designee.
   B.   No motor vehicle may be parked in areas of a park or City Council
facility except in designated parking lots or areas. Any vehicle parked at any
location other than a designated parking lot or area or any vehicle left in a
city park after the park closes may be ticketed or towed, and the costs of the
tow and storage shall be paid by the owner prior to the vehicle's release. The
director of parks and recreation or the director's designee may approve
temporary parking areas for special events or programs with such areas signed
where approval is given.
   C.   No person shall fly, operate, use, or control any power driven model
aircraft except when authorized by the director of parks and recreation or the
director's designee with such permission to be in writing kept by the permittee
and shown to any park and recreation department employee or peace officer upon
request.
   D.   No person shall ride any horse, mule, or any animal in any park area
unless permission is granted by the director of parks and recreation or the
director's designee with such permission to be in writing kept by the permittee
and shown to any park and recreation department employee or peace officer upon
request.
   E.   No bicycle shall be ridden or parked by any person within the safety
surface area of any playground.
   F.   No person shall damage, destroy, deface, remove any signage or
equipment, building, structure, tree, vegetation, or machine owned by or under
the control of the park and recreation board.
   G.   No person shall camp, golf (except at Palmer Hills Golf Course and only
upon paying the fee therefor), trap wild animals, fish (except at Leach Park,
Eagle's Landing Park and boat launch, the Crow Creek Park quarry, and at Middle
Park lagoon), or boat (except at Leach Park and Eagle's Landing Park and boat
launch) at any park in the city, unless authorized by the director of parks and
recreation, or the director's designee, and a letter authorizing the action is
carried with the person and made readily available to any park and recreation
department employee or peace officer upon request. Fishing at the designated
areas is permissible only if the appropriate licenses are in the possession of
the participants. Ice fishing is prohibited in any park area. Swimming is
allowed only at Splash Landing and the Life Fitness Center.
   H.   No person shall throw or deposit on any park or public ground any glass
bottles, glass, nails, tacks, wires, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter, or
any other debris or any substance likely to injure any person, animal, or
vehicle, except when placed in the appropriate refuse containers located in the
park.
   I.   All parks, with the exception of Palmer Hills Golf Course and Ed Scheck
Park, shall close at ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. each day, and shall reopen
at sunrise unless an activity is a regularly scheduled activity or otherwise
approved of by the director of parks and recreation or the director's designee
with such permission to be in writing, kept by the permittee, and shown to any
park and recreation department employee or peace officer upon request. Palmer
Hills Golf Course shall be open at such time as will allow persons to golf or
use the driving range. Ed Scheck Park shall close at ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
When closed, no person shall remain on park grounds.
   J.   The maximum speed limit for vehicles in city parks shall be fifteen
(15) miles per hour and such limit shall be posted at each park entrance.
   K.   No person shall operate, land, or launch a hot air balloon, airplane,
glider, hang glider, or helicopter, except if authorized by the director of
parks and recreation, or the director's designee with such permission to be in
writing, kept by the permittee, and shown to any park and recreation department
employee or peace officer upon request.
   L.   No person shall hunt, pursue, or take any wild animal, bird, or game,
and no one shall carry firearms, air guns, or bow and arrows unless authorized
by the police chief or the director of parks and recreation, or their
respective designees.
   M.   No person shall ice skate in any park (except at the Middle Park lagoon
when indicated by the green light).
   N.   No person shall place in any trash receptacle, or on any public
property, "yard waste" as defined elsewhere in this code.
   O.   No person shall, upon or in connection with any property of the park
and recreation department:
      1.   Set fire, or cause to be set on fire, any tree, forest, brushland,
grassland, meadow, prairie, marsh, refuse, container, or structure, unless
authorized by the director of parks and recreation, or the director's designee.
      2.   Build a fire anywhere, for any purpose, except in appropriate
receptacles.
      3.   Drop, throw away, or scatter any burning, lighted or hot coals,
ashes, cigarette, cigar, firecracker, or match.
      4.   Build any fire whatsoever, for any purpose in a receptacle or
fireplace and thereafter leave it unattended, unless such fire is properly
extinguished. For the purpose of this subsection, a fire shall be deemed
properly extinguished when its ashes, residue, coals, and unburned substances
are cold to the human touch.
   P.   No person shall reserve or use a park facility for a "special event"
(refer to the special event policy for guidelines) without appropriate
insurance coverage. The applicant shall provide a certificate of general
liability insurance, naming the city of Bettendorf as an additional named
insured (and not as a certificate holder) in an amount of three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence. If the
applicant is an organization, and not a private individual, the insurance
amount shall be no less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). (See
section
7-6-7, "Consumption Of Alcoholic Beverages", of this chapter for further
requirements that apply to alcohol use.)
   Q.   1. Pursuant to section
2-8-10 of this code, any full time park and recreation department management
staff member, or their designee, has the authority to suspend any patron from
participating in any park and recreation department activity or usage of any
park and recreation department facility for a period of up to seven (7) days,
provided any suspension beyond twenty four (24) hours must be approved by the
director of parks and recreation or the director's designee. Such approval may
be given either before or after the suspension is ordered.
      2.   The director of parks and recreation or the director's designee may
order the suspension of any individual's use of a facility or participation in
a program of the park and recreation department for a time not to exceed one
year.
      3.   Suspension in excess of a year may only be ordered by the park and
recreation board. (2008 Code § 20-5; amd. 2015 Code; Ord. 05-21, 3-16-2021)
7-6-6: SPLASH LANDING FAMILY AQUATIC CENTER:
The following rules shall apply to the Splash Landing Family Aquatic Center.
All patrons shall observe the posted pool rules and regulations at the Splash
Landing Family Aquatic Center, and specifically:
   A.   Maximum occupancy shall be as set by the Scott County health department
and the city fire chief. When occupancy limit is reached, no other person may
be admitted until the number of patrons using the facility is reduced.
   B.   No bicycles, skateboards, or motorbikes shall be operated on the paved
area surrounding the pool, except for peace officers or other authorized city
personnel.
   C.   No person shall obstruct the passage of pedestrians on the paved area
surrounding the pool.
   D.   No person may bring food, drink, or cigars/cigarettes into the fenced
swimming pool area.
   E.   Inside the fenced pool area, no person shall engage in fighting,
dunking, or other conduct likely to be dangerous to the other patrons. No
person shall harass or distract the lifeguards from their duties. (2008 Code §
20-6)
   F.   No child under the age of eleven (11) will be admitted unless
accompanied by a parent, guardian, or person over the age of sixteen (16)
designated by the parent or guardian to watch over and be responsible for the
child while at the pool area when permission is given by the pool management
staff. (2008 Code § 20-6; amd. 2015 Code)
   G.   No person shall remain in the fenced pool deck area unless having
showered and changed into pool attire. Street clothes will be allowed in
designated areas only.
   H.   No person shall use a pass not assigned to that person. Any person
found violating this subsection may have the pass revoked and will be required
to leave the pool. (2008 Code § 20-6)
7-6-7: CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
The following rules shall apply to the consumption of alcoholic beverages:
   A.   Palmer Hills Golf Course: No person shall consume alcoholic beverages
on Palmer Hills Golf Course unless the beverage is purchased from the liquor
license holder located thereon, unless a one hundred dollar ($100.00) beverage
consumption fee is paid therefor.
   B.   Where Permitted: Public use and consumption of beer in cans only is
authorized only in the following parks:
      1.   Crow Creek Park, within one hundred feet (100') of any reservable
shelter.
      2.   Middle Park, within one hundred feet (100') of the Middle Park
lagoon shelter.
      3.   Veterans Memorial Park, within one hundred feet (100') of the
bandshell shelter.
      4.   Devils Glen Park, within one hundred feet (100') of any reservable
shelter.
      5.   At such additional locations as may be approved by the park and
recreation board by resolution.
   C.   Special Event Approval: Special event approval is not required for use
or possession of any can of beer under the capacity of forty one (41) ounces.
If distributing to others (gifting, not selling) a certificate, naming the city
of Bettendorf as an additional named insured (and not as a certificate holder),
verifying host liquor coverage in an amount not less than three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per occurrence, must be provided. If the
applicant is distributing alcohol to others (selling, not gifting), the
applicant shall provide, as defined in state law and regulation, dramshop
coverage in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
   D.   Kegs: No person shall be allowed to possess a keg or kegs of beer in
the parks without completing the following items:
      1.   Provide a special event application to and obtain approval by the
City Council at their monthly meeting.
      2.   Provide a minimum one hundred dollar ($100.00) refundable deposit.
   E.   City Council Ground: Except as otherwise authorized in this section, no
consumption of any alcohol or alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on any
ground owned or controlled by the Bettendorf City Council. (2008 Code § 20-7;
amd. 2015 Code; Ord. 05-21, 3-16-2021)
7-6-8: CROW CREEK PARK; RULES FOR ENCLOSED DOG PARK:
   A.   The dog park is open daily from dawn until ten thirty o'clock (10:30)
P.M. unless closed for maintenance. (2008 Code § 20-8; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Sports activities, dog training, and business uses are prohibited
unless authorized by the director of parks and recreation.
   C.   Dogs must be in view and under the control of their handlers at all
times. All handlers must be at least sixteen (16) years of age. Each handler
must have a leash in hand at all times.
   D.   No more than two (2) dogs per handler are permitted in the park on any
one visit. Dogs cannot be left alone in the dog park.
   E.   Dogs must wear collars with current vaccination tags and city dog
licenses attached. (Dog licenses are available at city hall, 1609 State Street,
Bettendorf.)
   F.   Puppies under five (5) months of age and female dogs in heat are
prohibited from the park.
   G.   Owners are required to pick up and dispose of their dog's waste.
   H.   Dogs must be on a leash when they are outside of the dog park.
   I.   Remove or reattach leashes while the dog is in the staging area. Do not
enter the play area with the dog on leash.
   J.   Children under four feet (4') in height are not permitted in the dog
park. Children under sixteen (16) years of age must be closely supervised by an
adult.
   K.   Dogs that consistently exhibit dominant aggressive behavior, dogs that
regularly do not come when called, dogs that play too roughly, and dogs that
cannot control their barking must be removed from the park immediately and
without debate. Owners are required to stop their dog from digging and are
responsible for filling any holes their pet creates.
   L.   Smoking is not allowed in the dog park. (Tobacco products are hazardous
to canine health.)
   M.   The following items are not allowed in the dog park:
      1.   Bicycles, skates, rollerblades, skateboards.
      2.   Strollers, baby carriages.
      3.   Children's toys.
      4.   Dog treats and rawhides.
      5.   Food (dog and human).
      6.   Glass bottles.
      7.   Prong or spike collars.
   N.   Water must be furnished outside the dog park, and owners bringing pet
toys must take them when they leave. (2008 Code § 20-8)
CHAPTER 7
SCHOOL GROUNDS
SECTION:
7-7-1: Definitions
7-7-2: Uses Prohibited
7-7-3: Operation Of Motor Vehicles
7-7-4: Damage To School Property
7-7-5: Animals
7-7-6: Litter
7-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the terms used herein are defined as follows:
MOTOR VEHICLE: Automobiles, buses, trucks, recreational vehicles, snowmobiles,
minibikes, motorized skateboards, motorbikes, motorcycles, all-terrain vehicles
and any other self-propelled motorized conveyance, but not including public
safety vehicles or school district maintenance vehicles.
SCHOOL GROUNDS: All property owned by the Bettendorf community school district
and the Pleasant Valley community school district, located within the corporate
limits of the city, whether the property is used for school purposes or not.
(2008 Code § 26.5-1)
7-7-2: USES PROHIBITED:
Unless in conjunction with an authorized school activity, no person shall enter
or remain upon school grounds to:
   A.   Fly, operate, use or control any power driven model aircraft.
   B.   Ride a horse.
   C.   Shoot any airgun, firearm or bow and arrow.
   D.   Camp, golf or trap animals.
   E.   Operate, take off or land a hot air balloon, airplane, glider or hang
glider.
   F.   Perform an activity after sundown or before sunrise without
authorization or supervision by school officials. (2008 Code § 26.5-2)
7-7-3: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
Unless otherwise posted, all motor vehicles shall remain on roadways and
parking areas. No motor vehicle shall be operated on school grounds at a speed
in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. (2008 Code § 26.5-3)
7-7-4: DAMAGE TO SCHOOL PROPERTY:
No person shall change, deface, remove or alter any equipment, building,
structure, tree or other vegetation located on school grounds. (2008 Code §
26.5-4)
7-7-5: ANIMALS:
No person shall bring or allow an animal owned or controlled by such person on
school grounds without a leash not exceeding six feet (6') in length attached
to the animal and held by such person at all times while the animal is on
school grounds. (2008 Code § 26.5-5)
7-7-6: LITTER:
No person shall place on school grounds any glass bottles, nails, tacks, wires,
trash, rubbish, litter or any other debris or substance likely to injure person
or property. (2008 Code § 26.5-6)
CHAPTER 8
RAILROADS
SECTION:
7-8-1: Obstructing Railroads
7-8-2: Climbing On Cars, Locomotives
7-8-3: Speed Regulated At Certain Crossings
7-8-4: When Use Of Bell Required; Slowing
7-8-5: Switching Without Locomotive Attached
7-8-6: Watchman Used When Cars Moved Ahead Of Locomotive
7-8-1: OBSTRUCTING RAILROADS:
It shall be unlawful to obstruct the operation of any railroad or interfere
therewith by placing any stick, stone, or obstacle upon the tracks or rails.
(2008 Code § 26-1)
7-8-2: CLIMBING ON CARS, LOCOMOTIVES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to get on or off the cars of any railway with the
intent to annoy or interfere with the persons in charge of said cars.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to get upon or off a locomotive, engine or car of
any railroad company while the same is in motion, unless employed thereon or an
officer of the law in the discharge of his duty. (2008 Code § 26-2)
7-8-3: SPEED REGULATED AT CERTAIN CROSSINGS:
It shall be unlawful for any conductor, engineer or other person to run or move
any locomotive or car over the crossings of any railroad track where they
intersect with 36th, 33rd, 31st, 26th, 17th, and 12th Streets in the city at a
speed greater than twenty (20) miles per hour. (2008 Code § 26-3)
7-8-4: WHEN USE OF BELL REQUIRED; SLOWING:
It shall be the duty of the engineer having charge of any locomotive to cause
the engine bell to be rung upon the approach of the locomotive to any street
crossing or whenever any person or animal is upon the railroad track at such
crossing and, if necessary to avoid danger, to slacken the speed of the
locomotive. (2008 Code § 26-4)
7-8-5: SWITCHING WITHOUT LOCOMOTIVE ATTACHED:
It shall be unlawful for any conductor, engineer or other person to make flying
switches over any street or to move any car or cars over any street without
having an engine attached thereto. (2008 Code § 26-6)
7-8-6: WATCHMAN USED WHEN CARS MOVED AHEAD OF LOCOMOTIVE:
It shall be unlawful for any conductor, engineer or other person to move any
car or cars over any street when the car or cars are moving ahead of the
engine, unless some employee of the railroad company is stationed at such
crossing to give warning of the approach of the car or cars. (2008 Code § 26-7)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC UTILITIES AND SERVICES
CHAPTER 1
WATER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Water Well Construction Permit
8-1-2: Broken Water Line; Property Owner To Repair
8-1-3: Use Of Hydrants
8-1-4: Abandonment Of Water Service Line
8-1-1: WATER WELL CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
Permit Required: No person shall drill or construct a drinking water or
nondrinking water well for use within the following described areas in
Bettendorf, Iowa, unless a permit has been issued by the Scott County health
department: The area known as "1837 State Street, LUST #8LTL71, UST
registration #9017085, within 1,000 feet (MW-3)", the area known as "1740 State
Street, LUST # 9LTB51, UST registration # 198600808, within 1,000 feet (MW-5)”
and the area known as "1101 Devils Glen Road, LUST #8LTB06, UST registration
#198912210, within 1,000 feet (MW-16)”. (Ord. 20-22, 10-18-2022; amd. Ord. 19-
24, 9-3-2024; Ord. 23-24, 11-19-2024)
8-1-2: BROKEN WATER LINE; PROPERTY OWNER TO REPAIR:
   A.   Owner To Repair: It shall be the duty of any property owner to repair a
broken water service line up to and including the tap or intersecting fitting;
this does not apply to public water supply mains.
   B.   Repair By City; Assessment Of Cost: In the event that a water service
line is not repaired within a reasonable length of time, to be determined by
the administrative authority, the city may repair same and assess the actual
cost thereof against the property. (2008 Code § 31-1)
8-1-3: USE OF HYDRANTS:
Hydrants may be opened by a member of the fire department in the case of fire
or for other fire department purposes. The city may designate other employees
who may also be permitted to open hydrants in accordance with the rules of the
utility supplying the water. (2008 Code § 31-12)
8-1-4: ABANDONMENT OF WATER SERVICE LINE:
A water service line shall be abandoned at its connection to the public water
supply main. (2008 Code § 31-13)
CHAPTER 2
SEWER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-2-1: General Provisions
8-2-2: Abbreviations
8-2-3: Definitions
8-2-4: Administration
8-2-5: Powers And Authority Of Inspection
8-2-6: Comprehensive Sewer Service Charges - Enumerated
8-2-7: Sewer Utility Rates
8-2-8: Service Charge Billing; Delinquencies; Collections
8-2-9: Sewer Connection Fees; Disposition Of Funds
8-2-10: Confidentiality Of Information
8-2-11: Use Of Public Sewers Required
8-2-12: Broken Sewer Line; Property Owner To Repair
8-2-13: Prohibited Acts
8-2-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   General Adoption: The provisions of this chapter are enacted to aid in
the enforcement of the pretreatment regulations set forth herein and may be
placed in a separate portion of the municipal code of any Joint Contract
Sewerage Committee (JCSC) constituent community. Each Joint Contract Sewerage
Committee (JCSC) constituent community designates the City of Davenport as the
enforcement agency under this chapter. Employees, agents and officers of the
City of Davenport while acting to enforce the provisions of this chapter for
the Joint Contract Sewerage Committee are empowered to make such inspections,
issue such orders or permits and take such actions within the boundaries of the
JCSC as are authorized by this chapter.
   No unauthorized person shall in any manner break, damage, destroy, or tamper
with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment, which is part of the wastewater
facilities or the public sanitary sewer system.
   B.   Intent And Construction: This chapter seeks to implement provisions of
the Act, the General Pretreatment Regulations, and the Iowa Administrative
Code, Chapter 567, Sections 62.4 and 62.8. This chapter is to be construed and
applied in accordance with the Clean Water Act Amendments, the General
Pretreatment Regulations, the Iowa Administrative Code and the purpose and
policy provision set forth in subsection C below.
   C.   Purpose And Policy: This chapter regulates the use of sewers, private
wastewater disposal, the installation and connection of building sewers, the
discharge of water and waste into the sewers and drains of the JCSC system, the
discharge of water and waste into the sewers and drains of the Bettendorf
Sewage System systems, and the discharge to the Davenport JCSC POTW. This
chapter sets forth uniform requirements for dischargers into the wastewater
collection and treatment systems of Bettendorf and the JCSC constituents.
   The objectives of this chapter are:
      1.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that may
interfere with the operation of the system or interfere with sludge management
and disposal;
      2.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that may
pass through the system inadequately treated and ultimately into receiving
water, the atmosphere, or otherwise be incompatible with the system;
      3.   To protect workers' safety and health and to protect against damage
to the POTW;
      4.   To provide for equitable distribution of treatment and industrial
pretreatment costs resulting from pollutants introduced into the POTW.
      5.   To enable the POTW to comply with its NPDES permit conditions,
sludge use and disposal requirements, and any other Federal or State laws to
which the POTW is subject.
   D.   Jurisdiction: The provisions of this chapter are applicable in their
entirety to all users and contributors of wastewater, directly or indirectly,
into the wastewater treatment works of the City of Davenport or into the
wastewater collection and treatment system of the City of Bettendorf or the
JCSC without regard to whether the physical facilities of such contributors, or
the physical portion of the wastewater collection system is situated within or
outside the corporate limits of the City of Bettendorf.
   Unless otherwise expressly provided by contract providing for extension of
service by the City outside of the City, such City extended services and each
