      6.   Landscape and Screening Requirements: Landscape requirements for
off-street parking facilities are set forth in
Chapter 12 of this title.
      7.   Entrances and Exits:
         a.   Adequate access to each parking facility shall be provided by
means of clearly defined and limited driveways or access points. Such driveways
shall be designed to direct non-residential traffic away from residential
areas.
         b.   Parking facilities other than driveways for single-family,
duplex, two-family, or mobile home residential uses must permit vehicles to
enter streets in a forward position.
         c.   Head-in parking from any public right-of-way shall be permitted
only in the CBD district, or as part of a specific planned unit development
design.
      8.   Design And Pedestrian Access:
         a.   To reduce the visual impact of large parking lots, such lots
should be divided into smaller parking fields. Divisions should be made with
landscape strips, peninsulas, or grade changes.
         b.   Sidewalks and walkways in commercial developments should link to
the city's sidewalk and trail system where available, and shall provide for
pedestrian accessibility from adjacent public sidewalks and trails.
   K.   All open or unused areas shall be landscaped and continuously
maintained. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017)
11-13-7: SCHEDULE OF OFF-STREET PARKING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Parking facilities for each use shall be provided in accordance with
the minimum requirements set forth in Tables
11-13-7B1,
B2, and
B3 in this section, except as follows.
      1.   Interim/Temporary Uses. The City Administrator shall have the
authority to waive or modify the requirements contained in Chapter 11-13, Off
Street Parking and Loading for interim/temporary uses anywhere within the city,
so long as such use does not last more than 30 days. It shall be the duty of
the property owner or tenant proposing such a use to request in writing a
waiver or modification, at least 30 days prior to the use occurring. Requests
shall be directed to the Community Development Director.
      2.   Modifications and Waivers to Off-Street Parking Requirements in the
Downtown Masterplan Overlay District. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall
review and recommend to the City Council and the City Council may approve by
formal action to waive or modify the requirements specified in Chapter 11-13,
Off Street Parking and Loading for specific developments within the Downtown
Master Plan Overlay District upon approval of a parking plan that is consistent
with the intent of this chapter and when strict application of the code would
result in unnecessary hardship. The developer must submit a parking plan to the
Community Development Director that include provisions for:
         a.   Improved parking meeting all City design requirements meeting at
least fifty percent (50%) of the required parking.
         b.   User safety, including lighting and site security.
         c.   The required number of ADA parking stalls per Code.
         d.   Adequate site drainage.
         e.   Safe vehicle access to and egress from the parking lot.
         f.   A parking operations plan including methods to eliminate any
impacts to adjacent or nearby properties.
   B.   Computation:
      1.   When units of measurement result in the requirement of a fractional
space, any fraction shall require one parking space.
      2.   Unless otherwise indicated, parking requirements are based on gross
floor area. For parking calculation purposes, the gross floor area of a
building designed for tenant or owner occupancy and exclusive use, including
basements, mezzanines, and upper floors, if any, is expressed in square feet
measured from the centerlines of joint partitions and exteriors of outside
walls. It shall not include areas used principally for utilities and space
incidental to the management or maintenance of the building.
      3.   Dwelling Unit: A "dwelling unit" shall mean one room or a suite of
two (2) or more rooms, designed for or used by one family for living and
sleeping purposes and having only one kitchen or kitchenette.
      4.   Seat Or Bench: A seat shall be the space intended for one
individual. In places where patrons or spectators occupy benches, pews, or
other seating facilities, each twenty inches (20") of such seating facilities
shall be counted as one seat.
      5.   Employees: Employees shall be based on the maximum number of persons
on duty or residing, or both, on the premises at any one time.
      6.   When parking requirements are computed on the basis of capacity,
capacity shall be determined by the building code or other official
determinations of occupancy in effect for the city of Bettendorf at the time
the use is established.

11-13-8: PLOT PLAN:
Any application for a building permit, or for a certificate of occupancy, shall
include therewith a plot plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, showing
all parking facilities required by this chapter. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017)
11-13-9: MODIFICATIONS:
The board of adjustment may authorize or appeal a modification, reduction, or
waiver of the foregoing requirements, if it should find that, in the particular
case appealed, the peculiar nature of the residential, business, trade,
industrial, or other use, or the exceptional shape or size of the property or
other exceptional situation or condition, would justify such action. Exception:
Cases for properties located in the Downtown Master Plan District shall be
governed by Section
11-13-7(A)(2). (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 05-23, 1-17-2023)
11-13-10: OFF-STREET LOADING:
   A.   Scope: The provisions of this article shall apply and govern in all
districts.
   B.   Requirement: Off-street loading space shall be required and maintained
in connection with any building or part thereof, hereafter erected or altered
which is to be occupied by uses requiring the receipt or distribution of
materials or merchandise.
   C.   Location: Off-street loading space shall be located on the same lot as
the structure for which provided.
   D.   Duty To Provide: The duty to provide the off-street loading space
herein required shall be the joint and several responsibility of the operator
and the owner of the structure or structures for which off-street loading
spaces are required to be provided. No structure shall be designed, erected,
altered, used, or occupied unless the off-street loading space herein required
is provided in at least the amount herein set forth, provided, however, that
off-street loading space need not be provided for structures actually used,
occupied, and operated on the effective date hereof unless, after the effective
date hereof, such structures are enlarged or expanded, or the uses within such
structures are enlarged, expanded, or changed, so as to require a greater
amount of off-street loading space than the amount of off-street loading space
not required to be furnished by reason of the foregoing exclusion, in which
event, the structures hereby excluded shall not be used, occupied, or operated
unless there is provided for the increment only of such structures, and
maintained as herein required, at least the amount of off-street loading space
that would be required hereunder if the increment were a separate structure.
   E.   Design, Development, And Maintenance: Every parcel of land hereafter
used for off-street loading space shall be designed, developed, and maintained
in accordance with the following requirements:
      1.   Off-street loading spaces shall not be used for the sale, repair,
dismantling, or servicing of any vehicles, equipment, materials, or supplies.
      2.   Off-street loading spaces shall be graded for proper drainage and
provided with an all-weather surfacing maintained at all times in such a manner
as to prevent the release of dust and to be free of dust, trash, and debris.
      3.   Off-street loading spaces that adjoin or are across the street from
property zoned for any residential use shall have a dense evergreen planting,
fence, masonry wall, or such other screening as may be determined by the board
of adjustment. The board of adjustment shall also determine the height,
location, and density of screening used to provide adequate protection to
adjoining property.
      4.   Off-street loading spaces shall be provided with entrances and exits
not less than twelve feet (12') in width and so located as to minimize traffic
congestion.
      5.   No portion of a vehicle shall project into a street or alley while
being loaded or unloaded.
      6.   Each off-street loading space shall be not less than ten feet (10')
in width, twenty five feet (25') in length, and twelve feet (12') in height,
exclusive of access drives. When more than three (3) spaces are required, the
spaces other than the first three (3) shall be twelve feet (12') in width,
sixty five feet (65') in length, and fifteen (15') feet in height.
      7.   Off-street loading space may occupy all or any part of any required
yard space, other than the front yard or side yard adjoining a street.
   F.   Space Required: At least the following amounts of off-street loading
space shall be provided, plus an area or means adequate for maneuvering,
ingress, and egress:
   Table 11-13-10F
Square Feet Of Gross Floor Area Required Number Of Spaces
Square Feet Of Gross Floor Area             Required Number Of Spaces
Banks, office buildings, funeral parlors, hospitals and all other uses:
 Up to 100,000                             1
 For each additional 100,000 up to 500,000 1 additional
 For each additional 500,000               1 additional
Industrial, warehouse and storage buildings:
 Up to 20,000                              1
 20,001 to 40,000                          2
 40,001 to 70,000                          3
 70,001 to 120,000                         4
 120,001 to 200,000                        5
 For each additional 100,000               1 additional
Retail stores, theaters, auditoriums, bowling alleys, hotels and wholesale
establishments:
 Up to 20,000                              1
 20,001 to 50,000                          2
 50,001 to 100,000                         3
 For each additional 100,000               1 additional
 
   G.   Modifications: The board of adjustment may authorize an appeal
modification, reduction, or waiver of the foregoing requirements if it should
find that, in the particular case appealed, the peculiar nature of the
business, trade, industrial, or other use, as represented by the owner or
developer, or the exceptional shape or size of the property or other
exceptional situation or condition, would justify such action. (Ord. 35-17, 10-
17-2017)
11-13-11: TEMPORARY PARKING OF RECREATIONAL VEHICLES:
Restrictions: Recreational vehicles may be parked on unenclosed parking spaces
upon any residentially-zoned lot for a period of up to eight (8) consecutive
hours no more often than twice in any seven (7) consecutive-day period. At
least thirty (30) hours must separate each occurrence. Additionally,
recreational vehicles may be parked on unenclosed parking spaces for up to one
hundred sixty eight (168) consecutive hours four (4) times per year for the
purpose of visiting, loading, unloading, or repair. The owner of any
recreational vehicle parking said vehicle on unenclosed parking spaces for more
than eight (8) hours but less than one hundred sixty eight (168) hours shall
notify the zoning administrator of their intent to do so prior to such action.
Said notification shall include such information as may be required by the
zoning administrator in order to adequately enforce this provision. Upon the
expiration of the one hundred sixty eight (168) hours, the vehicle shall be
removed or otherwise lawfully parked. While temporarily parked, the vehicle may
be connected to the property's water and electrical utilities for charging or
loading of the vehicle's systems. Said vehicle shall not extend onto or over
any public right of way while so parked. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017)
11-13-12: BICYCLE PARKING:
   A.   Parking Requirements:
      1.   Each parking facility over twenty five (25) spaces shall provide one
bicycle parking space per twenty five (25) vehicle parking spaces.
      2.   A minimum of two (2) bicycle parking spaces shall be provided in
addition to the requirements above for all multi-family residential,
administration, recreational club, park and recreation, public assembly,
education, and commercial recreation uses listed in Chapter 4 of this title.
   B.   Parking Exemptions: Bicycle parking requirements do not apply to the
following use types:
      1.   All agricultural uses listed in Chapter 4, Table
11-4-5A of this title.
      2.   All industrial, transportation, and miscellaneous uses listed in
Chapter 4, Table
11-4-5C of this title, excluding transportation terminals.
   C.   Parking Location And Design:
      1.   Bicycle parking facilities shall include bicycle racks secured to
prevent easy removal, bicycle lockers, or bicycle posts or bollards expressly
designed for the secure storage.
      2.   The location of bicycle parking facilities shall be at least as
convenient to the main entrance of the primary use as the most convenient
automobile parking not reserved for use by disabled people.
      3.   All bicycle parking shall be located along a direct pedestrian route
to the main entrance of the primary use.
      4.   Bicycle parking should be located to prevent hazards or obstructions
to the normal flow of pedestrians into a use, including a five-foot (5') aisle
behind all bicycle parking. The required aisle may extend into the sidewalk
area if it does not interfere with accessible paths of travel as required for
ADA compliance. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017)
CHAPTER 14
SIGN ORDINANCE
SECTION:
11-14-1: Intent And Purpose
11-14-2: Permits Required
11-14-3: General Requirements And Restrictions
11-14-4: Removal and Conformance Requirements
11-14-5: Permitted Signs Within Zoning Districts
11-14-6: Specific Sign Regulations
11-14-7: Table Of Sign Types, Definitions, And Restrictions
11-14-8: Billboard Signs (Off-Premises Advertising)
11-14-9: Appeals
11-14-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
This chapter is intended to control and regulate the development of signs
within the city. There is a significant relationship between the manner in
which signs are displayed, the public health, safety and welfare, and the
value, compatibility, and economic stability of adjoining property, its land
use, and the city. The reasonable display of signs is necessary as a service to
the people in the conduct of competitive commercial and industrial activity and
to promote freedom of expression. The regulations in this article establish
standards for the display of signs in direct relationship to the above stated
purposes and directives. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 24-24, 12-3-2024)
11-14-2: PERMITS REQUIRED:
When the regulations of this article require a permit, said permit shall be
obtained from the zoning administrator or his designee. Where sections of this
code as applied to structures, particularly the uniform sign ordinances as
adopted by the city, are applicable, said permits must also be approved by the
Bettendorf Building Department. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 24-24, 12-3-
2024)
11-14-3: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
All signs must comply with the following conditions:
   A.   Obstructing Vision: No sign shall be placed so as to obstruct vision at
street intersections and driveway intersections for oncoming vehicles.
   B.   Permit Required; Display Name: When a permit is required for any
particular sign, said sign shall display the name of the owner and erector.
   C.   Blocking Accessway Or Window: No sign shall block any required
accessway.
   D.   Attaching To Tree Or Pole: No sign shall be attached to a tree or
utility pole.
   E.   Unauthorized Signs Prohibited: All signs not authorized by this chapter
are prohibited.
   F.   Public Service And Safety Signs: No signs other than public service and
safety signs shall be permitted on public property unless authorized by the
governmental agency having control thereof.
   G.   Lighting, Illumination, And Luminance:
      1.   No lighting shall be used in any way in connection with any sign
unless it is of such low intensity or brilliance as to not cause glare or to
impair the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle, or to otherwise interfere
with any driver's operation of a motor vehicle. In no case shall any sign
exceed a maximum luminance of five thousand (5,000) candelas per square meter
(nits) during daylight hours and a maximum of two hundred (200) candelas per
square meter (nits) between dusk and dawn as measured from the sign's face at
maximum brightness.
      2.   The above maximum luminance levels are not a guaranteed allowable
level of brightness, only a maximum potential level of brightness. When a
citizen complaint of a violation of Subsection
11-14-3G of this section has been confirmed by the zoning administrator, said
sign shall have its luminance permanently reduced to satisfy compliance with
Subsection
11-14-3G of this section as directed by the zoning administrator regardless of
the above-stated maximum allowable levels. An appeal of the zoning
administrator's decision regarding Subsection
11-14-3G of this section may be presented to the Bettendorf Board of Adjustment
in accordance with Section
11-15-12 of this title.
   H.   Electronically-Changing Copy: Signs capable of electronically-changing
copy, display graphics, or images shall not permit same to change at a rate
faster than once every eight (8) seconds. Flashing is prohibited. Video is
prohibited. Alphanumeric scrolling messages are allowed, except for off-
premises advertising signs (see
11-14-8: Billboard Signs for supplemental regulations for off-premises
advertising signs). (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 24-24, 12-3-2024)
11-14-4: REMOVAL AND CONFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS:
It is the intent of this section to recognize that the eventual elimination, as
expeditiously as it is reasonable, of existing signs that are not in conformity
with the provisions of this chapter is as much a subject of the health, safety,
and welfare of the public as is the prohibition of new signs that would violate
the provisions of this chapter. It is also the intent of this section that any
elimination of nonconforming signs shall be effected so as to avoid any
unreasonable invasion of established private property rights. The zoning
administrator shall cause removal of a sign or sign structure if the property
owner fails to comply with the standards of this chapter within ten (10) days
after being issued a written notification from the zoning administrator. Any
expense incurred by the city in removing or repairing the sign or sign
structure shall be paid by the owner of the property to which the sign is
attached.
   A.   Nonconforming Signs:
      1.   Any nonconforming off-premises sign which does not advertise a bona
fide business, product, or organization, or becomes obsolete because the
business or organization has relocated, shall be removed by the owner within
one hundred twenty (120) days of the termination or relocation of the business,
product, or organization being advertised. Removal of obsolete signs shall
include the supporting structure, exclusive of any building, if all signs on
the structure are obsolete.
      2.   Any nonconforming off-premises sign which is severely damaged and
requires over fifty percent (50%) of the cost of replacement for repair shall
be removed within one hundred twenty (120) days after the date of the damage.
Removal of damaged signs shall include the supporting structure exclusive of
any building, if all signs on the structure are nonconforming.
   B.   Obsolete Signs: Any obsolete sign which does not advertise a bona fide
business conducted, or a product sold, shall be taken down and removed by the
owner, agent, or person having the beneficial use of the structure upon which
such sign may be found within ten (10) days after written notification from the
zoning administrator. Upon failure to comply with such notice within the time
specified in such order, the zoning administrator may cause removal of such
sign, and any expense incident thereto shall be paid by the owner of the
property to which such a sign is attached.
   C.   Unsafe And Unlawful Signs: If the zoning administrator shall find that
any sign is unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been
constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of
this article, he/she shall give written notice to the person to whom the zoning
certificate had been issued. If he/she fails to remove or alter the sign so as
to comply with the standards herein set forth within ten (10) days after such
notice, such sign may be removed or altered to comply by the zoning
administrator at the expense of the holder of the zoning certificate issued or
owner of the property upon which it is located. The zoning administrator shall
refuse to issue a zoning certificate to any such party or owner who refuses to
pay costs so assessed. The zoning administrator may cause any sign which is an
immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily and without
notice.
   D.   Alterations: No display sign or outdoor advertising device shall be
altered, rebuilt, enlarged, extended, or relocated except in conformity with
the provisions of this title. Minor repainting, changing of parts, and
preventative maintenance of signs shall not be deemed to be alterations.
Repainting, changing of parts, and preventative maintenance of signs consisting
of more than fifty percent (50%) of the original cost of said sign, as shown on
the original building permit, shall be considered an alteration.
   E.   Maintenance: The owner of any sign requiring a permit shall be required
to maintain an exterior which is properly painted, galvanized, or otherwise
treated to prevent rust and deterioration of all parts and supports. (Ord. 35-
17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 24-24, 12-3-2024)

11-14-6: SPECIFIC SIGN REGULATIONS:
All signs which are listed in Section
11-14-5 of this chapter are listed below. The following regulations govern the
use of specific types of signs which are allowed within the applicable zoning
districts. Subsections
11-14-6A through H of this section explain the standards, phrases, and
abbreviations subsequently used for each type of sign.
A.   Type:
   1.   Each sign has a "type str." item which shows the permitted type of sign
structure which is permitted as shown in the applicable table.
 
One Face A sign structure with not more than one sign surface.
         A sign with one sign surface or not more than two sign surfaces where
Two Face the two sign surfaces back to each other and face opposite or nearly
         opposite directions.
Bldg     Signs attached to a building.
Mon      A ground mounted monument sign.
Pole     A sign mounted upon a pole or poles raised up seven (7) feet above
         ground level.
 
   2.   Types of signs not listed below are not permitted for that sign.
B.   Size: Any sign shall not exceed the maximum number of square feet listed
for that sign on any one side or surface as shown in the applicable table.
C.   Illumination: Signs may be illuminated when indicated in the applicable
table by one of the following general methods shown as "Ill."
 
Back  An illumination permitted by producing a sign translucent in total or in
      part and placing light behind and within the structure of such sign.
      Electronic programmable sign. A sign that is electronically programmable
      to change copy or display graphics and/or images. Electronic programmable
      signs shall not permit same to change at a rate faster than once every
EPS   eight (8) seconds. Flashing is prohibited. Video is prohibited.
      Alphanumeric scrolling messages are allowed, except for off-premises
      advertising signs (see
      11-14-8: Billboard Signs for supplemental regulations for off-premises
      advertising signs).
Exp   An exposed lighting source that is not obscured by any part of the sign
      structure.
Flood An illumination permitted by a light shining upon the sign located apart
      from the sign structure and directed toward the sign.
None  No illumination permitted at all.
      An illumination permitted by producing a sign with opaque characteristics
Sil   and placing a light behind the characteristics so as to outline the
      characteristic with the glow from the lighting source creating a
      silhouette.
 
D.   Height: Any sign shall not exceed the maximum height in feet above average
ground level listed for that sign as shown in the applicable table. The bottom
of any pole sign shall not be lower than seven feet (7') above average ground
level.
 
NTE Not to exceed.
 
E.   Location: Signs (not attached to buildings) are permitted on that portion
of each parcel indicated for that sign as shown on the applicable table.
 
NCT  A sign must be located "not closer than" the designated distance from the
     property line.
     No restriction as to location on the parcel other than those written in
None Section
     11-10D-3 of this title.
 
F.   Number: No category of sign shall be displayed in greater number than
listed in the applicable table except the phrase "one per interior lot" shall
also mean two (2) per corner lot with one sign oriented to each of the streets
forming the corner.
G.   Special Conditions: Each sign may have a "special conditions" item(s)
which may indicate other condition(s) or restriction(s) not previously listed.
H.   Projection: Sign may project from a building into the setback by not more
than the applicable number shown in the table below. (See Section
11-14-7.) (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 24-24, 12-3-2024)

   1.   Institutional Identification Sign: A permanent, on-premises sign for

11-14-8: APPEALS:
   A.   Definitions:
      1.   Off-Premises Advertising: A sign which advertises a business,
service, product, or activity at a location other than where the business,
service, product, or activity is located.
      2.   Billboard Sign (Static): A static display sign and its structural
support containing content that is off-premises advertising.
      3.   Billboard Sign (Digital Display): An electronic programmable sign
(EPS) and its structural support containing content that is off-premises
advertising.
      4.   New Billboard Sign: The construction of a billboard sign (static) or
billboard (sign) digital in a location where no billboard sign existed; or the
conversion of an existing billboard sign (static) to a billboard sign (digital
display).
   B.   Location:
      1.   Permitted Districts: Billboard signs are permitted in I-1, I-2, I-3,
C-3, C-6, C-7 Zoning Districts. Billboard signs are also permitted in the C-
2 zoning district if within six hundred sixty feet (660') of a U.S. highway or
interstate right-of-way.
      2.   Downtown Master Plan Overlay District Exclusion: Regardless of the
underlying zoning district, no billboard signs shall be permitted in the
Downtown Master Plan Overlay District, nor any other overlay district that does
not allow billboard signs.
   C.   Distance Buffers:
      1.   Residential Areas: All billboard signs shall be located at a minimum
distance of five hundred feet (500') from any residential zoning district in
Bettendorf or adjacent cities.
      2.   Parks: All billboard signs shall be located a minimum distance of
five hundred feet (500') from any designated public park in Bettendorf or
adjacent cities.
      3.   Billboard Separation: All billboard signs shall be separated by a
minimum distance of two thousand feet (2,000').
      4.   All listed buffer requirements shall apply to all newly-constructed
billboard signs regardless of sign viability due to topography, tree cover, or
other considerations.
   D.   Height:
      1.   A maximum height of thirty feet (30') as measured from the base of
the billboard sign support structure to the highest point of the billboard sign
(including sign face).
   E.   Yard Requirements:
      1.   Billboard signs shall be subject to the yard requirements
established for principal uses for the district in which they are located.
   F.   Maximum Sign Surface Area:
      1.   A billboard sign shall contain no more than six hundred seventy two
(672) square feet of sign surface area per face.
   G.   Maximum Number of Faces:
      1.   No billboard sign shall have more than two (2) faces. A face shall
be considered the display surface upon which an advertising message is
displayed.
   H.   Face Orientation:
      1.   No billboard sign shall have more than one (1) face (display
surface) oriented in the same vertical plane.
   I.   Name Of Owner:
      1.   No billboard sign shall be maintained in the City unless the name of
the person or company owning or maintaining it is plainly displayed thereon.
   J.   Illumination:
      1.   Illumination of billboard signs (static) shall be permitted if the
lighting is non-flashing.
      2.   Back and Flood lighting are permitted for billboard signs (static).
      3.   See subsection M for billboard signs (digital display) criteria.
   K.   Number Permitted:
      1.   The total number of billboard signs shall not exceed the total
number of billboard signs legally existing in the City on January 1, 2025,
minus any billboard signs which are removed and not replaced and minus any
reduction in the number of billboard signs pursuant to the conversion process
described in subsection M1c. Billboard signs are permitted to be replaced on a
billboard sign by billboard sign basis. A variance of dimensional standards or
a conditional use granted for the placement of a new billboard sign shall not
waive the requirement for removal of an existing sign to place a new billboard
sign.
   L.   Replacement Of Existing Billboard Signs:
      1.   A permit for a new billboard sign shall require the removal of an
existing billboard sign.
      2.   If the owner of a proposed new billboard sign owns a billboard sign
that is nonconforming to Section
11-14-8 of this code, then the billboard sign removed to satisfy the
requirements to construct a new billboard sign must be a nonconforming sign.
      3.   Upon removal of an existing billboard sign, the City shall record
the location, owner of structure, and other relevant information about the
billboard sign for ten (10) years from the date of removal, thus creating a
billboard sign credit. A removed billboard sign that is part of the City's
billboard sign credit record can be used to satisfy the removal requirement. If
the billboard sign credit is not claimed (used for a new billboard sign or
conversion to a digital display billboard sign) within ten (10) years, the
billboard sign shall be considered removed and the total number of billboard
signs permitted in the City shall be reduced by one.
         a.   The owner of the billboard sign credit shall be assumed to be the
owner of the billboard sign (static or digital display) prior to demolition or
removal. This does not supersede private party agreements, leases, or contract
terms. Evidence providing proof of ownership of a billboard sign credit shall
be required prior to issuance of a building permit for a new billboard sign
(static or digital display) or for the conversion of a billboard sign (static)
to billboard sign (digital display) as specified in subsection L5.
      4.   The owner of a legal billboard sign within the community may
transfer the right to build a new billboard sign to another party. The transfer
shall be stated in a letter signed by both parties which is submitted with an
application for a new billboard sign.
      5.   Prior to the issuance of a building permit for any billboard sign
subject to the requirements of this Chapter, the applicant shall provide the
following:
         a.   The telephone number of a maintenance service, to be available
twenty-four (24) hours a day, to be contacted in the event that a billboard
sign becomes dilapidated or damaged, or malfunctions in the case of a billboard
sign (digital display).
         b.   Proof of lease demonstrating a right to install the billboard
sign on the subject property.
         c.   Proof of lease or deed demonstrating ownership of a removed
billboard sign. The intent of this requirement is to facilitate verification of
the applicant's right to use of a billboard sign credit created from the
removal of a billboard sign.
         d.   A list and map of locations of all billboard signs in the City
owned or managed by the entity that will own or manage the subject billboard
sign, to the satisfaction of the Community Development Director. The intent of
this requirement is to facilitate analysis of the proposed billboard sign's
compliance with the spacing and location requirements, as well as the
nonconforming billboard sign removal requirements of this Chapter.
         e.   An application for a new billboard sign may be made in
anticipation of removal of an existing billboard sign. Such application may be
approved on the condition that no permit for the construction of the new
billboard sign shall be issued until the existing billboard sign is removed and
documentation of the removal is submitted to the City.
   M.   Billboard Sign (Digital Display) Criteria:
      1.   A billboard sign (digital display) is permitted under the following
criteria:
         a.   The following standards shall apply to billboard signs (digital
display) erected after the effective date of this ordinance, including existing
billboard signs (static) that are converted to billboard signs (digital
display) after said effective date, also referred to as "new".
         b.   Erection of a new billboard sign (digital display) shall require
the removal of an existing billboard sign (static or digital display).
         c.   Conversion of an existing billboard sign (static) to a billboard
sign (digital display) shall meet the following requirements:
            (1)   The location and dimensional requirements shall conform to
all requirements set forth in Section
11-14-8 of this code. Billboard signs (static) which do not conform to
Bettendorf City Code shall not be converted to billboard signs (digital
display).
            (2)   Conversion of an existing billboard sign (static) to a
billboard sign (digital display) shall require the removal of one existing
billboard sign (static or digital display) other than the one to be converted.
The total number of billboard signs (static or digital display) allowed in the
City of Bettendorf will be reduced by one as the result of a conversion.
            (3)   All standards set forth in subsection L shall be met.
         d.   No animation, flashing, video or scrolling text shall be
permitted on a billboard sign (digital display) during or in transition between
messages. Any image or message or part of a message displayed on the billboard
sign (digital display) shall have a minimum duration of eight (8) seconds and
shall be static display. Transition time between images or messages or part of
a message must be no longer than two (2) seconds.
         e.   In the event of a public emergency, such as an Amber Alert,
natural disaster, or other state of emergency, the owner of a billboard sign
(digital display) shall coordinate with public authorities and allow space for
the display of relevant messages to the public.
         f.   The maximum brightness during daylight hours is limited to five
thousand (5,000) candelas per square meter (nits) when measured from the
billboard sign's (digital display) face at its maximum color brightness
(white). The maximum brightness between dusk and dawn (i.e. the time of day
between sunset and sunrise) is limited to two hundred (200) candelas per square
meter (nits) when measured from the billboard sign's (digital display) face at
its maximum color brightness (white). The billboard sign (digital display) must
have an ambient light meter installed and contain automatic dimmer technology
that automatically adjusts the display's brightness based on ambient light
conditions. (Ord. 24-24, 12-3-2024)
11-14-9: APPEALS:
Any person or persons aggrieved by the decision of the zoning administrator to
approve or disapprove a sign permit, as provided by this section, may appeal
such decision to the Board of Adjustment as provided by subsection
11-15-12D of this title. (Ord. 35-17, 10-17-2017; amd. Ord. 24-24, 12-3-2024)
CHAPTER 15
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
